TEXT:
Der russische Landwirtschaftsminister Alexander Tkatschow verhaspelte sich bei einem Treffen mit Wladimir Putin

Er schlug vor, Schweinefleisch nach Indonesien zu exportieren

Putin hatte daraufhin einen Lachanfall, den ihr in dem Video sehen kÃ¶nnt

Auch Politprofis kÃ¶nnen nicht immer ernst bleiben: Der russische PrÃ¤sident Wladimir Putin hatte jedenfalls bei einem Treffen mit seinem Landwirtschaftsminister Alexander Tkatschow seinen SpaÃŸ. Denn dieser schlug Putin vor, Schweinefleisch nach Indonesien zu exportieren.

Tkatschow schlug bei dem Treffen vor, der deutschen Strategie zu folgen und mehr Schweinefleisch nach Asien zu exportieren. "Deutschland exportiert die HÃ¤lfte seines Schweinefleischs. Schauen sie Deutschlands Zahlen an: FÃ¼nfeinhalb Millionen Tonnen Schwein produzieren sie im Jahr, beinahe drei Millionen davon exportieren sie in andere LÃ¤nder, nach China, Indonesien, Japan, Korea, und so weiter", sagte er.

"Indonesien ist ein muslimisches Land, sie essen kein Schwein"

"Indonesien ist ein muslimisches Land, sie essen kein Schwein", unterbrach ihn Putin lachend. Tkatschow versuchte, sich davon nicht beirren zu lassen und mit seinem Vortrag weiter zu machen. Doch Putin konnte sich mittlerweile vor lauter Lachen nicht mehr beruhigen.

SpÃ¤ter berichtigte der Landwirtschaftsminister das MissverstÃ¤ndnis und erklÃ¤rte, er habe SÃ¼dkorea gemeint und nicht Indonesien.
TITLE: Putin kriegt sich vor Lachen nicht mehr ein, weil sein Minister einen ziemlich dÃ¤mlichen Vorschlag gemacht hat

Paul Keating has weighed into Victoria's controversial assisted-dying bill as debate in the state's parliament drags out.
Former prime minister Paul Keating has weighed into the debate on Victoria's controversial assisted-dying laws, saying allowing patients to kill themselves is unacceptable.
While Victoria's parliament wades through hundreds of disputed amendments amid a looming government deadline for a vote, Mr Keating is urging against crossing what he calls an "ethical threshold".
Today, Parliament will debate our legislation to allow voluntary assisted dying.
Let's deal w/ voluntary assisted dying.
TEXT:
Paul Keating has weighed into Victoria's controversial assisted-dying bill as debate in the state's parliament drags out.

Former prime minister Paul Keating has weighed into the debate on Victoria's controversial assisted-dying laws, saying allowing patients to kill themselves is unacceptable.

While Victoria's parliament wades through hundreds of disputed amendments amid a looming government deadline for a vote, Mr Keating is urging against crossing what he calls an "ethical threshold".

"What matters is that under Victorian law there will be people whose lives we honour and those we believe are better off dead," he wrote in Fairfax's Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday.

"No matter what justifications are offered for the bill, it constitutes an unacceptable departure in our approach to human existence and the irrevocable sanctity that should govern our understanding of what it means to be human."

Voluntary euthanasia is a threshold Australia should not cross, writes former PM Paul Keating #auspol https://t.co/KR7E81kzOG â€” Michael Koziol (@michaelkoziol) October 19, 2017

The state government hopes to get its divisive bill through the lower house by the end of the week.

But line-by-line scrutiny of the proposed laws and hundreds of proposed amendments from opponents has stalled progress.

The bid to introduce assisted dying for the terminally ill survived its first threat on Wednesday night - an amendment by Deputy Premier James Merlino which would have halted immediate further consideration of the bill.

But debate spilled over to insults within the government, with Health Minister Jill Hennessy calling Mr Merlino a "c***" in a text message sent to him by mistake the same night, multiple parliamentary sources confirm.

Today, Parliament will debate our legislation to allow voluntary assisted dying. The time for this change has come. pic.twitter.com/oIi0aKMvRX â€” Daniel Andrews (@DanielAndrewsMP) October 16, 2017

Premier Daniel Andrews said he would not support any of the amendments.

"This is a good bill. It is the product of a long and considered process involving experts," he told reporters on Thursday.

"I don't reflect negatively on anyone who moves amendments. That is their right.

"(But) many of them will be moved by people, who even if those amendments were successful, would not vote for the bill."

Let's deal w/ voluntary assisted dying. We owe it 2 Victorians suffering unbearably @ the end of life #springst #VAD https://t.co/0w2wfN8JK9 â€” JillHennessyMP (@JillHennessyMP) October 16, 2017

Ms Hennessy said the debate had been emotional, but had shown parliamentarians to be authentic and vulnerable.

"It's really hard to talk about death at the best of times but to debate significant reform about giving people a better death is really challenging but it can bring out the best in our parliamentarians," she told reporters.

"We're going to keep fighting hard to try and bring this home."

Parliament is expected to sit late into Thursday night and may return on Friday - usually not a sitting day - if needed.
TITLE: Former Prime Minister Paul Keating Weighs Into Assisted-Dying Debate

SUMMARY:
PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Memories Of Summer In The Cinque Terre To be suddenly transported away from the daily grind to this magical place, and to be able to experience it together, was an incredibly special experience.
Travel journalist, blogger at English Mum PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Peruvian Nostalgia: A Happy Travel Moment It's those little things, the five-minute moments and the spontaneous detours you'll never forget that are the best thing about holidays for me.
Travel blogger at Flash AnthologyA Blogger's Guide To St Lucia The first thing that hits you about St Lucia is the incredible scenery.
Writer & journalist48 Hours In... St Lucia Everything about St Lucia is green.
Irish Travel Blogger.
TEXT:
PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Memories Of Summer In The Cinque Terre To be suddenly transported away from the daily grind to this magical place, and to be able to experience it together, was an incredibly special experience. London-based photographer and blogger at skyeoneill.com

PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Disneyland Paris - My Best Holiday Moment You might think a visit to Nepal or a climb on Kilimanjaro would've been more appropriate for the best holiday moment blog post. For me, it was the emotion of a lost childhood recaptured in three days. It was the child in me finally seeing a dream come true. London-based lifestyle influencer, eatweartravel.com PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Wonderful, Wonderful Copenhagen With Family This year however, have decided to be a little more organised with our long weekends - and have MADE time to leave London, (and paused all the weekend clubs!) and jump on a plane to mainland Europe - to places we've never been before... London-based creative communicator, writer, and designer PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS How Mickey Mouse Changed My Life Spotting beautiful Cinderella Castle for the first time, pretty, pastel and huge at the end of bustling Main Street USA, we're already grabbing each other's hands, laughing and breathless with disbelief. Travel journalist, blogger at English Mum PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Peruvian Nostalgia: A Happy Travel Moment It's those little things, the five-minute moments and the spontaneous detours you'll never forget that are the best thing about holidays for me. Surround yourself with holiday memories and whenever you get a chance, go and make more! Travel blogger at Flash Anthology

A Blogger's Guide To St Lucia The first thing that hits you about St Lucia is the incredible scenery. I can totally understand why the island is so popular with honeymooners and for romantic getaways; the landscape is so lush that it feels seriously romantic. So much so, I didn't put my camera down apart from when I was actually sleeping and eating. TV Presenter/ Blogger/ My Travel Inspired Collection #Naomi by @brixandbailey and Mummy to @theistedkids

How To Prepare For A Long Distance Hike Don't bother with the Hilton. Avoid the Marriot. Nothing beats looking out of your tent on a clear night and seeing millions of stars in the sky. It offers a tonne more flexibility- often you can choose a place that suits you. For summer, tents can be less than one kilogram, and a great lightweight sleeping bag can be 450g. I find it's almost always worth it. Ultrarunner and Sports and Exercise Medicine consultant for the University of Edinburgh

Travel Eye: The Unforgettable Magic Of Whale Watching In Alaska My partner Brad and I are with a small group of guests on a small rubber power boat called a Zodiac, at the Chiswell Islands in the Gulf of Alaska. A Humpback whale has been feeding around us, at the surface of the water, for 45 minutes. Freelance travel & entertainment editor based in London

Chapter 3: Holbox Island "Welcome home", I was told with a smile as I stepped into CasaSandra after a mammoth 20 hour journey from London to Holbox Island and it felt like home. All my worries and apprehension were washed away the moment I walked up the candlelit footpath of the boutique hotel. My Mexican adventure had begun. Presenter, DJ, writer, and secret hopeless romantic

Travel - The Baby Edition Long gone are the days of basking peacefully in the sun on an isolated beach in the Mediterranean, or the indulgent yet meditative afternoon walks down 5th Avenue exercising both legs and credit card Mother and writer.

Why I Hate The Phrase 'Gap Year' The amount of times I've heard people say to me; "do it why you're young", as if the only time that we should open ourselves up to new possibilities is when we're still young enough to enjoy them, before age, and responsibility bears down on us, and we can no longer afford to take a break from our lives. Writer & journalist

48 Hours In... St Lucia Everything about St Lucia is green. From her lushly vegetated peaks undulating across the teardrop shaped island, to her twinkling emerald waters, it's a Caribbean paradise chock-full of geological marvels. Arts, lifestyle and socio-political writer

Traversing The Rockies - Week 4 (D28-30) After 10km, and a river crossing made making us unavoidably wet, we lost the path. Multiple small rivers and bogs had us pretty much soaked. One river crossing had to be made across a log and while Stan managed it with relative ease, I obviously fell off and into fast flowing river up to my hips. Lucy is a London based Doctor setting out to traverse the Canadian Rocky Mountains on the Great Divide Trail- 2 people, 60 days, 1600km.

Is This Ireland's Best Kept Secret? I thought I knew this part of Ireland pretty well until we arrived in Glengarriff and I quickly realised this is a part of my home county I have failed to explore. The view from our hotel upon check in was magical, the soft evening light reflecting on the bay. Irish Travel Blogger. Skyscanner addict.

Traversing The Rockies - Week Four (D25-27) After a warm night, and consequently an abundance of mozzies we started out along the Brazeau River. Expecting torrential rain from Diane's sat phone weather report, we donned our waterproofs at the first raindrops but this proved to be a big mistake with the upcoming climb! Lucy is a London based Doctor setting out to traverse the Canadian Rocky Mountains on the Great Divide Trail- 2 people, 60 days, 1600km.
TITLE: Travel: Ideas, Advice and Tips On Flights, Hotels And Holidays

SUMMARY:
Ethical fashion advocate.
Founder of Annaborgia â€“ ethical glamour, slow fashion & sustainable bridal wear made in Italy & USA.
That's how much fabric is wasted by the fashion industry during the cutting and manufacturing process.
Imagine the irony of a much-loved industry that's second only to oil as the world's most polluting line of business: that's the fashion industry too.
/ goblackwood.co.ukRedefining Female Innovation: Sustainable Fashion It's funny how one can be so engrained in a journey that it takes someone else to point out how far you've come.
TEXT:
Unnatural Phenomena: Three Weird Things That Shouldn't Be Happening Right Now... As we all know, the world is pretty weird right now - American politics, North Korea, climate change, fast fashion, landfill waste... The list goes on. But here are three important unnatural phenomena that have managed to largely slip under the radar. Co-founder of BOOBY Shoes. Passionate about start-ups, conservation, all things outdoors... and a boat shoe lover! www.boobyshoes.com

Saving The World In Style, For 10 Years It's been 10 years of developing sustainable supply chains, building relationships with incredible artisans around the world, opening a studio and boutique showroom in Bloomsbury, dressing celebrities, hundreds of patterns, hour upon hour of stitching, cutting, ironing, marketing, photo shoots, selling, networking, bookkeeping, signing contracts, advising, teaching, training, putting on shows... Sustainable couturier to the stars

What Do These Ethical Labels Really Mean? Confused between Fairtade, Fair for Life, organic, ethical? Want to know what you're really putting in your basket in the supermarket? Let's demystify some of the thinking behind the labels shall we? Editor of pebble magazine. Fashion, food, travel and design with an ethical edge.

Why Don't We Wear Our Wedding Dresses Again? Despite their best intentions, few women these days ever wear their bridesmaid's dresses again and although it's probably the most expensive dress they'll ever own, most women only wear their wedding dress once. Ethical fashion advocate. Founder of Annaborgia â€“ ethical glamour, slow fashion & sustainable bridal wear made in Italy & USA.

The Myth Of Magnificence: Price, Perception And Why Provenance In Luxury Matters To cite Oscar Wilde, too many of us know the price of everything, but the value of nothing. Thankfully, transparency is now determining price tags much more than before and consumers will vote with their purses. Economics of scale state that it's the global companies who have the most capacity to foster systemic change, so let's hope that 'luxury' leads the way. Freelance writer, PR consultant and editor

Alpaca: 10 Things To Know And Love About This Supremely Sustainable Fibre Alpaca fibres are sorted and classified by their thickness and colour, by hand. This process can never be mechanised because the variable characteristics of the fibre can only be identified by experienced hands and eyes. Founder, STUDY 34

Time To Put An End To Killer Heels Shoe production is a shady world. There is little to no transparency throughout the shoe industry, and complex global supply chains make it nearly impossible to pick up a shoe in a high street store and trace its origins. Director of Labour Behind the Label

Time To Practice Not Preach On Zero Waste Fashion Imagine a blanket that covers about a quarter of the UK - spanning about 60billion square meters. That's how much fabric is wasted by the fashion industry during the cutting and manufacturing process. Imagine the irony of a much-loved industry that's second only to oil as the world's most polluting line of business: that's the fashion industry too. Garment technologist, pattern cutter, researching sustainable innovation through a technical design process.

Is High Street Sustainability An Oxymoron? Personally, I can think of plenty of other things to make me feel happier. But, being British, they usually depend on the weather: gardening, relaxing with family, enjoying a barbeque. If it's raining, I might finally get round to making the conservatory hygge for winter. CSR & sustainability consultant and blogger

How We Engineer A Solution To The Skills Gap Designed by Royal College of Art graduate Ryan Mario Yasin, Petit Pli employs the Negative Poisson's ratio to allow garments to expand in both directions - enabling them to continuously fit children as they grow. A neat solution to the problem of quickly outgrown clothing, so familiar - and frustrating - to parents. James Dyson Award Manager

Does Sustainability Need To Be Sexy To Sell? Even if you identify as someone who cares deeply about saving planet Earth, chances are, when you get dressed each morning, you're motivated first and foremost by style. That a product looks good, functions well, and has no negative impact is the goal. But, as the flawed human beings that we are, our decision making process usually follows this logic; design first and impact last. Communications Strategist living in The Netherlands. Originally from New Zealand, she now calls Amsterdam home.

Is Zero Waste Beauty The Next Big Trend? If you want to buy from a zero waste beauty brand, what should you be looking for? Let's go through the life cycle of a beauty product and unpick its journey from cradle to grave so that we can build up a clearer picture. Biologist, Environmental Scientist and Director of Formula Botanica, the award-winning organic cosmetic science school

Sexy Stories: You Might Be Wearing One At a gathering last year I listened with interest as Vanessa Friedman, Fashion Director at The New York Times, explained that in order for consumers to get on board with the words 'sustainable' and 'ethical' then we, the designers and makers of clothing, needed to find a way to make it sexy. Founder, STUDY 34

Why Vegan Leather Is On The Rise Consumers today are much more conscious of the ethics of what they're buying. High on the list is an approach to fashion which takes care of the environment and the people who make the things we wear. And this is where vegan leather comes in. Enthusiast of all the things that make the world a better place. / goblackwood.co.uk

Redefining Female Innovation: Sustainable Fashion It's funny how one can be so engrained in a journey that it takes someone else to point out how far you've come. I recently had my portrait taken by p... CEO of Ananas Anam Ltd.
TITLE: HuffPost UK Sustainable Fashion: Blogs, Advice And Reports On The Sustainable Fashion World

TEXT:
Samantha Renke was reduced to tears in the latest episode of â€˜New Activistsâ€™ after her wheelchair broke and engineers failed to provide her with a replacement.

The actress lives with brittle bone disease, making it incredibly difficult for her to move around without breaking a bone or being in pain.

She explained that her chair had broken and engineers had taken it away to fix. However in doing so, they had left her at home without a means of getting around.

â€œIâ€™m stuck, I canâ€™t go to the toilet, I canâ€™t get anything to eat,â€ she said.

â€œI wasnâ€™t even offered a spare wheelchair. If you break down a car, you get a spare car, and I canâ€™t even get a wheelchair.â€

Thankfully Samâ€™s friend was on hand to help her get around, but she understandably didnâ€™t want him to have to help her use the toilet - so she waited all day until the engineers returned.

At one point, when the engineers said they werenâ€™t sure whether they could get the wheelchair back to her that day, she became overwhelmed with emotion and burst into tears.

Frustrated beyond belief, she said: â€œI want to be responsible for me, because Iâ€™m an adult, but right now I canâ€™t.â€
TITLE: Samantha Renke Bursts Into Tears After Broken Wheelchair Leaves Her Stranded In Own Home

Christine Forster, in a scene mourning her partner, played by her real-life partner Virginia Edwards.
Sydney City Counsellor Christine Forster, whose campaigning on the marriage equality postal survey has put her at odds with her brother, former PM Tony Abbott, stars as a widow grieving her partner, who is played by her real-life partner Virginia Edwards.
Former NRL star Ian Roberts plays the father of a young man who struggles after coming out to his judgmental parents.

TEXT:
Christine Forster, in a scene mourning her partner, played by her real-life partner Virginia Edwards.

Some of Australia's most high profile LGBTQ leaders have starred in a confronting video set to a cover version of George Michael's 'Freedom'.

Sydney City Counsellor Christine Forster, whose campaigning on the marriage equality postal survey has put her at odds with her brother, former PM Tony Abbott, stars as a widow grieving her partner, who is played by her real-life partner Virginia Edwards.

In a shocking scene Edwards is killed falling down the stairs in their home, and Forster is later confronted with a death certificate which fails to list her as spouse.

Former NRL star Ian Roberts plays the father of a young man who struggles after coming out to his judgmental parents.

Former NRL star Ian Roberts plays a father at odds with his son's sexuality.

In a Facebook post the video's creator, musician Greg Gould, said he hoped the video would "inspire a few more YES votes".
TITLE: Leading 'Yes' Campaigner Christine Forster Stars In Startling Music Video

SUMMARY:
Imagine having the power to turn nightmares into sweet dreams or make sweet dreams even sweeter.
Dr Denholm Aspy has found three relatively simple techniques - one in particular - can increase people's chances of having lucid dreams.
And with awareness comes the possibility of dream control.
The final group did both of those things but added another technique known as mnemonic induction of lucid dreams or MILD for short.
The volunteers who told themselves they would remember their dreams achieved a 17 per cent success rate in having lucid dreams - the kind that can be controlled.
TEXT:
Imagine having the power to turn nightmares into sweet dreams or make sweet dreams even sweeter.

It sounds like fantasy but a study at the University of Adelaide has worked out how to help put dreamers in the driver's seat.

Dr Denholm Aspy has found three relatively simple techniques - one in particular - can increase people's chances of having lucid dreams.

Lucid dreams are the kind in which dreamers are aware they're dreaming. And with awareness comes the possibility of dream control.

His findings hold great promise for people plagued by nightmares but also for anyone who wants to have more fun in bed, so to speak.

Dr Aspy studied 169 Australian volunteers divided into three groups.

The first practised reality testing - a physical breathing check to see which reality they were in - the dream world or waking life.

The second used a technique called "wake back to bed", which involved waking after five hours for a short time and then going back to sleep for the latter hours of the sleep cycle when dreaming most commonly occurs.

The final group did both of those things but added another technique known as mnemonic induction of lucid dreams or MILD for short.

After waking at the five-hour mark, volunteers had to repeat phrases such as: "The next time I'm dreaming, I will remember that I'm dreaming."

And that's where the most exciting findings emerged.

The volunteers who told themselves they would remember their dreams achieved a 17 per cent success rate in having lucid dreams - the kind that can be controlled.

That spiked to 46 per cent in those able to go back to sleep within the first five minutes of completing the MILD technique.

Dr Aspy says people who know they're in the middle of a dream can then work on controlling what's happening in it.

"You'll remember that intention to remember your dream, you'll look around and notice that you are dreaming, and that allows you to then try to control the dream," he explains.

"Initially people may have limited control within the dream environment. But with more practice you can stay in a lucid dream for half an hour or even an hour, with a high level of control over your dream environment."

Dr Aspy says his findings are potentially life changing for people who have nightmares, a common affliction for sufferers of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

"They are notoriously difficult to treat, these nightmares," he says.

"Lucid dreaming allows people to take control of nightmares. They might be able to confront an attacker in a dream and try to gain resolution or even deliberately wake themselves up. You can basically do anything you can imagine."

Dr Aspy's study has been published in the journal Dreaming.
TITLE: Researchers Work Out How We Can Potentially Control Our Dreams

SUMMARY:
A total of 4,308,921 animals were used in Canadian laboratories in 2016, compared to 3,570,352 used in 2015.
What's more, the overall increase included a major jump in the use of dogs and cats along with high numbers of "random source" dogs and cats i.e.
Canada's high use of "random source" dogs and cats is particularly troubling.
The acquisition of dogs from shelters for research and training is increasingly viewed by the research and educational institutions as unnecessary and problematic.
Further, the Canadian Institutes of Health Research should follow the example of the U.S. NIH and eliminate funding for experiments involving "random source" animals.
TEXT:
The Canadian Council on Animal Care (CCAC) recently released the 2016 statistics on the use of animals in laboratories and the numbers are shocking. A total of 4,308,921 animals were used in Canadian laboratories in 2016, compared to 3,570,352 used in 2015.

At a time when development and use of modern non-animal methods is a burgeoning field in all areas of research, it is vexing that Canada had such a marked increase in the use of animals in experiments. What's more, the overall increase included a major jump in the use of dogs and cats along with high numbers of "random source" dogs and cats i.e. animals that may be collected from various sources including public shelters.

In 2016, 15,093 dogs were used compared to 9,573 in 2015 (58 per cent increase), and in 2016, 8,526 cats were used compared to 5,035 in 2015 (69 per cent increase). Of the 15,093 dogs used, 7,518 were recorded as "random source" and 345 from "unspecified" sources and of the 8,526 cats a full 7,659 were "random source" and an additional 273 from "unspecified" sources.

Canada's high use of "random source" dogs and cats is particularly troubling. Sourcing dogs and cats for laboratories from municipal shelters erodes the very core of a shelter's purpose â€” to care for animals in need, find new homes for homeless animals and to reunite families with lost companions. Nobody wants to imagine adoptable shelter dogs and cats suffering in laboratories, or worry that a lost family companion may end up in laboratory before they are able to find them.

Not surprisingly the practice is deeply unpopular with the public. A 2016 opinion poll carried out by YouGov on behalf of Cruelty Free International revealed that 73 per cent of Canadian adults agree that dogs found or given to animal shelters should not be sold to laboratories for experiments.

It is out of step with modern science.

"Random source" and "unspecified source" dogs and cats used in Canadian laboratories may have come from shelters in Quebec where pound seizure is not prohibited, or Ontario where pound seizure is explicitly allowed under the Animals for Research Act.

The use of random source dogs and the practice of pound seizure is not only glaringly out of step with public opinion, it is out of step with modern science. The acquisition of dogs from shelters for research and training is increasingly viewed by the research and educational institutions as unnecessary and problematic.

The University of Guelph and the Ontario Veterinary College no longer use animals acquired from animal shelters for teaching or experimentation and in the United States, the U.S. National Institutes of Health eliminated all funding for research using random source cats in 2012 and ended funding for research using random source dogs in 2015.

Ontario Premier Kathleen Wynne.

In June of 2016, Cruelty Free International called on the Canada and other governments to end the use of stray and shelter dogs in experiments. Canadian actor Eric McCormack who played Will in popular '90s sitcom Will & Grace supported our efforts stating: "Shelter dogs should be adopted into loving homes not used in cruel experiments. That's why I support the Cruelty Free International global dog campaign."

With 2016 CCAC figures now revealing such a massive increase in the use of dogs and cats, including those from "random sources," change is urgently needed in Canada.

To start, the provinces of Ontario and Quebec should pass legislation to firmly prohibit pound seizure. Canadian citizens living in those provinces can reach out to their provincial representatives,Ontario Premier Kathleen Wynne and Quebec Premier Philippe Couillard.

It would strengthen protection for four-legged family members and shelter animals in Canada.

Further, the Canadian Institutes of Health Research should follow the example of the U.S. NIH and eliminate funding for experiments involving "random source" animals. Canadians can also reach out to their senators and members of Parliament on the issue.

Prohibiting the use of random source dogs and cats in experiments and eliminating and the transfer of animals from municipal animal shelters to laboratories would reflect modern education and scientific standards, as well as public opinion and expectation. Last, but not least, it would strengthen protection for four-legged family members and shelter animals in Canada.

All figures, unless otherwise stated, are from YouGov Plc. Total sample size was 1,000 adults. Fieldwork was undertaken between 12 - 21 February 2016. The survey was carried out online. The figures have been weighted and are representative of all Canadian adults (aged 18+).

Follow HuffPost Canada Blogs on Facebook

Also on HuffPost:

TEXT:
The Triumphalism Of Corbyn's Conference t's entirely possible the Lib Dems or even UKIP could revive support under new leadership in a snap election, to assume that it would result in an almost automatic victory for Labour is a very dangerous thing indeed, if recent events are anything to go by. Aspiring journalist with a passion for news, current affairs and politics

Lines In The Political Sand So it is that time of year again. The time when political hacks descend on the British seaside to drink too much warm wine and eat soggy sandwiches together. Also known as party conference season. Acting Senior UK Political Adviser at Christian Aid. Previously worked in health policy, UK Parliament & UK civil service.

The Lib Dems' Prospects Are Bleak The Liberal Democrats are still not sure how to feel about the 2017 general election. For many, it is ambiguous whether their increased number of seats constitutes a comeback, or whether their failure to make significant electoral gains exposes the party's long-term problems. Opinion owner.

Did The Old Really 'Shaft' The Young Over Brexit? If young people really do feel 'shafted', they have largely their own age group to blame - while turnout among 18-24s was at a high level (64%), among those aged 65+ it was 25% points higher at a massive 89%. Chairman, ComRes

On The 50th Anniversary Of The Sexual Offences Act 1967, Look How Far We've Come I think today we can all celebrate a more open liberal society, with same-sex couples able to marry and huge steps forward being made for gender recognition, and I further think we Lib Dems have a bit of a right to blow our own trumpet about it. Yes, we are by no means the only party to have furthered LGBT+ rights: but we were, for example, the first party to host a gay rights fringe at party conference. Acting chair of LGBT+ Lib Dems

Given The Choice Between Theresa May And Jeremy Corbyn, Dear Lord Please Just Let It Be Vince Cable At 74, he has proved that age is no barrier to ambition and for this he should be applauded. No matter what profession we're in, we all deserve one last hurrah. You can't help feeling that this is his. Would be multi-millionaire, would be celebrated writer- sadly neither (yet)

Vince Cable Can Carve Out A New Identity For The Liberal Democrats As leader of the Liberal Democrats, Vince Cable has an opportunity to re-brand the party. He will be starting with a clean slate and can carve out distinctive new policies. During the election, I left the Conservatives and joined the Liberal Democrats, but a lot of my friends, and people I talk to, are confused about what the party stands for. former member of the British Army, Parliamentary Candidate, Author, and Entrepreneur

Students Need Urgent Reassurance On The Safety Of Student Halls I call on the Government, Universities and Local Authorities to act on this and reassure students and their families as soon as they can. The Summer should be for relaxation and recuperation, not worry and consternation. Lib Dem MP for Oxford West and Abingdon

Why I'm Urging Ed Davey To Stand As The New Leader Of The Liberal Democrats Despite growing evidence that the environment is not getting better that voice has faded in all our political discussions. We need that voice now from the Liberal Democrats and for me, as a committed environmentalist that would be enough to support Ed Davey. Liberal Democrat Member of the European Parliament for South East England

Norman Lamb Is The Leader The Lib Dems Need He has the sincerity and integrity to appeal to a wider electorate than currently consider voting for the Liberal Democrats. I believe in his ability to offer the country a vision that we've been desperate for, for many years. Liberal Democrat members have a huge opportunity in this contest to elect an honest, caring man as their leader. I hope he stands and I hope they do. Political campaigner for the Liberal Democrats and European Movement UK.

Tim Farron Supports A Disestablished Church Of England - He Was A Monument To Liberalism But it is time to dispel any rumours of Tim Farron's own illegitimacy due to his beliefs. He was a true Liberal, anyone who argues otherwise is merely carrying on the trend of illiberal intolerance. Lib Dem campaigner in Cambridge, bodyman for Susan van de Ven. Toby Ziegler wannabe.

Tim Farron And The Gay Issue So yet another twist in this extraordinary election is the resignation of Lib Dem leader Tim Farron. The blunt truth is that although he got more MPs elected, this was a very poor election for a party that went into the campaign with high hopes of kicking off a bounce-back from the disastrous wipe-out of a few years ago. CEO of the International Fur Trade Federation, former Lib Dem MP

The Lib Dems Need A Fresh Pitch To Young Voters I'm not sure enough people understand what the Liberal Democrats stand for. I want to help the party to develop a new way of thinking and a distinctive identity that allows us to make a strong pitch for the youth vote. former member of the British Army, Parliamentary Candidate, Author, and Entrepreneur

The Election Results Is Much Ado About Nothing For Labour, revel in your success, you have deserved it but be aware of why it tastes so sweet. Exceeding expectations has its own trappings. The fight is only just beginning, and it is only going to get dirtier. Lib Dem campaigner in Cambridge, bodyman for Susan van de Ven. Toby Ziegler wannabe.

DisMayed You will all remember from school science lessons that two minuses make a plus. Not in politics it seems. Westminster based political consultant. Associate Director with JBP.

TEXT:
Alexâ€™s fridge is emblazoned with the words â€œf*ck you cancerâ€. The sign is a daily reminder of how far she and her friend Jo have come in the past two years.

Itâ€™s not common for women under the age of 40 to be diagnosed with breast cancer, but the friends, in their thirties, both realised they had the disease within 14 months of each other.

Surprisingly though, their story is not one of tragedy, but one of hope.

Alex and Jo supported each other through the highs and lows of diagnosis and treatment, and now, they want to show other women thereâ€™s life after cancer.

HuffPost UK Jo (left) and Alex (right)

London-based Jo was diagnosed with breast cancer in September 2015 at 37 years old, after feeling pain in her breast that she initially dismissed as a symptom of PMT.

Shortly after her diagnosis she met Alex, an American also based in the capital. They were introduced at a tennis club and immediately hit it off, with a shared love of hitting the dance floor after practice.

Jo joked that nights out with Alex, getting â€œutterly drunkâ€ with their tennis team, helped her to maintain a sense of normality throughout treatment.

But just over a year later, their blossoming friendship was dealt another blow when Alex felt a lump in her breast and was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 31. Jo was one of the first people she told.

â€œI knew if anyone was going to understand what I felt like, it would be Jo,â€ she told HuffPost UK.

HuffPost UK Alex's fridge.

Having only recently ended treatment herself, hearing about Alexâ€™s diagnosis was difficult for Jo.

â€œItâ€™s actually quite awful to hear that someone else has got it,â€ she said.

â€œWhen youâ€™ve got it yourself, youâ€™re constantly fighting, youâ€™re having the appointments, the meetings with doctors, and you donâ€™t really have time to step back and think about the emotional side of things.

â€œBut when itâ€™s someone close to you, you actually then realise how absolutely terrifying it is. I was devastated. I think itâ€™s worse to look at someone going through it.â€

With Alexâ€™s family spread across America, Jo became an invaluable lifeline for her. She became the person Alex went to for fun and distraction, but also the person she lent on during her darkest moments.

â€œIt was so helpful to have somebody who knew what to go through and how it would feel, and to know that no matter how bad my day was, I could always call,â€ Alex said.

Jo Jo in hospital during treatment.

Despite the parallels in their diagnosis, the treatment the two friends received was quite different.

Jo had a mastectomy and implant reconstruction, without chemotherapy, and is currently taking daily tamoxifen tablets and receiving a monthly zoladex implant injection.

Meanwhile Alex had a lumpectomy followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy, which she finished in May of this year. Like Jo, she is also still taking daily tamoxifen tablets and receiving a monthly injection.

Because of the different nature of their treatments, Alex and Jo experienced different side effects, with Alex losing her hair.

â€œHair is so easily your identity as a woman,â€ Alex said.

â€œI loved my hair. It was very long and hair makes you feel sexy. As soon as you lose it you have a really hard time... I still donâ€™t feel like I look sexy. But you do get used to it.â€

Jo added that not losing her hair has also caused problems, as cancer treatment is so often associated with hair loss.

â€œWeirdly enough, people seem to think Iâ€™m either lying about my cancer because Iâ€™ve still got my hair, or people ask me why Iâ€™ve still got hair if Iâ€™ve had cancer - which is a really weird thing to ask somebody,â€ she said.

Alex Alex and Jo.

Both Alex and Jo were keen to share their stories to prove breast cancer isnâ€™t just an â€œold lady diseaseâ€.

Almost half (48%) of breast cancer cases in the UK each year are diagnosed in people over the age of 65, and as women in their thirties, Alex and Jo struggled to find support they could relate to.

â€œWhen you go online and look for help, all the pamphlets that you find have got old ladies on them, it makes you feel like youâ€™ve got an old lady disease,â€ Jo explained.

â€œI had a mastectomy with an implant reconstruction, which is something that a lot of young women struggle with because most of the information covering mastectomies uses older womenâ€™s experiences.

â€œI want to show other young people that you can still look normal after a mastectomy - Iâ€™m quite proud of my Barbie boob!â€

Thankfully, the pair were able to access the information and support they needed thanks to Breast Cancer Haven, a charity that supports women through cancer treatment.

Staff at the Haven offer practical advice on things like managing money and employment, healthy eating and combating stress through treatment.

Women can also join exercise classes or therapy groups specifically tailored to breast cancer patients.

But ultimately, itâ€™s their strong friendship that has helped Alex and Jo navigate diagnosis, treatment and aftercare, together.

â€œItâ€™s been amazing,â€ Alex told Jo. â€œI donâ€™t know what I would have done without you.â€

For more information about Breast Cancer Haven, visit the website here.

Breast Cancer Signs And Treatment
TITLE: Two Friends Took On Breast Cancer Together After Being Diagnosed 14 Months Apart

El presidente del gobierno catalan, Carles Puigdemont, realiza gestos durante su asistencia a una reuniÃ³n gubernamental en el Palacio de la Generalitat en Barcelona el 17 de octubre del 2017.

PeguÃ© un brinco. Estaba ordenando periÃ³dicos viejos en mi casa de 'entre meses' en Ortigueira (A CoruÃ±a) un pequeÃ±o pueblo que en julio de cada aÃ±o festeja las raÃ­ces ancestrales de Galicia organizando el mejor festival del mundo celta. Y leo este titular, dÃ­ganme ustedes si no es una casualidad: "El peligro es que en tiempos de crisis busquemos un salvador". Y lo dice el Papa Francisco, argentino, jesuita y franciscano.

PensÃ© que habÃ­a que tener en cuenta esas palabras, aunque no estuviera influido directamente por el EspÃ­ritu Santo o por alguna de las altas autoridades celestiales. Pero no: se referÃ­a a Donald Trump, en una entrevista del director de El PaÃ­s, Antonio CaÃ±o, y de Pablo Ordaz, en Roma, el 22 de enero de 2017.

Como todas las palabras, dichos o citas de los papas, estÃ¡ aconsejado trascender de lo concreto y personal. Ya saben, las parÃ¡bolas. AsÃ­ que mi confusiÃ³n al creer que SS se referÃ­a al problema catalÃ¡n, y sin nombrarlos seÃ±alaba al trÃ­o de la bencina, Jordi Pujol, Artur Mas y Carles Puigdemont, sin desmerecer a Oriol Junqueras, y a su RufiÃ¡n estrella, y a Anna Gabriel, jefa de los antisistema de la CUP, a los que, sin duda, una parte de la sociedad catalana cree, juntos o por separado, salvadores de una patria que nunca existiÃ³.

Tampoco se ha certificado ningÃºn milagro en CataluÃ±a, de esos que dejan chiquitos a aquellos famosos de Jesucristo. A pesar de que la multiplicaciÃ³n de los panes y los peces y la conversiÃ³n del agua en vino del bueno es 'pecata minuta' comparado con la multiplicaciÃ³n de la parroquia independentista en las encuestas y los votos en los referÃ©ndum.

Todo ha tenido truco, porque lejos de ser los dirigentes de la 'cosa' hombres de Estado, honestos, responsables y sinceros, solo son unos vulgares y patÃ©ticos magos PantopÃ­n de miserable circo antiguo.

Desde los idus de Xabier Arzalluz y del 'estadista' Pujol, ambos egÃ³latras y endiosados, siempre me parecieron como los tontos del pueblo que van delante del santo en las procesiones, sacando pecho.

O como esos beatos, sobre los que siempre me prevenÃ­a mi padre, que estaban en los primeros bancos de la iglesia, llevaban los tronos y comulgaban entre aspavientos. "Esos, Ãngel, son los mayores putaÃ±eros y sinvergÃ¼enzas, pero necesitan la imagen, que los pobres diablos confÃ­en en ellos. Solo es teatro".

El caso es que, en efecto, en tiempos de crisis, como muy bien opinaba Su Santidad, mucha gente necesita alguien que ofrezca un camino hacia el futuro. Por eso el auge de tarotistas, arÃºspices, videntes, homeÃ³patas, astrÃ³logos... Como ha sucedido con la enÃ©sima resurrecciÃ³n de la 'cuestiÃ³n catalana', que estaba zombi, aun cuando ya no exista el problema: aparecen los charlatanes revestidos de pontifical.

El presidente de la Generalitat en el exilio, rescatado para la democracia espaÃ±ola por Adolfo SuÃ¡rez, Josep Tarradellas, las vio venir. De Jordi Pujol, de sus andanzas con Banca Catalana, y de su cÃ­nico desparpajo, ya dijo que era un "farsante genial".

A partir de ahÃ­ se fue montando, con paciencia y mucho dinero escamoteado del presupuesto, un tablado destinado a llevar a cabo un vaciado del cerebro colectivo. Extraordinaria, por cierto, la intervenciÃ³n en el Congreso de los Diputados del parlamentario valenciano de Ciudadanos, Toni CantÃ³, que desgranÃ³ uno a uno los manejos para el adoctrinamiento en el 'pensamiento â€“ sic- Ãºnico' de los niÃ±os y los jÃ³venes desde las escuelas a las universidades.

Medios de comunicaciÃ³n como correas de transmisiÃ³n, educaciÃ³n teledirigida, chantaje a las empresas... Y como por arte de magia, en medio de una gran hecatombe moral, del insoportable olor a podrido, los mismos ciudadanos que estaban satisfechos con la ConstituciÃ³n y el Estatuto, los que sabÃ­an que 'en todas partes cuecen habas' y los que perseguÃ­an al grito de Â¡sinvergÃ¼enzas!, Â¡ladrones! a los malos, los corruptos de CiU, cambiaron de opiniÃ³n y pasaron a perseguir a los buenos.

Gran ejemplo de prestidigitaciÃ³n. El 'EspaÃ±a nos roba' no solo era una mentira , es una cortina de humo para ocultar la realidad del latrocinio.

Era evidente que la empresas emigrarÃ­an en el instante preciso en que los accionistas vieran tomar forma de genio malÃ©fico el riesgo en sus cuentas de resultados. JosÃ© Manuel Lara fue el primero que se atreviÃ³ a decir en octubre de 2012, alto y claro, como era Ã©l, que si CataluÃ±a elegÃ­a la independencia Ã©l se llevarÃ­a la ediciÃ³n en espaÃ±ol de 'Planeta' a Madrid o Zaragoza; no solamente la sede social.

Ahora, cuando los registradores de la propiedad y los notarios hacen horas extras para atender la demanda en el mostrador de 'salidas', ya van mÃ¡s de medio millar de empresas que huyen de la quema, hay quien trata de minimizar el caos.

El tabaco no mata, el cÃ¡ncer es bueno, porque nos acerca a Dios, y el humo de los coches es como el incienso del botafumeiro de la Catedral de Santiago de Compostela, empleado desde la Edad Media para disimular el olor a tanta humanidad peregrina.

Hasta Josep Borrell, ex presidente del Parlamento Europeo, acompaÃ±ado en el ofertorio por el Nobel Vargas Llosa en la gigantesca manifestaciÃ³n de los silenciosos a favor de la unidad de EspaÃ±a en la Ciudad Condal, les preguntÃ³ retÃ³ricamente a los empresarios que huyen en manadas que por quÃ© no lo habÃ­an dicho antes, porque igual no habrÃ­a ocurrido lo que estÃ¡ ocurriendo.

Pues por la misma razÃ³n que Pasqual Maragall, que querÃ­a ignorar que los Reyes Magos son los padres, no insistiÃ³ en su denuncia la trama del 3%: porque tenÃ­a miedo de que no saliera 'su' Estatut, y que se le rajase para siempre jamÃ¡s el 'cuco' apoyo de CiU.

Los empresarios tenÃ­an miedo, un miedo cerval, ante el lobo disfrazado de inocente cordero. El empresariado catalÃ¡n, el grande y el chico, no vive tranquilo sin el calor del poder. Y mÃ¡s si ese poder es 'amigo' y conservador, y reparte bien y equilibradamente las subvenciones, las concesiones y las consideraciones.

Pasados los instantes de atontamiento, la UniÃ³n Europea les dice con crudeza que cÃ³mo van a mediar entre una regiÃ³n sublevada y un Estado constitucional y democrÃ¡tico. SerÃ­a como mediar entre el estafador y el estafado.

Hasta que desaparece el calor, y entre las palmeras del oasis de plÃ¡stico entra un ventarrÃ³n de aire gÃ©lido que seÃ±ala la llegada de una inmediata glaciaciÃ³n. Entonces el capital huye entre las dunas. Por la misma razÃ³n que los delincuentes polÃ­ticos y econÃ³micos temen el fin del secreto bancario de Andorra con fecha de transparencia formal el 1 de enero de 2018.

Y es entonces cuando pasados los instantes de atontamiento, inducido por el cÃ³ctel de demagogia, el disfraz carnavalero de la realidad y los profetas de pacotilla, la UniÃ³n Europea, a travÃ©s del Europarlamento, de la ComisiÃ³n y el Consejo, les dice con crudeza que cÃ³mo van a mediar entre una regiÃ³n sublevada y un Estado constitucional y democrÃ¡tico. Eso serÃ­a como mediar entre el estafador y el estafado.

Y Jean Claude Junker, presidente del Ejecutivo comunitario, les aclara algo tan elemental, que ha acallado a los recalcitrantes esnobistas, a fuer de pintorescos, papanatas europeos que cuando ven las fotos de los antidisturbios porra en mano en Barcelona se olvidan de las de los altercados G-20 en todas las capitales mundiales y ven a la EspaÃ±a de la leyenda negra o a la del rifle y la pandereta, la de bandoleros y toreros ensangrentados. "No quiero que en quince aÃ±os haya noventa estados en Europa. SerÃ­a imposible".

Pero quien abriÃ³ la cacerÃ­a a carcajada limpia fue la revista satÃ­rica francesa Charlie Hebdo, que titulÃ³ un viÃ±eta: "Los catalanes, mÃ¡s tontos que los corsos". El ministro de Justicia de Alemania, Heiko Maas, susurrÃ³ a los periodistas cuando entraba a una 'cumbre' en Luxemburgo: "Ahora mismo he declarado la independencia del Sarre", uno de los mÃ¡s pequeÃ±os estados federados, donde estudiÃ³.

Una influente publicaciÃ³n norteamericana de asuntos internacionales, Foreign Policy, resume un artÃ­culo con el ejemplo de que "CataluÃ±a fuera de EspaÃ±a es como Illinois fuera de Estados Unidos". Y como 'a perro flaco todo son pulgas', Reporteros Sin Fronteras (RSF) no se anda con rodeos: las acusaciones de la Generalitat a los medios de comunicaciÃ³n independientes "evocan las campaÃ±as de Trump y los movimientos de extrema derecha".

Es otra seÃ±al de que se ha perdido el 'respeto' al nacionalismo separatista, ya esfumado el artificial 'glamour' de vÃ­ctima de diseÃ±o, al que solo apoya 'Podemos' que, en su lÃ­nea, tiene un cada dÃ­a mÃ¡s definido objetivo antisistema y revolucionario, que ya ha abierto serias grietas en su seno.

TambiÃ©n es suicida para el separatismo y el populismo pulgoso ignorar una seÃ±al clara de que estÃ¡ cambiando la marea. Cuando mÃ¡s de un millÃ³n de catalanes salen a la calle con banderas espaÃ±olas, y senyeras tradicionales, defendiendo la unidad de EspaÃ±a y la ConstituciÃ³n del 78, cuando casi cien mil repiten unos dÃ­as despuÃ©s, el 12 de Octubre, Fiesta Nacional, es que la masa silenciosa ha decidido hacerle caso a Bertolt Brecht: "Cuando la verdad sea demasiado dÃ©bil para defenderse, tendrÃ¡ que pasar al ataque".

Y si esto sucede, lo primero que debe hacer un polÃ­tico es huir del... ridÃ­culo. El ridÃ­culo mata.

Como decÃ­a Mark Twain, con el mismo enfado con el que discrepaba del "con la patria, con razÃ³n o sin ella", "se puede andar con una pistola cargada, se puede andar con una pistola descargada, pero no se puede andar con una pistola que no se sabe si estÃ¡ cargada o descargada".

Este texto fue publicado originalmente en El HuffPost.

*Este contenido representa la opiniÃ³n del autor y no necesariamente la de HuffPost MÃ©xico.
TITLE: CataluÃ±a: los tontos del pueblo se creyeron muy astutos

SUMMARY:
Supporter de l'Olympique de Marseille (OM), j'ai dÃ©cidÃ© de ne pas regarder le match, dimanche, face au Paris Saint-Germain (PSG).
Devenu adulte, je n'ai cessÃ© de supporter l'OM, contre vents et marÃ©es, malgrÃ© des rÃ©sultats en dents de scie.
Elle ne comporte aucun suspense quant Ã  son issue, ce qui, Ã  terme, provoquera le dÃ©sintÃ©rÃªt des supporters, et, par consÃ©quent, des diffuseurs officiels et des sponsors en quÃªte de nouveaux marchÃ©s.
Et il n'y a aucune raison pour qu'il en soit autrement dimanche soir.

TEXT:
Supporter de l'Olympique de Marseille (OM), j'ai dÃ©cidÃ© de ne pas regarder le match, dimanche, face au Paris Saint-Germain (PSG). C'est une dÃ©cision mÃ»rement rÃ©flÃ©chie, consÃ©quence logique d'un processus qui conduit aujourd'hui le PSG Ã  rÃ©gner sans partage sur la Ligue 1, et, ainsi, Ã  attÃ©nuer l'intÃ©rÃªt portÃ© Ã  ce championnat par les supporters des clubs adverses.

Car supporter un club de football est un acte passionnel. C'est aussi un acte fondateur, car il est frÃ©quemment rÃ©alisÃ© lors de l'enfance ou de l'adolescence, pour des raisons gÃ©nÃ©ralement liÃ©es Ã  l'environnement familial, amical ou gÃ©ographique. C'est enfin un acte d'une portÃ©e Ã©motionnelle considÃ©rable, qui conduit le jeune supporter, bien souvent, Ã  se nourrir de sentiments contradictoires, et Ã  accepter l'Ã©chec et les dÃ©faites bien avant d'avoir goÃ»tÃ© aux joies â€“ parfois sans saveur â€“ du succÃ¨s.

La passion du supporter, irrationnelle et trop souvent dÃ©criÃ©e, est fondÃ©e sur la promesse d'un avenir radieux, de lendemains qui chantent, d'un futur glorieux comprenant la consÃ©cration absolue, celle de devenir champion de France.

Cette promesse, essentiellement fictive, je la ressentais avec une grande intensitÃ© au moment du marchÃ© des transferts, car l'acquisition de chaque nouveau joueur gÃ©nÃ©rait, pendant quelques jours, un grand nombre d'espoirs. Cette promesse, je la retrouvais chaque Ã©tÃ©, enfant, lorsque j'espÃ©rais, quelles que soient les qualitÃ©s de ses joueurs, que mon club de cÅ“ur allait pouvoir remporter le championnat de France. Cette promesse, c'est encore celle qui me guidait, lorsque j'attendais, avec impatience, angoisse et excitation, le prochain match opposant l'OM au PSG.

Devenu adulte, je n'ai cessÃ© de supporter l'OM, contre vents et marÃ©es, malgrÃ© des rÃ©sultats en dents de scie.

Je n'ai cessÃ© de supporter l'OM, car, comme l'a si bien Ã©crit Gigi Riva, rÃ©dacteur en chef de l'hebdomadaire L'Espresso en Italie, dans Le Dernier Penalty (Editions du Seuil, 2016): "Au club, on pardonne les fautes, les revers, les erreurs parce qu'en Ã©change de cette passion impÃ©rissable on obtient l'impossible: l'illusion de rester un enfant".

HÃ©las, il faut le dire sans dÃ©tour: depuis que le Qatar a procÃ©dÃ© au rachat du Paris Saint-Germain, en 2011, cette passion s'est amenuisÃ©e. Aujourd'hui, aprÃ¨s les recrutements des joueurs fantastiques que sont Neymar et MbappÃ©, qui viennent s'ajouter aux prÃ©cÃ©dentes acquisitions, elle a fini par disparaÃ®tre.

Que l'on s'entende bien, il ne s'agit pas ici de faire preuve d'une jalousie dÃ©placÃ©e envers le club de la capitale ; ni mÃªme d'analyser l'activitÃ© du PSG sur le marchÃ© des transferts Ã  l'aune de la crise diplomatique qui oppose actuellement le Qatar aux monarchies du Golfe, Arabie Saoudite en tÃªte. Il s'agit simplement de regretter une situation marquÃ©e par un dÃ©sÃ©quilibre trop important, sans doute Ã©phÃ©mÃ¨re, qui conduit Ã  anÃ©antir tout espoir de victoire pour le supporter d'une Ã©quipe tierce.

La rÃ©alitÃ©, c'est que cette compÃ©tition â€“ la Ligue 1 â€“ est biaisÃ©e dÃ¨s l'origine. Elle ne comporte aucun suspense quant Ã  son issue, ce qui, Ã  terme, provoquera le dÃ©sintÃ©rÃªt des supporters, et, par consÃ©quent, des diffuseurs officiels et des sponsors en quÃªte de nouveaux marchÃ©s. Ceux-lÃ  mÃªme qui, aujourd'hui, notamment au sein des instances dirigeantes de la Ligue, semblent s'Ã©merveiller du pouvoir d'attractivitÃ© de Neymar, vont se rÃ©veiller avec la gueule de bois et une Ã©quation insoluble: comment parvenir Ã  vendre les droits d'un championnat dont le scÃ©nario est connu Ã  l'avance?

Certains invoqueront la glorieuse incertitude du sport. Qu'on en juge plutÃ´t par les faits: depuis la derniÃ¨re victoire de l'OM face au PSG, en novembre 2011, quatorze confrontations se sont dÃ©roulÃ©es. L'OM, malgrÃ© des faits de jeu parfois favorables, ne l'a jamais emportÃ©. Et il n'y a aucune raison pour qu'il en soit autrement dimanche soir. A plus long terme, le risque de jouer ce match dans un stade vidÃ© de ses supporters est une hypothÃ¨se rÃ©aliste, et sans doute souhaitable. Car il est temps de signifier aux acteurs du monde du football une vÃ©ritÃ© que certains refusent de voir: un championnat dÃ©sÃ©quilibrÃ©, c'est l'assurance de provoquer le dÃ©sintÃ©rÃªt des supporters des autres clubs, et, Ã  terme, de voir l'activitÃ© Ã©conomique liÃ©e au championnat se ralentir.

Aujourd'hui, il n'y a plus que le passÃ©, l'histoire et la nostalgie qui alimentent la fiertÃ© d'un supporter de l'OM. Avec le PSG, le Qatar n'a pas seulement rachetÃ© un club de football, il nous a arrachÃ©s de notre enfance, il a brisÃ© ce qui fait la raison d'Ãªtre d'un supporter: la promesse de jours meilleurs.

Ã€ voir Ã©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Pourquoi je ne regarderai pas OM-PSG dimanche, mÃªme si je suis supporter de Marseille

Die Situation in Katalonien spitzt sich weiter zu. Weil die Regionalregierung in Barcelona auf einer Abspaltung beharrt, will die Zentralregierung in Madrid nun Artikel 155 der Verfassung in Kraft setzen. Es wÃ¤re das erste Mal seit Inkrafttreten der Verfassung im Jahr 1978.

Artikel zur Einhaltung der spanischen Verfassung

Der Artikel trÃ¤gt aufgrund SchÃ¤rfe auch den Beinamen der â€œnuklearen Optionâ€. Er erlaubt es der Regierung, gegen autonome Regionen â€œMaÃŸnahmenâ€ einzuleiten, um die Einhaltung der Verfassung zu gewÃ¤hrleisten.

Premierminister Mariano Rajoy will sich am Samstag festlegen, was genau er unternimmt.

Die mÃ¶glichen Schritte

â–º Einsatz des MilitÃ¤rs: Wie Peter A. Kraus von der UniversitÃ¤t Augsburg "Focus Online" sagte, kÃ¶nnte Madrid das MilitÃ¤r einsetzen, wie schon wÃ¤hrend des Referendums am 1. Oktober. Diese MÃ¶glichkeit existiert dank Artikel acht und kÃ¶nnte nun zusammen mit Artikel 155 zum Einsatz kommen. Der Katalonien-Experte hÃ¤lt diese Option allerdings fÃ¼r eher unwahrscheinlich.



â–º Festnahmen: FÃ¼r etwas wahrscheinlicher hÃ¤lt Kraus weitere Festnahmen katalonischer Politiker. Auch der Chef der Regionalregierung, Carles Puigdemont, kÃ¶nnte verhaftet werden.



â–º Politische Kontrolle: Rajoy kÃ¶nnte alle Ministerien der Region der Kontrolle Madrids unterstellen und Neuwahlen in Katalonien veranlassen. Madrid hat bereits die finanzielle Autonomie Kataloniens aufgehoben. Kraus hÃ¤lt diese Schritte also fÃ¼r denkbar.

TEXT:
Parents should look out for an additional safety label on kidsâ€™ Halloween costumes, which shows they have undergone further flammability testing.

The British Retail Consortium (BRC) revealed today [Wednesday 18 October] that they have introduced two voluntary â€˜Codes of Practiceâ€™ which exceed the current testing standard.

The consortium felt the need for a more robust flammability test than was currently required under European standards, and worked with UK laboratories to develop one.

The BRC told HuffPost UK the three largest childrenâ€™s costumes manufacturers in the UK - Christyâ€™s by Design, Rubies UK and Smiffyâ€™s - have signed up to put their fancy dress outfits through these additional tests.

The warning label shown below indicates a costume has undergone the additional safety testing for flammability.

BRC

BRC

The tests have a more stringent requirement of a maximum burn rate of 10mm/minute. This is an improvement of 300% compared to the current European standard â€˜EN71-2â€™ of fire safety testing, which requires a maximum burn rate of 30mm/minute for childrenâ€™s fancy dress costumes - which are classed as â€œtoysâ€ rather than â€œclothingâ€.

David Bolton, head of product safety at the BRC explained that, despite the additional flammability testing, parents should still be cautious when their children are near flames.

â€œAll parents know that children should not be allowed to play near fire and that clothing of any sort will burn if exposed long enough to flame or extreme heat,â€ he told HuffPost UK.

The BRC also explained that this does not mean costumes without this label are not safe for children to wear.

â€œThose [other costumes] have still been tested under the European standard â€˜EN71-2â€™, certified to be safe,â€ a spokesperson said.

â€œOur â€˜Code of Practiceâ€™ is more robust than this legal standard and therefore costumes tested under it are safer.

â€œThatâ€™s also not to say that costumes that havenâ€™t been tested to our â€˜Code of Practiceâ€™ wouldnâ€™t meet the standard if they were.â€

Speaking about the new â€˜Code of Practiceâ€™, Bolton added: â€œWe are still recommending that the UK Government and EU authorities revisit the legislation to ensure all products on the market are effectively regulated to reflect the hazards presented by todayâ€™s style of costumes, including the fabrics and finishes used.â€

Ken Dunn, consultant burns and plastic surgeon and medical trustee at the Childrenâ€™s Burns Trust said:

â€œThe number of incidents of burns involving clothing, for example a childâ€™s fancy-dress costume, is thankfully relatively low - but when it does happen it is catastrophic.
TITLE: Halloween Costumes: The Fire Safety Label Parents Should Look Out For When Buying Outfits For Kids

SUMMARY:
This most recent breaking of the silence around this widespread issue has reinforced how the attitudes making sexual abuse acceptable to perpetrators are attitudes that pervade the way men behave.
Of course the victims are people we know - we all know women.
But the fact is, sexual assault IS ubiquitous in the gay scene.
So normal has it been in my experience to be treated as a sexual object by other gay men, I rarely questioned it.
Don't you think the time is long overdue for all men consider the roles we play in keeping sexual abuse alive?
TEXT:
Over the weekend I watched with growing horror as the "#MeToo" campaign revealed the number of people who have been subject to sexual harassment and assault at the hands of men. With a cascade of celebrities disclosing their stories about the abhorrent Harvey Weinstein, it's easy to comprehend at least that victims of such abuse exist. It is all the more unsettling when you realise that victims are much closer to home. As my social media feeds filled up with more and more brave admissions from friends, family members and colleagues of "me too", it soon became apparent that the victims of sexual harassment and assault exist much closer to home.

This most recent breaking of the silence around this widespread issue has reinforced how the attitudes making sexual abuse acceptable to perpetrators are attitudes that pervade the way men behave. So normalised has harassment and assault become that it often goes unspoken of. As a result, many people (including myself) have woken up to the fact that victims of sexual violence are people we actually know saying, "I just didn't know". Considering that the group of people on the receiving end of harassment and abuse includes pretty much all women, there is no excuse for this kind of ignorance. Of course the victims are people we know - we all know women.

Maybe part of my own unwillingness to realise the extent of this issue has been precisely because it is so close to home. Foolishly - but humanly - it can feel better to remain in ignorance of those things which hurt us, and it took me a number of years to awaken to the fact that this is something I've been personally subject to as well. As a gay man, I've been quick to recognise the occasions where I've been verbally or physically assaulted by other men on the basis of my sexuality. That's homophobic abuse. It took me much longer to realise that sexual comments, groping by strangers in nightclubs, and threats or enactments of sexual force were actually sexual assault, and not just a normal part of socialising in certain environments.

But the fact is, sexual assault IS ubiquitous in the gay scene. So normal has it been in my experience to be treated as a sexual object by other gay men, I rarely questioned it. I've even thought I should've felt flattered by it, that is it was desirable - laughing it off despite the sick feeling in my stomach, or the sense of disgust that comes with your bodily integrity being violated.

Whilst the silence of the abused protects the abuser, it shouldn't be the responsibility of the victim to have to stand up and say "me too". It shouldn't be for women to have to tell their stories in order to right the wrongs of the behaviour of men. This double injustice is simply not OK - it is those who perpetrate abuse who are responsible for stopping it from happening. The discourse that says we must empower women to refuse the unwanted sexual advances of men is a disturbing oversight of the real priority - stopping the need to so frequently defend against male behaviour in the first place.

Why is it that the onus is on the victim to say "this is not OK"? Of course we are all responsible for our own behaviour and how we respond to challenging situations, and should someone be unfortunate enough to be on the receiving end of harassment and abuse then it is better that they have the skills to prevent the worst from happening. But in the causal chain of events, prevention is better than cure, and men have to step up and take responsibility.

Ensuring that sexually harassing and abusive behaviour doesn't happen in the first place also involves tackling perspectives that see it as OK for men to treat others as sexual objects. In this sense, responsibility for sexual violence also lies with those who are complicit with the attitudes that cause it. For example, what about the men who knowingly keep silence for peers who view and treat women as sexual objects for their own use? In the case of Weinstein, so much effort has been made to criticise powerful women in show-business for not speaking out about the way they had been treated, yet the powerful men who surrounded him are left unexamined.

What about the pervading culture in the gay community that makes the assumption that simply entering a gay bar is to make an open invitation for sexual advances from anyone and everyone? All of us men have a responsibility to speak out - not only if we (or someone we care about) has experienced sexual assault, but when we have played our part in propping up the attitudes that cause this end product.

For things to really change, we need to see a hashtag that admits "me too" not to being a victim of sexual abuse, but to complicity to sexual objectification, harassment and assault. "Me too" to being part of the slippery slope towards sexual violence that begins with the sexualisation of children or making remarks about someone's body that were never asked for. How about "me too - I am guilty of touching any part of another person's body without permission"? "Me too, I remained silent about male colleagues harassing women at work"?

Don't you think the time is long overdue for all men consider the roles we play in keeping sexual abuse alive?

Me too.
TITLE: So Long As Men Remain Complicit, Women (And Gay Men Like Me) Will Keep Saying "Me Too"

ADVERTISEMENTSupreme Court's ban on the sale of firecrackers made Diwali a comparatively quiet affair in the Delhi NCR this year.
However, the order did little to help keep the pollution levels in control.
Some areas in the city recorded a steep hike in pollution levels with more than 24 times the average level.

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

Supreme Court's ban on the sale of firecrackers made Diwali a comparatively quiet affair in the Delhi NCR this year.

However, the order did little to help keep the pollution levels in control. According to NDTV, data from the Central Pollution Control Board reflected Delhi's Air Quality Index (AQI) value at 319, putting it in the "very poor" category. Some areas in the city recorded a steep hike in pollution levels with more than 24 times the average level.

As per the indicators of pollution monitoring systems, on Friday morning Delhi's RK Puram monitoring station recorded PM2.5 and PM10 at 878, which is quite hazardous.

But in comparison to last year, pollution levels this year seems much lower. In 2016, the day after Diwali, the Air Quality Index was recorded at 431, as compared to 319 this year.

In 2016, particulate matter (PM)10 and PM2.5 was recorded at over eight times the safe limit. This year, however, PM10 and PM2.5 levels were over two and half times the satisfactory limit.

Several news agencies and people from the city have been tweeting images of smog and pollution from Friday morning.

Here is a post showing India Gate a day after Diwali from 2016 and 2017.

Delhi: Visuals of #Smog from NH 24 near Pandav Nagar pic.twitter.com/N1beGXWzJU â€” ANI (@ANI) October 20, 2017

Its not Venusian surface its Delhi with runaway green house gas. Special ğŸ™ to parties who made this even worse. #delhipollution pic.twitter.com/sC7unqxmnR â€” Dhrithi Manohar (@DhrithiManohar) October 20, 2017

Next day of Diwali

Time 8:30AM

Location: Chirag delhi, CR Park pic.twitter.com/pDSNuQj0ZS â€” kanishka proothi (@imkproothi) October 20, 2017

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: Air Quality In Delhi Was Slightly Better This Diwali, But Is That Enough?

SUMMARY:
Tony Abbott will travel to the U.S. to deliver a speech to a controversial anti-LGBTQ group.
CANBERRA -- Former Prime Minister and current backbencher Tony Abbott will once again address a controversial American Christian organisation which has been deemed a "hate group" and supports the criminalisation of homosexuality.
The ADF has been a vocal opponent of advancing rights for LGBTQ people, including staunch opposition to same-sex marriage.
It will be the second time Abbott has addressed the Alliance Defending Freedom, after first speaking to the group in January 2016.
On that occasion, he spoke against marriage equality, saying "society should "respect and appreciate values and institutions that have stood the test of time and pass them on, undamaged".
TEXT:
Tony Abbott will travel to the U.S. to deliver a speech to a controversial anti-LGBTQ group.

CANBERRA -- Former Prime Minister and current backbencher Tony Abbott will once again address a controversial American Christian organisation which has been deemed a "hate group" and supports the criminalisation of homosexuality.

The Australian Financial Review revealed on Thursday that Abbott, the member for Warringah, will travel to the United States later this month to deliver a speech to the Alliance Defending Freedom. The ADF has been a vocal opponent of advancing rights for LGBTQ people, including staunch opposition to same-sex marriage. The ADF has also advocated for homosexuality to be relisted as a criminal offence.

Breaking: Abbott to take anti-gay marriage campaign to the US https://t.co/oHZsrD2IIm â€” Phillip Coorey (@PhillipCoorey) October 19, 2017

The ADF has been classified as both a "hate group" and "extremist" by the Southern Poverty Law Center. On its website, the SPLC says the Alliance:

has supported the recriminalization of homosexuality in the U.S. and criminalization abroad; has defended state-sanctioned sterilization of trans people abroad; has linked homosexuality to pedophilia and claims that a "homosexual agenda" will destroy Christianity and society.

Quotes from ADF members posted on the SPLC's website claim that homosexuality is a "dangerous temptation", that it is linked to "deviant sexual practices", and is "intrinsically linked" to paedophilia. The SPLC also details numerous occasions where the ADF has supported various campaigns worldwide to criminalise homosexuality and gay sex.

Abbott's speech will come just days before the result of Australia's postal survey on marriage equality is announced, and the AFR reports that Abbott is expected to use his speech to the Alliance at the end of this month to step up the case for robust laws protecting religious freedoms if same-sex marriage is legislated.

The religious freedoms argument is especially relevant to the ADF and Australia's marriage equality push. Marriage equality opponents have raised hypotheticals around devout religious people being forced to supply food or supply flowers for same-sex weddings against their religious beliefs, while the ADF is currently representing a Colorado baker who refused to make cakes for gay weddings.

Bakers should be allowed to have their cake â€” and their freedom https://t.co/nSFmgTRERC @TheHillOpinion pic.twitter.com/ltKrcDok1K â€” AllianceDefends (@AllianceDefends) October 13, 2017

A spokesperson for Abbott told the AFR that "Mr Abbott is honoured to have been invited by the ADF to reiterate his well-known position that advocates for same sex marriage must demonstrate how â€“ in their brave new world â€“ freedom of speech, freedom of religion and parental choice will be protected."

It will be the second time Abbott has addressed the Alliance Defending Freedom, after first speaking to the group in January 2016. On that occasion, he spoke against marriage equality, saying "society should "respect and appreciate values and institutions that have stood the test of time and pass them on, undamaged".

Soon after the Financial Review published its story, Abbott himself tweeted a reply, linking his speech in to the "five million Australians yet to vote" in the postal survey. It is unclear how many of those five million will be in attendance at Abbott's speech in America.
TITLE: Tony Abbott To Visit Anti-LGBTQ 'Hate Group' Again

Et si elle exclut tout ethnicisme et revendique les valeurs universalistes de la France, elle rompt avec la tradition internationaliste de l'extrÃªme gauche.

TEXT:
UNION EUROPEENNE - L'argument a surpris. Ce jeudi matin dans l'hÃ©micycle, Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon a profitÃ© des dÃ©bats sur le projet de loi de finances 2018 pour livrer un rÃ©quisitoire lapidaire contre une "dÃ©pense somptuaire": la contribution de la France au budget de l'Union europÃ©enne.

"La France rÃ¨gle 20 milliards 200 millions d'euros au budget de l'Europe. Il lui en revient 14 milliards ensuite dans une logique que tout le monde connait. Il manque donc 6 milliards. Nous faisons donc cadeau de 6 milliards tous les ans Ã  l'UE pour Ã©quiper d'autres pays autour de nous. Je n'en suis pas d'accord", a tranchÃ© le chef de file de la France Insoumise.

RÃ©clamant le remboursement de ce solde qui permettrait, selon lui, Ã  la France de sortir de la liste des pays en dÃ©ficit excessif, le dÃ©putÃ© des Bouches-du-RhÃ´ne a conclu son propos en mettant en garde l'AssemblÃ©e contre ce "fantÃ´me fiscal qui nous ponctionne et nous cloue dans une situation dont nous ne voulons plus".

UE : @JLMelenchon veut "rÃ©cupÃ©rer" les 6 mds dâ‚¬ de diffÃ©rence entre la somme versÃ©e par la France et ce qui lui "revient". #DirectAN pic.twitter.com/YuRMWMSvZy â€” LCP (@LCP) 19 octobre 2017

AprÃ¨s sa bataille pour obtenir le retrait du drapeau europÃ©en de l'AssemblÃ©e nationale, c'est la premiÃ¨re fois que le chef de file de la France insoumise reprend publiquement Ã  son compte l'argument prÃ©fÃ©rÃ© des souverainistes selon lequel l'Union europÃ©enne coÃ»terait plus cher Ã  la France qu'elle ne lui rapporte. Contestable tant sur le plan arithmÃ©tique que sur le plan politique, la punchline du "solde nÃ©gatif" n'avait Ã©tÃ© brandie pendant la campagne prÃ©sidentielle que par les adversaires les plus rÃ©solus de la construction europÃ©enne et qui faisaient voeu de la dÃ©manteler: Marine Le Pen, Nicolas Dupont-Aignan et FranÃ§ois Asselineau.

Ce positionnement souverainiste de plus en plus visible chez Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon intervient dans un tout autre contexte: la France est dirigÃ©e par le prÃ©sident le plus ouvertement europhile de son histoire. AprÃ¨s Nicolas Dupont-Aignan, Marine Le Pen, qui fut longtemps la candidate du "Frexit" la plus en vue, opÃ¨re un revirement spectaculaire en ne considÃ©rant plus la sortie des traitÃ©s europÃ©ens comme une prioritÃ© politique.

Pour une "Europe des nations bien intÃ©grÃ©e"

Cette concomitance politique interroge: faut-il y voir l'opportunisme d'un Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon cherchant Ã  s'opposer au prÃ©sident de la RÃ©publique sur la scÃ¨ne europÃ©enne tout en courtisant l'Ã©lectorat europhobe abandonnÃ© par la prÃ©sidente du Front national? SÃ©duisante, l'hypothÃ¨se ne rÃ©siste guÃ¨re Ã  la chronologie.

VoilÃ  des annÃ©es que celui qui fut dÃ©putÃ© europÃ©en pendant huit ans ne cesse de muscler son discours Ã  l'encontre de Bruxelles, symbole Ã  ses yeux d'une oligarchie ultra-libÃ©rale s'opposant aux souverainetÃ©s nationales. L'annÃ©e 2014 est charniÃ¨re, annÃ©e oÃ¹ Marine Le Pen ne jurait que par la sortie de l'Europe et oÃ¹ Emmanuel Macron n'existait pas politiquement.

C'est Ã  cette pÃ©riode que Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon acte Ã  la fois l'Ã©chec de la stratÃ©gie de conquÃªte du pouvoir du Front de Gauche et l'impossibilitÃ© d'Ã©chapper aux traitÃ©s libÃ©raux europÃ©ens. Le traumatisme de la forfaiture grecque de Syriza et d'Alexis Tsipras, contraint de ravaler son rÃ©fÃ©rendum et de soumettre son pays aux plans d'austÃ©ritÃ© de ses crÃ©diteurs, est passÃ© par lÃ .

"On oublie que j'ai passÃ© presque dix ans Ã  mener un combat fÃ©dÃ©raliste au niveau europÃ©en avec la gauche du SPD pour aboutir Ã  une assemblÃ©e constituante. Au bout d'un moment, j'ai laissÃ© tomber. Leur Europe, celle des traitÃ©s libÃ©raux, a gagnÃ©. Le pli est dÃ©sormais irrÃ©versible", se remÃ©morait-il cette semaine dans un entretien Ã©clairant accordÃ© Ã  l'hebdomadaire "Le 1".

Sa philosophie souverainiste y est clairement assumÃ©e. Et si elle exclut tout ethnicisme et revendique les valeurs universalistes de la France, elle rompt avec la tradition internationaliste de l'extrÃªme gauche. "On ne peut pas laisser faire l'Europe en dÃ©faisant la France. Mais en s'appuyant sur l'identitÃ© rÃ©publicaine de la France, on peut faire une Europe des nations bien intÃ©grÃ©e", plaide Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon.

Souverainisme altermondialiste

De fÃ©dÃ©raliste europÃ©en, MÃ©lenchon a basculÃ© dans un souverainisme altermondialiste, inspirÃ© des nationalismes de gauche latino-amÃ©ricains. Chez l'ancien candidat Ã  la prÃ©sidentielle, cette conversion marque un changement de paradigme. En 2014 donc, "MÃ©luche" publie "L'Ere du peuple", oeuvre dont il estime aujourd'hui qu'elle est le "point de dÃ©part" de sa rÃ©volution citoyenne. Assumant "l'Ã©puisement de la vieille gauche", il y rompt avec la matrice de classe (gauche contre droite, dominÃ©s contre dominants) pour y substituer la confrontation entre le "peuple", seul dÃ©tenteur lÃ©gitime de la souverainetÃ©, et "l'oligarchie" (europÃ©enne notamment mais pas seulement) qui la lui confisque.

En vue de la prÃ©sidentielle de 2017, MÃ©lenchon prÃ©pare la rupture avec les traitÃ©s europÃ©ens. Faute d'obtenir une rÃ©vision complÃ¨te des traitÃ©s (plan A), le candidat s'engage Ã  en sortir unilatÃ©ralement pour rebÃ¢tir un nouveau projet europÃ©en. Refus de verser la contribution franÃ§aise au budget de l'UE, rÃ©quisition de la Banque de France, contrÃ´le des capitaux... C'est le fameux "plan B". "Entre la souverainetÃ© du peuple et l'euro, je choisis la souverainetÃ© du peuple", assume-t-il.

Depuis, le dÃ©putÃ© des Bouches-du-RhÃ´ne n'a pas dÃ©viÃ© de cette ligne qui justifie son opposition frontale au projet europÃ©en rÃªvÃ© par Emmanuel Macron. Lors de son discours de la Sorbonne, le prÃ©sident n'a pas fait mystÃ¨re de sa volontÃ© de bÃ¢tir une "souverainetÃ© europÃ©enne", esquissant les contours d'un fÃ©dÃ©ralisme europÃ©en qui ne dit pas son nom. Ce Ã  quoi Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon se dit "en dÃ©saccord complet", jugeant qu'il n'y a de souverainetÃ© que "dans le peuple".

"Le peuple europÃ©en, qu'est-ce que c'est? Je ne me sens rien de commun avec les pays baltes. C'est le bout du monde, mÃªme les Romains ne sont pas allÃ©s lÃ  bas!" s'enflamme-t-il. En jurant qu'il s'opposera Ã  tout abandon de "souverainetÃ© populaire sous prÃ©texte de cantiques europÃ©istes creux et dangereux".

TITLE: Contre Macron et Le Pen, MÃ©lenchon s'impose comme le nouveau champion du souverainisme
