FÃ¼r einen CDU-Politiker, der dem konservativen FlÃ¼gel zugerechnet wird, klang das fast schon zu optimistisch.

Doch Spahn machte auch deutlich, was er als Ergebnis der Verhandlungen erwarte. Es waren die alten Spahn-Themen der integrationsunwilligen und frauenverachtenden Moslems:

"Die Frage, wie wir Menschen integrieren, die Kulturen entstammen, in denen der Mann mehr zÃ¤hlt als die Frau, und die nicht gerade zimperlich mit Minderheiten, etwa Schwulen und Juden, umgehen, sollte GrÃ¼ne und Liberale ebenso umtreiben wie uns."

Die Rufe mehren sich, dass nun nach der Bundestagswahl auch die Nachfolge-Debatte fÃ¼r die angeschlagene Kanzlerin beginnen mÃ¼sse. Nicht wenige sehen in Spahn einen HoffnungstrÃ¤ger der Union.

In den KoalitionsgesprÃ¤chen wird der CDU-GeneralsekretÃ¤r auch den konservativen FlÃ¼gel der Partei vertreten - und weiter an seiner Rolle als Merkel-Erbe arbeiten.

SUMMARY:
"No longer can we consider ourselves the 'land of opportunity' where people can easily cross class barriers."
No longer can we consider ourselves the 'land of opportunity' where people can easily cross class barriers.
The most worrying aspect was that the correlation between adult and child welfare dependency was strongest when the parents were on disability, mental health payments and single parent benefits.
A more pertinent inquiry for governments to ask is: 'what are the themes here, and how can we assist families out of avoiding intergenerational welfare dependency?'.
These models can be game changers in communities around Australia yet seem to be fringe dwellers of family welfare in this country.
TEXT:
"No longer can we consider ourselves the 'land of opportunity' where people can easily cross class barriers."

At the rate we are going, Australia is headed for an intergenerational poverty and welfare crisis that threatens the foundations of our so-called egalitarian society.

Research by the universities of Melbourne and Sydney, showing that children of parents on Centrelink benefits are almost twice as likely to be on benefits themselves by their early twenties, is a startling finding that should awaken our political and community leaders.

No longer can we consider ourselves the 'land of opportunity' where people can easily cross class barriers. For the first time, we now have evidence to suggest that there is a fundamental and dangerous shift in our society that sees people born in poverty, staying there.

The findings -- together with the spiralling property asset inflation that is shutting many young people out of the market -- dismantle Australia's long and proudly held beliefs that everyone can win in Australia no matter where you come from.

Nor, can it be said, that parents can realistically work towards ensuring that their children can enjoy a better lifestyle than their own.

Trading one's way out of disadvantage is becoming harder and harder.

The Melbourne and Sydney universities' study traced Centrelink data from 1987. The most worrying aspect was that the correlation between adult and child welfare dependency was strongest when the parents were on disability, mental health payments and single parent benefits. This runs counter to the intuitive belief that the correlation would be strongest between adult and child unemployment benefits due to lack of investment in education.

Unless we are moved by these findings, the dissolving of these long-held cultural beliefs as a society will see likely further breakdown in social cohesion, leading to resentment, protest, political and societal unrest.

Whilst one swallow does not make a spring, this study joins a growing band of evidence that shows family life, at the poorer end of the continuum, is struggling in many ways and that trading one's way out of disadvantage is becoming harder and harder. For instance, it is now estimated by ACOSS that more than 730,000 children are living in poverty.

However, the Government seems to have a preoccupation with drug testing and income cards when it comes to welfare policy. Whilst there may be merit for such preoccupation, these issues won't turn either the intergenerational poverty cycle some families now seem to be in, nor any Treasury expectations on expenditure forecasts that they are worried by.

A more pertinent inquiry for governments to ask is: 'what are the themes here, and how can we assist families out of avoiding intergenerational welfare dependency?'.

One place to look is our expenditure on the family unit in support and assistance. Current government expenditure suggest that Australian governments are spending on average as little as 17 percent of child and family welfare budgets on prevention whilst the remaining dominant amount is spent on statutory child protection investigation, family support assistance and out-of-home care.

For us to break intergenerational disadvantage we have to break our traditional jaded outlook on families caught up in welfare, and see the evidence that says investing in them will reap rewards we all want.

Of course, solutions will not be easy or quick, but for the first time in this country we are seeing early signs that state governments, such as those in Victoria and New South Wales, are interested in funding evidence-informed interventions that have track records of turning disadvantaged families around.

This includes funding parenting programs that are proven to increase parents' confidence and safety and routine in households, family workers who help families readdress roles and responsibilities, or fast moving teams that can quickly intervene with families at the point of crisis and move the dynamics to a safer and calmer environment that last for the long term.

These models can be game changers in communities around Australia yet seem to be fringe dwellers of family welfare in this country.

For the community and its political leaders this is where the long-term dividends in the form of reduced welfare payments can be found. And directing such investment does not need to be difficult as we now have strong instructive data that tell us which postcodes are driving our child protection, correctional services and income benefit demands.

Being more strategic in investing in communities, the international evidence suggests, will see community disadvantage decrease and family functioning lift through such place-based investment.

However, this type of thinking requires a change of mind set in approaching welfare policy. Governments could be helped in viewing a new approach by bringing in our best social researchers and service providers to a dialogue with them on how disadvantage, within a family or within a community, can be turned around and how, proactive investment coupled with the right models can reap great returns for families and governments alike.

With the evidence now shattering our fairy tale view of ourselves as a society, governments could do worse than to establish an inquiry or summit to discuss ways to repair the now emerging chasm in our society.
TITLE: Where The Land Of The Fair Go Has Gone

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

KOCHI -- The Kerala High Court on Thursday held that all inter-religious weddings cannot be viewed as 'love jihad' as it upheld a marriage between a Hindu woman and a Muslim man.

A division bench comprising justices V Chitambaresh and Sathish Ninan made the observations in its judgement on a habeas corpus petition filed by the man. A habeas corpus plea is filed to ensure a person under arrest is brought before a court which will determine whether the detention is legal.

"We are appalled to notice the recent trend in this state to sensationalise every case of inter-religious marriage as either 'love jihad' or 'ghar wapsi' even if there was platonic love between the spouses before," the court said.

The bench also cited the Supreme Court order in the Lata Singh versus state of Uttar Pradesh case of 2004 to emphasise the need for encouraging inter-caste and inter-religious marriages.

"We caution that every case of inter-religious marriage shall not be portrayed on a religious canvass and create fissures in the communal harmony otherwise existing in the God's Own Country - Kerala," the bench said and upheld the marriage.

It said the present case was projected by the parents of the woman as 'love jihad' whereas the man, who was in love with her and married her later, termed it as 'ghar wapsi' (a bid to coerce her to come back).

The woman from Kannur had left her home on 16 May along with the Muslim youth. On a complaint from her parents, police had traced and detained them in Sonepat in Haryana a month later.

Initially, a lower court had allowed the woman to go with her parents, who then lodged her in a yoga centre at Tripunithura in Ernakulam district allegedly to make her give up the relationship with the Muslim man.

When the woman was produced before the high court on 18 August, she had interacted with a single judge and expressed her desire to go back with parents.

Subsequently, when the petition came up for hearing four days later, the woman retracted her stand and told the division bench that she made the statement expressing her wish to go with her parents under pressure.

She alleged that she was tortured at the yoga centre. It was being run "to coerce the inmates to return to Hindu religion", she had charged.

During the litigation and counter-litigation by both sides, the woman and man had got married legally.

The division bench applauded the "extra-ordinary courage" shown by the girl to live up to her conviction and "decry the attempt of her parents to deflect the course of justice by misleading litigations".

It observed their marriage had now been registered too.

The court also observed that any centre for forcible conversion or re-conversion had to be busted by the police whether it was Hindu, Muslim or Christian lest it offends the Constitutional right.

Article 25 (1) of the Constitution guaranteed every citizen the right to freely profess, practice and propagate any religion which cannot be trampled upon by subversive forces or religious outfits, the court observed.

The judgement began with a quote from American poet Maya Angelou who famously said: "Love recognises no barriers. It jumps hurdles, leaps fences, penetrates walls to arrive at its destination full of hope."

It may recalled that another division bench of the Kerala High Court had in May annulled the marriage of a 24-year-old woman with a Muslim man after allegedly forced to convert to Islam, terming it as an instance of 'love jihad'.

On an appeal by the husband, the Supreme Court had on August 16 ordered a probe by the National Investigation Agency into the case as the agency claimed it was not an isolated incident but a "pattern" that was emerging in Kerala.
TITLE: 'Not All Inter-Religious Marriages Can Be Viewed As Love Jihad,' Says Kerala HC

SUMMARY:
The children Bassam Darwich paid for sex were pimped to him by two women who targeted vulnerable young runaways or those in the care of community services.
She initially said she didn't want to have sex for money but ended up agreeing just to keep the women happy.
Another girl's concerned mother had shown up at a hotel where her daughter was with Darwich, the court heard.
Judge Conlon said Darwich's offences had a psychological impact on his victims damaging to their self-worth.
He was unable to admit to his family that he knew the girls were underage, Judge Conlon said.
TEXT:
The children Bassam Darwich paid for sex were pimped to him by two women who targeted vulnerable young runaways or those in the care of community services.

One girl was 12 when she met him at a hotel in 2011. She shut her eyes and put a pillow over her face when he tried to kiss her.

"It made me feel sick," she told a court.

Darwich, 57, was jailed for at least 20 months in the NSW District Court in Sydney on Thursday for engaging three child prostitutes aged between 12 and 16 on infrequent occasions between 2010 and 2011.

Judge Paul Conlon said the 12-year-old victim had just run away from a refuge when the two women gave her a place to stay.

Bassam Darwich has been jailed after a jury found him guilty of acting as a client in child prostitution.#9News https://t.co/2K3YIhHcsn â€” Nine News Sydney (@9NewsSyd) October 19, 2017

The girl agreed to sell herself when they told her she'd have to go home if she didn't.

Darwich paid the girl $100 and she gave it to one of the women because she knew she would be asked for it anyway, the court heard.

The judge said another girl was 15 or 16 and a regular user of the drug ice when she moved in with the women.

She initially said she didn't want to have sex for money but ended up agreeing just to keep the women happy.

She said she kept her eyes closed the entire time she was with Darwich and she believes he later paid one of the women about $50, the court heard.

Darwich has denied knowing the girls were so young but Judge Conlon said while the 12-year-old did look older, she didn't appear to be anywhere near 18.

Another girl's concerned mother had shown up at a hotel where her daughter was with Darwich, the court heard. However he simply engaged in sexual acts with her after she left.

Judge Conlon said Darwich's offences had a psychological impact on his victims damaging to their self-worth.

Yet he agreed he didn't mistreat, coerce or exhibit degrading behaviour towards the girls.

He said it was usually argued a person could not be rehabilitated if they continued to deny their offences but in this case he felt Darwich's denial had more to do with embarrassment and humiliation.

He was unable to admit to his family that he knew the girls were underage, Judge Conlon said.

Darwich's sentence has been backdated to May 2017 and he will be eligible for parole in January 2019.
TITLE: NSW Man Jailed For Paying To Have Sex With Children

SUMMARY:
When it comes to emotional cheating, the lines between what constitutes an affair, and what doesnâ€™t, can feel very blurred.
â€œSome people have told me theyâ€™d rather their partner had a one-night stand than an emotional affair,â€ Relate counsellor Dee Holmes tells HuffPost UK.
That said, relationship counsellors do agree on one thing: when a person becomes emotionally unavailable to their partner, instead turning to their new interest for support, this constitutes emotional cheating.
What is considered cheating, is messaging constantly and beginning to rely on that other person for emotional support in place of a partner.
â€œSo sensing youâ€™re no longer included in their life or their thought processes is a sign.â€How to handle emotional cheating.
TEXT:
When it comes to emotional cheating, the lines between what constitutes an affair, and what doesnâ€™t, can feel very blurred. But that doesnâ€™t detract from the pain it can cause.

â€œSome people have told me theyâ€™d rather their partner had a one-night stand than an emotional affair,â€ Relate counsellor Dee Holmes tells HuffPost UK. â€œThey believe it would be easier to deal with.â€

People have different boundaries when it comes to what constitutes inappropriate behaviour. That said, relationship counsellors do agree on one thing: when a person becomes emotionally unavailable to their partner, instead turning to their new interest for support, this constitutes emotional cheating.

franckreporter via Getty Images

Madeleine Mason, dating and relationship psychologist, explains: â€œEmotional cheating is a non-sexual, emotionally-intimate relationship between two people, where one is in a committed relationship to someone else.â€

During this time, a personâ€™s partner might remain unaware about the level of intimacy between the two â€œfriendsâ€.

Of course, innocently texting a colleague every now and then or having relationships with other people is not cheating.

What is considered cheating, is messaging constantly and beginning to rely on that other person for emotional support in place of a partner.

â€œThey become the first person your partner turns to when they need emotional support or want to share good news,â€ Mason explains. â€œYour partner prefers the other personâ€™s comfort and affection over and above that of you.

â€œYour partner is cheating you out of emotional intimacy, as they are meant be your support and vice versa.â€

If your partner is sending sexual messages, this may also be considered â€œcheatingâ€, even if there has been no physical contact.

Michael Kallenbach, a relationship counsellor working in London and Marlborough, explains: â€œHaving a full blown sexual affair is often too risky for both sides, so they might resort to salacious and sexy text messaging without any sexual encounters taking place.â€

Which is why, Holmes advises couples iron out what they define as an affair in the early stages of their relationship.

â€œIâ€™ve seen people in the counselling room who have separate definitions of what cheating is,â€ she explains.

â€œOne person might think their husband is having an affair, while he says â€˜no Iâ€™m not, sheâ€™s accusing me of it but I just went out to lunch with my secretary twice.â€™â€

Signs your partner might be emotionally cheating.

1. An unexplainable change in behaviour

â€œA major sign would be a change in their behaviour that doesnâ€™t seem to have an explanation,â€ says Holmes.

There are a wide range of behavioural changes, which could act as a â€œred flagâ€ over time, according to Madeleine Mason. These may include:

:: increased use of technology such as texting, social media interaction and calls,

:: being more upbeat after receiving texts,

:: a tendency to hide the phone or become nervous when you are close to their phone,

:: becoming more secretive,

:: going out more - for example more late nights at work or meeting more often with a particular friend,

:: a sudden and increased interest in appearance - for example buying new clothes or taking up gym sessions,

:: acting more distant and cold towards you,

:: being vague about their whereabouts and who they have been with,

:: having less sex,

:: equally, wanting more sex could be a sign,

:: talking a lot about someone else and dropping their name or mentioning their point of view in conversations, or talking about them and suddenly ceasing to mention them (â€œit could be because they are playing it safe by keeping the person out of conversations incase they give away the new closeness with them,â€ explains Holmes).

Itâ€™s important to remember that, first and foremost, these are signs that somethingâ€™s not quite right in your relationship (not necessarily that your partner is having an affair) - and communication is important to address this.

â€œHave a conversation about what is not right with your relationship, be it you are dissatisfied that sex has reduced or you spend less time together,â€ says Mason.

â€œRegardless of whether the emotional affair is going on, something is not right in your relationship - and you have the power to address that.â€

2. Defensiveness

People can also become quite defensive when theyâ€™re having an emotional affair.

â€œEspecially when theyâ€™re doing something which they might be excusing themselves for - for example, thinking â€˜oh itâ€™s only lunchâ€™,â€ explains Holmes.

â€œIf you tell your partner that they seem to be texting a lot or late home a lot, they might get defensive and this behaviour is often a sign of guilt.â€

3. Becoming distanced

â€œIf two people have been emotionally close in a relationship and shared a lot with each other, when one of them starts to share these things with someone else, their partner might notice theyâ€™re not being kept in the loop anymore,â€ says Holmes. â€œSo sensing youâ€™re no longer included in their life or their thought processes is a sign.â€

How to handle emotional cheating.

The key to dealing with this behaviour is communication, although Holmes suggests taking a different approach than youâ€™d expect.

â€œRather than saying â€˜you never talk to meâ€™ anymore, bring up that you donâ€™t feel close to them anymore and youâ€™re wondering why youâ€™re not as close,â€ she advises.
TITLE: How To Tell If Your Partner Is Emotionally Cheating

SUMMARY:
A member of the Question Time audience last night launched a passionate attack on Universal Credit, claiming the Government is showing â€œcontempt for the poorâ€.
The Conservative representative on this weekâ€™s show, Chris Grayling, was questioned repeatedly on the issue, with even host David Dimbleby getting exasperated at his responses.
But it was the contribution from a lady in the audience which brought the biggest cheer.
The Government has been under intense pressure over Universal Credit, most recently to set aside millions to refund the call fees of claimants after confirming plans to scrap charges for the serviceâ€™s helpline.
Work and Pensions Secretary David Gauke confirmed on Wednesday that up to 55p a minute fees would no longer apply from November, with all calls to benefits advice lines beginning 0345 to be made free by the end of the year.
TEXT:
A member of the Question Time audience last night launched a passionate attack on Universal Credit, claiming the Government is showing â€œcontempt for the poorâ€.

The Conservative representative on this weekâ€™s show, Chris Grayling, was questioned repeatedly on the issue, with even host David Dimbleby getting exasperated at his responses.

But it was the contribution from a lady in the audience which brought the biggest cheer.

The Government has been under intense pressure over Universal Credit, most recently to set aside millions to refund the call fees of claimants after confirming plans to scrap charges for the serviceâ€™s helpline.

Work and Pensions Secretary David Gauke confirmed on Wednesday that up to 55p a minute fees would no longer apply from November, with all calls to benefits advice lines beginning 0345 to be made free by the end of the year.
TITLE: Question Time Audience Member Attacks Toriesâ€™ â€˜Contempt For The Poorâ€™ Over Universal Credit

Sedesol autorizÃ³ 100 millones que se van a destinar a las viviendas de TlÃ¡huac y Xochimilco, anunciÃ³ hoy Mancera y explicÃ³ que serÃ¡n casas antisÃ­smicas.
Asimismo, el gobierno local estÃ¡ impulsando que el presupuesto participativo se pueda utilizar para el mismo fin.
Al anunciar que se van a instalar mil altavoces mÃ¡s en los postes de la ciudad, Mancera se jactÃ³ de ser Ã©l quien decidiÃ³ colocar la alerta sÃ­smica en el mobiliario urbano, aunque la gente se "enojÃ³ mucho".
Pero ahora fÃ­jense, le damos la vuelta a la pÃ¡gina y ahora quieren que pongamos mÃ¡s y ahora dicen 'Â¿Y por quÃ© no lo pones aquÃ­ en la esquina de mi casa?'."
TEXT:
A un mes de suscitarse el sismo, la Ciudad de MÃ©xico estÃ¡ en pie y continÃºa redoblando el esfuerzo en las labores de reconstrucciÃ³n y transformaciÃ³n, afirmÃ³ el jefe de gobierno, Miguel Ãngel Mancera Espinosa, quien tambiÃ©n se ha ocupado de dejar en claro que no dejarÃ¡ de lado sus aspiraciones rumbo a 2018, las cuales en algÃºn punto parecieron cimbrarse.

Este 19 de octubre, antes de anunciar que la SecretarÃ­a de Desarrollo Social (Sedesol) autorizÃ³ 100 millones de pesos para la construcciÃ³n de viviendas y recordar que le dijeron de todo cuando decidiÃ³ poner las alertas sÃ­smicas en los postes de la ciudad, dejÃ³ en claro que no renuncia a sus aspiraciones presidenciales, pero sÃ­ a la oportunidad de buscar una candidatura independiente, lo cual ya tampoco serÃ­a factible con base en los tiempos del INE.

TambiÃ©n, en entrevista radiofÃ³nica con W Radio, se dijo creyente del Frente Ciudadano como "una gran oportunidad para un cambio de rÃ©gimen."

Mancera fue claro: le interesa participar en el Frente, aunque, dijo, debido a la emergencia que el sismo desatÃ³ en Ciudad de MÃ©xico no ha podido participar.

No he podido trabajar con el grupo que estÃ¡ haciÃ©ndolo, apoyÃ¡ndolo, porque me tiene ocupado el tema de la Ciudad de MÃ©xico, es mi prioridad (...) Yo no cancelo poder servirle a MÃ©xico, y si llegamos a tener la oportunidad de participar, me gustarÃ­a participar en el Frente, cancelada completamente la posibilidad de participar como independiente."

Sedesol autorizÃ³ 100 millones que se van a destinar a las viviendas de TlÃ¡huac y Xochimilco, anunciÃ³ hoy Mancera y explicÃ³ que serÃ¡n casas antisÃ­smicas.

Esto se suma a los recursos del Fondo de Aportaciones para la Infraestructura Social (FAIS), el cual originalmente estÃ¡ destinado a las delegaciones, pero que ayer el gobierno capitalino acordÃ³ con la SecretarÃ­a de Hacienda y CrÃ©dito PÃºblico (SHCP) redireccionarlo para la reconstrucciÃ³n de las zonas daÃ±adas.

Asimismo, el gobierno local estÃ¡ impulsando que el presupuesto participativo se pueda utilizar para el mismo fin.

Al anunciar que se van a instalar mil altavoces mÃ¡s en los postes de la ciudad, Mancera se jactÃ³ de ser Ã©l quien decidiÃ³ colocar la alerta sÃ­smica en el mobiliario urbano, aunque la gente se "enojÃ³ mucho".

Yo fui el que decidÃ­ que la alerta sÃ­smica estuviera en los postes, en los altavoces y la gente se enojÃ³ mucho en ese tiempo porque era una gran alerta y porque sonaba muy fuerte y me dijeron que le bajara el volumen y ya lo he repetido varias veces, me preguntaban por quÃ© no me lo ponÃ­a yo en el burÃ³ de mi cama para que me despertara y bueno. Me dijeron de todo.

Pero ahora fÃ­jense, le damos la vuelta a la pÃ¡gina y ahora quieren que pongamos mÃ¡s y ahora dicen 'Â¿Y por quÃ© no lo pones aquÃ­ en la esquina de mi casa?'."
TITLE: Mancera deja claro que el sismo no cimbrÃ³ sus aspiraciones a 2018

SUMMARY:
Two weeks after investigative journalists exposed decades of accusations of sexual misconduct against Harvey Weinstein , Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyongâ€™o has come forward with her own allegations against the disgraced producer.
More than 40 women have accused Weinstein of using his power in the industry to manipulate, harass and sexually abuse them.
â€œWe went back and forth,â€ the actress wrote, â€œuntil finally he turned to the waiter and said, â€˜Get her what I tell you to get her.
Nyongâ€™o recalled:Harvey led me into a bedroom â€” his bedroom â€” and announced that he wanted to give me a massage.
The massage ended when Weinstein said he wanted to take off his pants.
TEXT:
In an op-ed for The New York Times , Nyongâ€™o, 34, said Weinstein invited her to lunch, then to his Connecticut home for a private movie screening, where he brought her up to his room, offered to give her a massage, then said he wanted to take off his pants. She also accused the Hollywood mogul of abruptly ending a dinner with her after she declined his invitation to come up to his hotel room.

Two weeks after investigative journalists exposed decades of accusations of sexual misconduct against Harvey Weinstein , Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyongâ€™o has come forward with her own allegations against the disgraced producer.

I was part of a community of women who were secretly dealing with harassment by Weinstein, says @Lupita_Nyongo https://t.co/XZpHnQ8Ine

Many of Weinsteinâ€™s accusersâ€™ stories have a similar pattern : Weinstein lured them into a room under the guise of a business meeting, then pressured them into an intimate act. In some cases, Weinstein is accused of rape. In others, he is accused of humiliating them after they rejected his advances.

More than 40 women have accused Weinstein of using his power in the industry to manipulate, harass and sexually abuse them. The alleged incidents span decades. Police in Los Angeles , New York and London are investigating claims of sex crimes, including rape, against the producer.

â€œBut now that this is being discussed openly, I have not been able to avoid the memories resurfacing.â€

â€œI had shelved my experience with Harvey far in the recesses of my mind , joining in the conspiracy of silence that has allowed this predator to prowl for so many years,â€ wrote the actress, who won an Academy Award in 2014 for her supporting role in the acclaimed film â€œ12 Years a Slave.â€

These encounters, Nyongâ€™o wrote, happened when she was still an aspiring actress and student at the Yale School of Drama.

Me looking (and feeling) peaceful in '97, 21 years old, a few months before I was raped by #HarveyWeinstein pic.twitter.com/tr6sgfIr4v

In her op-ed, Nyongâ€™o described Weinsteinâ€™s bullying and unwanted advances on her. She explained how he made it difficult when she told him no, and what she had to do to try to take back control of the situations he put her in.

During a lunch with Weinstein, Nyongâ€™o said, the producer insisted that she order a vodka and soda, ordered one for her and then told her she needed to drink it even after she declined it more than once.

â€œWe went back and forth,â€ the actress wrote, â€œuntil finally he turned to the waiter and said, â€˜Get her what I tell you to get her. Iâ€™m the one paying the bill.â€™â€

Later at a movie screening at his house, Weinstein interrupted the movie and led Nyongâ€™o up to his bedroom, where he told her he wanted to massage her. Feeling uncomfortable and uncertain, the actress said she offered to give him one instead so she could be in control of the situation.

She rationalized that decision: It would be just like her body work classes in her drama department, in which students massage each other to understand the connection between body, mind and emotion.

Nyongâ€™o recalled:

Harvey led me into a bedroom â€” his bedroom â€” and announced that he wanted to give me a massage. I thought he was joking at first. He was not. For the first time since I met him, I felt unsafe. I panicked a little and thought quickly to offer to give him one instead: It would allow me to be in control physically, to know exactly where his hands were at all times.

The massage ended when Weinstein said he wanted to take off his pants. Nyongâ€™o left the room and eventually his house.

At another dinner with the producer, Nyongâ€™o said, Weinstein cut their meal short after she rejected his invitation to go up to his hotel room:

I was stunned. I told him I preferred to eat in the restaurant. He told me not to be so naÃ¯ve. If I wanted to be an actress, then I had to be willing to do this sort of thing. He said he had dated Famous Actress X and Y and look where that had gotten them. I was silent for a while before I mustered up the courage to politely decline his offer.

Nyongâ€™o â€• whoâ€™s starred in several blockbuster films in her career, including â€œStar Wars: The Force Awakensâ€ and the upcoming â€œStar Wars: The Last Jediâ€ â€• said that she hasnâ€™t faced any such harassment since her encounters with Weinstein. She attributes this to choosing projects led by women and â€œmen who are feminists in their own right who have not abused their power.â€

Weinstein isnâ€™t the only powerful figure in Hollywood accused of abuse. Former Playboy model Carrie Stevens and actress Patricia Arquette have accused director Oliver Stone of abusive behavior. Weinsteinâ€™s brother Bob has also been accused of being abusive and a bully.

The actress said the industryâ€™s â€œintimate natureâ€ is why insiders must stay vigilant about abusers in the industry.

â€œNow that we are speaking, let us never shut up about this kind of thing,â€ she wrote.

â€œI speak up to contribute to the end of the conspiracy of silence.â€

Read Lupita Nyongâ€™oâ€™s op-ed here.
TITLE: Lupita Nyongâ€™o Says Weinstein Pushed Her To Massage Him: 'I Panicked'

SUMMARY:
However, the first cat in space has been largely forgotten by history.
Centre dEnseignement et de Recherches de Medecine AeronautiqueNo cat has been in space since and FÃ©licette has become a UFO â€” an underappreciated feline orbiter.
â€œAround 6 months ago whilst at work, I came across a tea towel in the staff kitchen commemorating the 50th anniversary of the cat who went to space,â€ Guy said in a release.
â€œThere was no name for the cat on the towel, nor did it resemble FÃ©licette.
â€œAfter Googling it, I became fascinated with FÃ©licetteâ€™s story, how it had been forgotten over the years, and (like the design of the tea towel) misattributed.
TEXT:
Everyone knows the names of famous astronauts like Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and some may even remember Laika, the first dog in space.

However, the first cat in space has been largely forgotten by history.

This pioneering pussycat was named â€FÃ©licette,â€ and she was shot into space 54 years ago this week from a base in the Sahara desert by the Centre National dâ€™Ã©tudes Spatiales (CNES), the French version of NASA.

FÃ©licette was picked out of a group of about a dozen cats because she had the best reaction to a series of tests that included a spin in a centrifuge, according to EuroNews.

Her 12-minute flight took her 97 miles above Earth and included five minutes of weightlessness.

Although this â€œAstrocatâ€ made history, FÃ©licette was euthanized a few months later so scientists could study the effects of space travel on her body.

Centre dEnseignement et de Recherches de Medecine Aeronautique

No cat has been in space since and FÃ©licette has become a UFO â€” an underappreciated feline orbiter.

Even worse, in some of the few tributes she received, sheâ€™s been misidentified as a male named Felix, according to LeDauphine.com

Now a British advertising executive is hoping to restore FÃ©licette to the pantheon of great space explorers by erecting a statue in her honor in Paris, France.

Matthew Serge Guy, a creative director for Anomaly London, has started a Kickstarter campaign to raise $52,439 for the statue.

â€œAround 6 months ago whilst at work, I came across a tea towel in the staff kitchen commemorating the 50th anniversary of the cat who went to space,â€ Guy said in a release. â€œThere was no name for the cat on the towel, nor did it resemble FÃ©licette.

â€œAfter Googling it, I became fascinated with FÃ©licetteâ€™s story, how it had been forgotten over the years, and (like the design of the tea towel) misattributed. It felt like something big should be done to right these wrongs.â€

The campaign video is below and seems to have catapulted FÃ©licette back into the public eye. After one day, Guy is nearly 20 percent towards his goal with a month to go.

Guy emphasizes to recognize that FÃ©licette and other animals involved in the early days of space exploration suffered and had no choice in the matter.
TITLE: The First Cat In Space May Finally Get The Recognition She Deserves

SUMMARY:
Atsuko Kudo is the Japanese designer who brought latex-wear out of the world of fetishes and into the mainstream.
So of the other sins itâ€™s possible it could be associated with pride - as in being proud to wear latex for those reasons.
I first tried latex clothing myself when I was at college in Japan (a long time ago!)
Rebecca Naden - PA Images via Getty Images British model Georgia Frost wears a lace print latex ballgown, designed by Atsuko Kudo.
Itâ€™s a myth that you need the perfect body to wear latex.
TEXT:
Atsuko Kudo is the Japanese designer who brought latex-wear out of the world of fetishes and into the mainstream.

Favoured by the likes of Kim Kardashian, Jennifer Metcalfe and Taylor Swift, Kudo says her dream is now to see a royal in one her designs.

â€œMy ambition is still to dress the Queen,â€ she tells HuffPost UK.

â€œStylistically I wouldnâ€™t stray too much from the kind of thing she already wears - but of course it would have to be latex.â€

Scott Barbour via Getty Images Kim Kardashian in an Atsuko Kudo design.

We caught up with the designer ahead of the launch of her collaboration with Veuve Clicquot, the champagne brand celebrating the Seven Deadly Sins as part of their annual art installation, the â€˜Widowâ€™ series.

Hosted by Carine Roitfeld, the two-day event taking place in London on 20 and 21 October will be decked out by renowned opera set designer Patrick Kinmonth and Kudo is contributing designs to represent the seventh sin: Lust.

She discussed ideas surrounding women and their sexuality, the trend of lingerie worn as outerwear and whether she considers any part of that a â€˜sin,â€™ or simply a womanâ€™s right.

Thomas Niedermueller via Getty Images Designer Atsuko Kudo.

Do you think â€˜lustâ€™ is the â€˜sinâ€™ that most suits your stylistic take on garment making?

Because I design exclusively in latex, I understand that my clothing is often concerned with a sensual and sexual experience.

So if lust is a sin then itâ€™s probably the most suitable of the seven! Iâ€™d also like to think that my designs are concerned with love, empowerment and respect.

So of the other sins itâ€™s possible it could be associated with pride - as in being proud to wear latex for those reasons.

We loved your play on the idea of the â€œmodest womanâ€ in your New York collection. What are your thoughts on modesty and fashion?

In some ways modesty can seem outdated as it can be confused with prudishness.

I am most concerned with designing clothing that can help the person wearing it to look and feel beautiful, feminine and strong.

What the clothing reveals and what it doesnâ€™t reveal, should be in the hands of the person choosing to wear it.

And being covered or semi covered is more often - I think - sexier than total nudity. I hope my designs make that choice deeper and hopefully more empowering.

When I design for our shows I always try to present several different moods - so there is something for every occasion.

A post shared by atsukokudolatex (@atsukokudolatex) on Jun 24, 2017 at 9:35am PDT

Were you always confident the trend of wearing latex would take off as it has for your brand?

I first tried latex clothing myself when I was at college in Japan (a long time ago!) I felt it was thrilling and made me feel like a superwoman.

I thought if I felt like that about it other women might also feel the same - if I could design pieces, which they would enjoy.

So it started from there. Now more women enjoy wearing this unique fabric and I am happy if I have been responsible for it in any way.

Rebecca Naden - PA Images via Getty Images British model Georgia Frost wears a lace print latex ballgown, designed by Atsuko Kudo.

Many of the ladies who wear your creations are superstars with lots of confidence. How do your garments make normal women, who may not be as confident, feel good in their skin?

We dress many women from all over the world and the vast majority are not famous.

Itâ€™s important to understand that all women come in different shapes and sizes including celebrities.

My job is to make every person who wears the clothing feel special and create a moment for them that is outside of everyday reality.

Itâ€™s a myth that you need the perfect body to wear latex. Atsuko Kudo

If latex clothing is cut correctly (as I hope mine is) then it will act like the best kind of shapewear and enhance your natural assets - but it must be cut correctly.

Then anyone can enjoy the feeling it gives - making the best of what you have.

David M. Benett via Getty Images Rita Ora in one of Kudo's designs.

Was it always your intention to showcase your work in lingerie as outerwear?

Iâ€™ve always considered it pointless to distinguish between categories of clothing.

I only work in latex, so the difference between lingerie and outerwear gets quite blurred.

But then I also think you donâ€™t have to just wear a mac only when itâ€™s raining.

You can wear whatever suits your mood.

A post shared by atsukokudolatex (@atsukokudolatex) on Mar 8, 2017 at 3:06am PST

What kind of outcome are you anticipating from your collaboration with Veuve Clicquot?

This project is so inspiring because of the subject (Seven Deadly Sins) but also because of the opportunity to work with such amazing people as Carine Roitfeld and Patrick Kinmonth.

I am excited and a little nervous because the expectation working with such talented people is very high.

The ideas weâ€™ve put together will be very interesting and hopefully will inspire others.

We donâ€™t have the sins listed in this way in Japanese so Iâ€™m naturally fascinated by them.

Doug Peters/EMPICS Entertainment Jennifer Metcalfe wears one of Kudo's designs.

What outfits can we expect for your â€œlustâ€ section at the Veuve Clicquot Widow Series?

I canâ€™t give too much away as to the looks at this stage - youâ€™ll have to come to the exhibition and see. It will be expressive and about more than the outfits.

But I can say that it will be sexy, shiny and hopefully lustful in all the right ways!

A post shared by Veuve Clicquot UK (@veuveclicquotuk) on Oct 4, 2017 at 6:01am PDT
TITLE: Kim Kardashian's Favourite Designer Atsuko Kudo Wants To Dress The Queen In Latex

Jeremy Corbyn has a â€œvery strongâ€ prospect of winning the next general election, Lord Mandelson has conceded.
But speaking to BBC Radio 4â€²s Today programme on Friday, Lord Mandelson said some Tory MPs now believed they faced â€œannihilationâ€ at the hands of Labour.
â€œI think obviously the prospects for the Labour party are now looking very strong.
I think Mr Corbyn has a choice,â€ he said.

TEXT:
Jeremy Corbyn has a â€œvery strongâ€ prospect of winning the next general election, Lord Mandelson has conceded.

The former Labour cabinet minister has previously been extremely critical of Corbyn and his electoral

Before the election he famously said he worked â€œevery single dayâ€ to try and remove Corbyn from the leadership of the party.

But speaking to BBC Radio 4â€²s Today programme on Friday, Lord Mandelson said some Tory MPs now believed they faced â€œannihilationâ€ at the hands of Labour.

â€œIâ€™m not a Corbynista. I am New Labour to my core because I believe in both social justice and economic efficiency,â€ he said.

â€œBut he is the leader, the Tories are giving him and the Labour party victory on a plate at the next election, it seems to me but what sort of victory he gets depends on him and what he does now.â€

JOHN THYS via Getty Images

Lord Mandelson said if Corbyn wanted to secure a big win at the next election, due in 2022, he should reach out to voters in the centre ground.

â€œI think obviously the prospects for the Labour party are now looking very strong. I think Mr Corbyn has a choice,â€ he said.

â€œFirst of all, Iâ€™ve talked to two Conservative MPs in the last week in Parliament who are now talking about the threat of annihilation of the Conservative party at the next election and that very referendum that was designed to heal the divisions in the Conservative Party has instead deepened them further.

â€œBut I think the actual result depends on what Jeremy Corbyn does now and I think he has a choice.

â€œIn the party he can go for total ideological control of Labour or he can opt instead for unity right across Labourâ€™s broad spectrum.

â€œAnd in the country he can either consolidate his sort of sectarian support on the left and amongst young voters or he can additionally embrace more centrist and older voters.
TITLE: Jeremy Corbyn Has 'Very Strong Prospect' Of Winning The Next Election, Admits Lord Mandelson

SUMMARY:
People participate in an emergency exercise on prevention and control of H7N9 bird flu virus organised by the Health and Family Planning Commission of the local government in Hebi, Henan province, China.
The H7N9 virus has been circulating in China since 2013, causing severe disease in people exposed to infected poultry.
Is H7N9 flu going to go pandemic?
'The whole world is worried about it': New H7N9 bird flu strain in China has pandemic potential https://t.co/dPBOrS7WTh #7News pic.twitter.com/5MIqi9XyCQ â€” 7News Yahoo7 (@Y7News) October 20, 2017"The work is very concerning in terms of the implications for what H7N9 might do in the days ahead in terms of human infection," said Michael Osterholm, an infectious disease expert from the University of Minnesota.
Since 2013, the H7N9 bird flu virus has already sickened at least 1,562 people in China and killed at least 612.
TEXT:
People participate in an emergency exercise on prevention and control of H7N9 bird flu virus organised by the Health and Family Planning Commission of the local government in Hebi, Henan province, China.

CHICAGO, Oct 19 (Reuters) - Lab experiments on a new strain of the H7N9 bird flu circulating in China suggest the virus can transmit easily among animals and can cause lethal disease, raising alarms that the virus has the potential for triggering a global human pandemic, researchers reported on Thursday.

The H7N9 virus has been circulating in China since 2013, causing severe disease in people exposed to infected poultry. Last year, however, human cases spiked, and the virus split into two distinct strains that are so different they no longer succumb to existing vaccines.

One of these has also become highly pathogenic, meaning it has gained the ability to kill infected birds, posing a threat to agriculture markets.

U.S. and Japanese researchers studied a sample of this new highly pathogenic strain to see how well it spread among mammals, including ferrets, which are considered the best animal model for testing the transmissibility of influenza in humans.

Is H7N9 flu going to go pandemic? Well, there's both good and bad news: https://t.co/Ujd1xPCiyv â€” Ed Yong (@edyong209) October 19, 2017

In the study published in Cell Host & Microbe, flu expert Yoshihiro Kawaoka of the University of Wisconsin and colleagues tested a version of the new H7N9 strain taken from a person who died from their infection last spring.

They found that the virus replicated efficiently in mice, ferrets and non-human primates, and that it caused even more severe disease in mice and ferrets than a low pathogenic version of the same virus that does not cause illness in birds.

To test transmissibility, the team placed healthy ferrets next to infected animals and found the virus spread easily from cage to cage, suggesting the virus can be transmitted by respiratory droplets such as those produced by coughing and sneezing.

Two out of three healthy ferrets infected in this way died, which Kawaoka said is "extremely unusual," suggesting that even a small amount of virus can cause severe disease.

'The whole world is worried about it': New H7N9 bird flu strain in China has pandemic potential https://t.co/dPBOrS7WTh #7News pic.twitter.com/5MIqi9XyCQ â€” 7News Yahoo7 (@Y7News) October 20, 2017

"The work is very concerning in terms of the implications for what H7N9 might do in the days ahead in terms of human infection," said Michael Osterholm, an infectious disease expert from the University of Minnesota.

Since 2013, the H7N9 bird flu virus has already sickened at least 1,562 people in China and killed at least 612. Some 40 percent of people hospitalized with the virus die.

In the first four epidemics, the virus showed few changes. But last flu season, there were some 764 cases - nearly half of the 1,562 total.

"The whole world is worried about it," Osterholm said.

(Reporting by Julie Steenhuysen; Editing by Marguerita Choy)
TITLE: New H7N9 Bird Flu Strain In China Has The Whole World Worried

SUMMARY:
These are packed with summery fruits like watermelon, mango and peaches, and use a variety of alcohol bases like wine, whisky and white rum.
These minty watermelon mojitos are incredibly easy to make and require just five ingredients.
Wine lovers, grab some berries, stone fruit and your favourite white wine because it's time to make sangria.
These mango mojitos are zesty, minty and super easy to make -- just pop your ingredients in the blender and enjoy.
This pretty pink punch is made with refreshing coconut water, champagne (or white wine if you prefer), juice and fresh fruit.
TEXT:
With spring in full bloom and summer time just around the corner, we start turning to ways to cool down -- ocean swims, air con (or alternatively, four fans on full blast), acai bowls and of course, refreshing drinks.

Here are eight refreshing, delicious cocktails to try. These are packed with summery fruits like watermelon, mango and peaches, and use a variety of alcohol bases like wine, whisky and white rum.

To make these drinks alcohol-free, simply sub the alcohol for more juice or sparkling water.

1. Watermelon mojitos

From Jessica in the Kitchen.

Juicy watermelon is ideal for staying hydrated and cool on a hot day. These minty watermelon mojitos are incredibly easy to make and require just five ingredients. Here's the recipe.

2. Easy white sangria

From Minimalist Baker.

Wine lovers, grab some berries, stone fruit and your favourite white wine because it's time to make sangria. This recipe is simple and requires just eight ingredients, one pitcher and 15 minutes to whip up. Get the recipe.

3. Whisky lemonade with honey simple syrup

From Foodie Crush.

Need something a little stronger? Try this fresh whisky lemonade with your favourite herbs (basil, rosemary, lavender and mint all work well) and simple syrup made with honey instead of sugar. Try the recipe.

4. Mango mojitos

From Jessica in the Kitchen.

Mangoes are the symbol of summer and are perfect in cocktails. These mango mojitos are zesty, minty and super easy to make -- just pop your ingredients in the blender and enjoy. Here's the recipe.

5. Ginger beer paloma cocktails

From A Saucy Kitchen.

Ginger beer fans, try this fiery, gingery cocktail with grapefruit juice, lime juice, tequila and agave syrup. And don't forget the salt-dipped glasses for a salty twist. Get the recipe.

6. RosÃ© sangria

From Jessica in the Kitchen.

With its delicate and fresh flavour, rosÃ© pairs beautifully with sangria. This sweet and summery rosÃ© sangria is simple to make and best enjoyed by the poolside. Try the recipe.

7. Coconut water champagne fruit punch

From Averie Cooks.

This pretty pink punch is made with refreshing coconut water, champagne (or white wine if you prefer), juice and fresh fruit. All you need to do is combine the ingredients in a large mixing bowl or pitcher, stir to combine and chill in the fridge before serving. Get the recipe.

8. Frozen pineapple margaritas

From A Saucy Kitchen.

Add an adult twist to your favourite childhood slushies with these frozen pineapple maragarias. You'll need pineapple, freshly squeezed lime juice, tequila and triple sec to make these naturally sweet and fresh margaritas. Here's the recipe.
TITLE: 8 Easy, Refreshing Cocktails To Make This Summer

SUMMARY:
Among men, the lowest risk group were those who had one or no oral sex partners in their lifetimes, with only 1.5 per cent of them getting an oral HPV infection, which rises to four per cent among non-smokers with two to four oral sex partners.
The rate of infection was highest, at 15 per cent, among men who smoked and had five or more oral sex partners.
Researchers analysed data from 13,089 people, aged 20-69, taking part in the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) who had been tested for oral HPV infection.
They used the numbers of oropharyngeal cancer cases and deaths from US registries to predict the risk of cancer from oral HPV infection.
Study: 1 in 9 U.S. men infected with oral HPV -- which raises their risk for certain head, neck, and throat cancers.
TEXT:
Men who smoke and have had five or more oral sex partners are at the greatest risk of developing a type of head and neck cancer triggered by the human papilloma virus (HPV), according to new US research.

Although the research, published in journal Annals of Oncology, shows that risk remains low, with only 0.7 per cent of all men to ever develop oropharyngeal cancer in their lifetimes.

Among men, the lowest risk group were those who had one or no oral sex partners in their lifetimes, with only 1.5 per cent of them getting an oral HPV infection, which rises to four per cent among non-smokers with two to four oral sex partners.

Human papilloma virus (HPV), a sexually-transmitted virus is a leading cause of throat cancer & spreads from person to person via oral sex https://t.co/G6qthIayAU â€” Dr Elizabeth Kimani (@Liz_Kimani) October 1, 2017

Risk of infection rose further among men who smoked and had two to four oral sex partners, with a prevalence of 7.1 per cent, rising to 7.4 per cent among those who did not smoke but who had five or more oral sex partners.

The rate of infection was highest, at 15 per cent, among men who smoked and had five or more oral sex partners.

Men: Remember you can get the vaccine for HPV and have it be really effective if you're under 26 https://t.co/IExhQfHI3q â€” Kim Kardafrican (@wstafrican) October 18, 2017

The risk was much lower among women, anyone who did not smoke, and people who had less than five oral sex partners in their lifetimes.

Researchers analysed data from 13,089 people, aged 20-69, taking part in the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) who had been tested for oral HPV infection.

They used the numbers of oropharyngeal cancer cases and deaths from US registries to predict the risk of cancer from oral HPV infection.

It was found women who had one or no oral sex partners during their lifetimes had the lowest prevalence of oral infection with cancer-causing types of HPV, with 1.8 per cent of smokers infected, and 0.5 per cent of non-smokers.

Study: 1 in 9 U.S. men infected with oral HPV -- which raises their risk for certain head, neck, and throat cancers. https://t.co/MYCtott996 pic.twitter.com/Aj3AkGlKeg â€” WebMD (@WebMD) October 18, 2017

There are over 100 different kinds of HPV but only a few are known to cause cancer; infection with HPV 16 or 18 is already known to trigger most cervical cancer, and HPV16 also causes most oropharyngeal cancer.

Currently there are no tests that can be used for screening people for oropharyngeal cancer. While incidence remains relatively low it is predicted to overtake cervical cancer by 2020, making screening for at risk patients important, says Dr Amber D'Souza at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health and one of the authors of the study.

"It would be useful to be able to identify healthy people who are most at risk of developing oropharyngeal cancer in order to inform potential screening strategies, if effective screening tests could be developed," Dr D'Souza said.
TITLE: Oral Sex With Multiple Partners Puts Men At Highest Risk Of HPV-Related Cancer

TEXT:
Katie Price has hit out at Olivia Attwood claiming she is â€œas badâ€ as boyfriend Chris Hughes, as their public feud rumbles on.

Pricey is currently locked in a war of words with former â€˜Love Islandâ€™ contestant Chris, after he published a series of flirty messages sheâ€™d sent him.

He branded Katie a â€œrotten piece of s***tâ€ in a furious online rant earlier this week, after Katie apparently revealed alleged responses from him to The Sun. But Katie has now turned her attention to his girlfriend.

Tim P. Whitby via Getty Images Katie Price

Speaking to HuffPost UKâ€™s Matt Bagwell on an episode of â€˜BUILDâ€™, Katie claimed she had sent Olivia various replies Chris had sent to her messages.

â€œSheâ€™s just as bad,â€ Katie said. â€œSheâ€™s piped on about me as well.

â€œIâ€™ve messaged her and said, â€™Look, hereâ€™s the messages,â€² and sent her a couple, but heâ€™s obviously lied to her.â€

She continued: â€œAll Iâ€™m going to say is, if youâ€™re going to be in the media, and youâ€™ve just started, always take advice from people who have been in it longer. Sometimes you think you know better? Do it.â€

Joe Maher via Getty Images Chris Hughes and Olivia Attwood

Comparing Chris to her former lover Gareth Gates, who categorically denied having a relationship with Katie for years before he eventually admitted to it, Katie said: â€œLook at Gareth Gates, he lied. He lied and said nothing happened, and then as soon as it came out, his career went downhill.

â€œI donâ€™t need to use other people to raise my profile. I donâ€™t need to do anything. But what I wonâ€™t be called is a liar. And when I can prove it.â€

While Katie has shown the alleged responses from Chris to Sun journalists, she has so far refrained from making them public - something which she insists she wonâ€™t be doing.

â€œI donâ€™t have to put the messages out to prove nothing,â€ she said.

â€œIâ€™d show anyone but I donâ€™t have to physically put them out because it puts me in the same situation as them.

â€œHe should just drop it and move on. Iâ€™m so over it myself.â€

Rex Chris and Katie met on 'Loose Women'

She added: â€œI just wish Chris would leave it. Who actually cares? I actually donâ€™t care if heâ€™s sent me a message or not. I donâ€™t care, but just donâ€™t call me a liar when I can prove not.

â€œObviously when you keep piping on about it, it shows that youâ€™re guilty.â€

Katie first met Chris when he appeared as a guest on â€˜Loose Womenâ€™ earlier this year, announcing on the show prior to his arrival that she wanted him to be her â€œnext husband.â€

In his furious Twitter tirade against the star earlier this week, Chris maintained he hadnâ€™t responded to Katieâ€™s messages, adding media lawyers would â€œf*** her upâ€.

Tim P. Whitby via Getty Images Katie made an appearance on 'BUILD'

â€œKatie Price youâ€™re a piece of rotten shit,â€ he raged.â€œI couldnâ€™t give a fuck about you. Be a mother, be something respectful for everyoneâ€™s sake.

â€œI showed your true colours, you couldnâ€™t live with it. You have 52 screenshots on Snapshchat since I humiliated you? Comical.

â€œIâ€™ve got my whole account history from Snapchat and media lawyer will fuck you up. No one deserves your shit, and I ainâ€™t one to take it. You fuck lives. You have MY number, you can see I havenâ€™t sent you shit. Youâ€™re washed up and you stink.â€

Chris later deleted the tweet, because he felt the language he had used was â€œdisrespectfulâ€ to his younger fans, but maintained he had â€œmeant everythingâ€ heâ€™d said.

Watch the full â€˜BUILDâ€™ interview with Katie Price in the video below, where she also ignited her most random celebrity feud to date...

Katie Price photocalls in pictures
TITLE: Katie Price Slams Olivia Attwood As Chris Hughes Feud Takes A Fresh Turn

SUMMARY:
Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption The Speaker told the government, following the latest Opposition Day vote: Don't pretend you didn't loseStill no sign of the eagerly-anticipated Commons committee of the whole House debates on the EU (Withdrawal) Bill - the mission-critical Brexit measure previously known as the Great Repeal Bill.
There's plenty to chew on, with the latest amendment paper running to 146 pages, covering more than 300 amendments and 50 new clauses - and the longer the delay, the more new proposals to rewrite this crucial bill arrive.
And the delay also allows MPs, particularly "soft Brexit" supporters to examine rival amendments and condense around the ones which command the widest support.
While all that goes on, offstage, the timetable for Commons Chamber is devoted to a mix of uncontroversial technical legislation (Smart Meters and Self-Drive Cars this week), backbench debates and Opposition debates.
Opposition debates highlighted
TEXT:
Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption The Speaker told the government, following the latest Opposition Day vote: Don't pretend you didn't lose

Still no sign of the eagerly-anticipated Commons committee of the whole House debates on the EU (Withdrawal) Bill - the mission-critical Brexit measure previously known as the Great Repeal Bill.

Westminster rumour suggests the planned eight committee-stage days will not begin until after the November half-term (although an alternative rumour suggests maybe one committee day will be scheduled to allow the government whips to test the waters) and that MPs will then have to yomp through two or three days a week of detailed debate, until the bill is done.

There's plenty to chew on, with the latest amendment paper running to 146 pages, covering more than 300 amendments and 50 new clauses - and the longer the delay, the more new proposals to rewrite this crucial bill arrive.

And the delay also allows MPs, particularly "soft Brexit" supporters to examine rival amendments and condense around the ones which command the widest support.

While all that goes on, offstage, the timetable for Commons Chamber is devoted to a mix of uncontroversial technical legislation (Smart Meters and Self-Drive Cars this week), backbench debates and Opposition debates.

Opposition debates highlighted
TITLE: Mark D'Arcy

Â« Câ€™est un drame, parce que câ€™est dâ€™abord la perte dâ€™une vie humaine. Mais dÃ¨s que vous parliez dâ€™agriculture, vous constatiez combien il Ã©tait passionnÃ©! Ses fromages au lait cru, dont Le Gaulois de Portneuf, Ã©taient exceptionnels, irremplaÃ§ables. Mais le mal Ã©tait fait, le QuÃ©bec ne compte plus aujourdâ€™hui, avec le dÃ©part de Rudy Ducreux, que quatre ou cinq fromagers au lait cru, selon Normand CÃ´tÃ©, prÃ©sident de lâ€™Association des fromagers artisans du QuÃ©bec, qui regroupe une trentaine de membres.

Parmi les pays dÃ©veloppÃ©s, la France sâ€™est toutefois dotÃ©e en 2013 dâ€™un Observatoire national du suicide qui dÃ©nombre 417 suicides chez les hommes agriculteurs entre 2007 Ã  2009, surtout dans les Ã©levages de bovins.



Rudy Ducreux, lâ€™arbre qui cache la forÃªt?



Notre enquÃªte rÃ©vÃ¨le cependant que le phÃ©nomÃ¨ne du suicide des agriculteurs existe bel et bien dans la campagne quÃ©bÃ©coise. Parlez-en Ã  Laurier Gauthier, un voisin de Rudy Ducreux. Il venait de sâ€™acheter une Cadillac. Un bon matin, on apprend quâ€™il sâ€™Ã©tait tirÃ© un coup de 22 en arriÃ¨re des oreilles. Surprise totale Â». SUMMARY:
The 21st and 22nd of October is the weekend that Australia will host over 20,000 garage sales around the country as part of the national Garage Sale Trail.
Now in its seventh year, the award winning sustainability and community campaign sees homes, community groups, and schools band together to de-clutter, promote up-cycling and raise money for charity.
"Every year the campaign has grown from strength to strength with this year being the biggest year in our history and the most garage sales ever held on one weekend in Australia -- or any country in the world!"
Darryl Nichols, co-founder of the Garage Sale Trail said in a brand statement.
If you're in Sydney, event expert and designer Alex Zabotto-Bentley is holding a garage sale, letting go of many of his props used on his projects and in photoshoots.
TEXT:
No plans this weekend? Or maybe you're in the market for a new chest of drawers? Good news! The 21st and 22nd of October is the weekend that Australia will host over 20,000 garage sales around the country as part of the national Garage Sale Trail.

Now in its seventh year, the award winning sustainability and community campaign sees homes, community groups, and schools band together to de-clutter, promote up-cycling and raise money for charity.

"Every year the campaign has grown from strength to strength with this year being the biggest year in our history and the most garage sales ever held on one weekend in Australia -- or any country in the world!" Darryl Nichols, co-founder of the Garage Sale Trail said in a brand statement.

If you're in Sydney, event expert and designer Alex Zabotto-Bentley is holding a garage sale, letting go of many of his props used on his projects and in photoshoots.

There's countless other very cool sales happening around the country so if you're driving or wandering around your neighbourhood and see a bunch of your neighbours selling their old wares, you now know why.
TITLE: Garage Sale Trail: Australia Is Having A Giant Garage Sale This Weekend

TEXT:
In the wake of allegations facing Harvey Weinstein, women are coming forward to share experiences of sexual assault and harassment to show how rape culture permeates all areas of society.

The #MeToo hashtag has encouraged women from across the world to open up about very personal, and difficult, experiences. And while itâ€™s powerful to share stories to show the gravity of the problem, many have said survivors shouldnâ€™t feel pressured to share their stories so publicly and we should be focusing on perpetrators rather than victims.

Continuing this conversation, Leena Norms, from London, raised an important point about the dangers of dismissing our own sexual harassment experiences as trivial compared to othersâ€™.

I have been sitting on my #MeToo contributions all day because dismissing my experiences of harassment as 'not that bad' is second nature â€” Leena Norms (@leenanorms) October 16, 2017

Call me Suburban Sally, I've never been raped and never had anything happen to me that the police would 'file a report for' - â€” Leena Norms (@leenanorms) October 16, 2017

Leena said she decided not to share her own stories of sexual harassment because she had dismissed her own experiences as â€˜not [being] that badâ€™.

But she then went on to describe her own experiences, which ranged from being subjected to vulgar language in the street, to being groped, to having men threaten to kill or rape her.

She explained that she thought she had â€œgot off the lightestâ€ because her experiences were nowhere near as bad as her friends. But the reality is, all accounts of harassment and abuse are valid. They should not be swept under the carpet.

And the worst part is I STILL DO NOT THINK THIS IS A BIG DEAL. I'd say out of most of my friends I've got off the lightest â€” Leena Norms (@leenanorms) October 16, 2017

I would imagine that there's a lot of women who don't want to drain the short attention span the world has for the subject 'harassment' - â€” Leena Norms (@leenanorms) October 16, 2017

- by mentioning these things we've been taught to filter as 'normal'. We do it out of care for those who have had 'worse' - â€” Leena Norms (@leenanorms) October 16, 2017

Her admission just goes to show how sexual harassment is the norm for a lot of women. Women who believe, deep down, that their experiences arenâ€™t shocking enough or awful enough to be shared. Women who believe it would detract away from more serious offences, where others have been assaulted or raped.

But why do women feel forced to remain silent and, dare we say it, feel guilty of admitting theyâ€™ve experienced such awful treatment?

â€œWomen are socialised to accept these experiences as normal because they are so commonplace, we downplay them as â€˜not a big dealâ€™ because others have have had worse experiences,â€ Caitlin Roper, campaigner for Collective Shout, tells HuffPost UK.

â€œThe reality is these experiences are shared by all women. They are female experiences. They exist on a spectrum of male violence, with sexist jokes and normalised objectification of women on one end and rape and murder on the other.â€

The very fact that the issue is so endemic in society makes it very difficult for women to come out and say it happened to them.

â€œItâ€™s a very difficult thing to â€˜come outâ€™ as a survivor, and much more so in such a public way on social media,â€ Caitlin explains.

â€œWe know how women are treated for sharing their stories of sexual assault and the hostility and scrutiny they are subjected to, at a time when they desperately need to be believed, validated and supported.

â€œWomen are not obligated to share their stories and to publicly recall their most traumatic experiences.â€

The onus is still on women to relive experiences, but the problem with this way of thinking is that it can be triggering (more on that here) and painful for those who feel torn between wanting to share their story and, in the process, having to relive a nightmare.

Sophie Walker, leader of the Womenâ€™s Equality Party, acknowledges that while speaking out is important, holding women accountable for this means weâ€™re all completely ignoring â€œthe massive power imbalance that has created such systemic abuseâ€.

â€œRemember that in the case of Weinstein and many others this was largely acknowledged as an â€˜open secretâ€™ for years because so many other people, including other powerful men, knew or suspected what was going on,â€ she tells HuffPost UK.

â€œA problem this big needs a political response and, in the meantime, stronger protection for women who do make a complaint.â€

Men play a huge role in tackling the problem. Thatâ€™s why executive producer and feminist Liz Plank coined the hashtag #HimThough to move the focus away from women having to share their stories and onto men. â€œI was sexually harassed, physically and verbally attacked,â€ she tweeted. â€œBut what about him though? Who decided it was womenâ€™s job to fix men?â€ Samantha Rennie, executive director at Rosa, a charitable fund set up to support initiatives that benefit women, says men must have a deeper understanding of what sexual harassment and assault actually is before things can change. â€œIt can be anything from unsolicited comments about body and appearance all the way up to rape,â€ she explains. â€œIn addition, it shouldnâ€™t only be an issue if it happens to your wife or your daughter; we all have to fight this until hashtags like #metoo are no longer necessary.â€

As a society, we must also move away from â€œtrivialising sexual harassment as â€˜banterâ€™ or an unfortunate come-onâ€, says Sophie Walker from the Womenâ€™s Equality Party.

And finally, we need to stop victim-blaming. Samantha, from Rosa UK, explains: â€œIt can be incredibly difficult for women who have experienced sexual harassment, abuse or assault to speak out because we live in a world that consistently questions the lived experiences of women and does its best to find fault with the survivor.

â€œQuestions like â€˜What was she wearing?â€™, â€˜Why was she alone with him?â€™ only serve to blame women for the actions of an abuser.â€

Useful helplines and websites:
TITLE: #MeToo: All Sexual Harassment Experiences Are Worth Reporting, But Don't Feel Pressured To Share

SUMMARY:
Les clÃ©s pour faire le bon choixAvec la flat tax Ã  30%, le forfait sera donc le mÃªme pour tous les produits ou presque (voir dÃ©tails ci-dessous).
Mais attention, il ne sera pas possible de choisir la flat tax et les prÃ©lÃ¨vements traditionnels Ã  la carte, en fonction du type d'Ã©pargne, ce sera tout ou rien.
Ã€ l'exception des personnes non assujetties Ã  l'impÃ´t sur le revenu la Flat Tax sera toujours plus intÃ©ressante."
Le deuxiÃ¨me montre la fiscalitÃ© lorsque l'on opte pour le barÃ¨me de l'impÃ´t sur le revenu.
Le contribuable pourra opter entre le barÃ¨me Ã  l'impÃ´t sur le revenu et la fameuse taxe forfaitaire unique.
TEXT:
FINANCE - L'AssemblÃ©e a donnÃ© son feu vert dans la soirÃ©e du 19 octobre Ã  une "flat tax" de 30% sur les revenus du capital, aprÃ¨s des dÃ©bats tendus autour des prises de parole sur cette mesure prÃ©sentÃ©e comme une "rÃ©volution fiscale" par le gouvernement, mais comme un "cadeau aux riches" par la gauche.

Le ministre de l'Economie Bruno Le Maire a dÃ©fendu cette disposition, l'une des plus controversÃ©es du budget 2018, comme Ã©tant "sans aucun doute la vraie rÃ©volution fiscale de ce projet de loi de finances et probablement ce qui amÃ©liorera le plus le financement, la croissance et l'emploi dans notre pays".

Et pour vos Ã©conomies, s'agit-il aussi d'une rÃ©volution? Pas nÃ©cessairement, d'autant qu'anciens et nouveau rÃ©gimes fiscaux vont cohabiter.

Aujourd'hui, la plupart des produits d'Ã©pargne sont soumis Ã  deux types de fiscalitÃ© au choix. Soit les prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux (CSG) et l'intÃ©gration des intÃ©rÃªts au calcul de l'impÃ´t sur le revenu, soit un forfait fixe, diffÃ©rent d'un produit Ã  l'autre. Charge Ã  chacun de calculer ce qui lui est le plus avantageux.

Les clÃ©s pour faire le bon choix

Avec la flat tax Ã  30%, le forfait sera donc le mÃªme pour tous les produits ou presque (voir dÃ©tails ci-dessous). Mais les particuliers auront toujours la possibilitÃ© d'opter pour les prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux et l'impÃ´t sur le revenu. Le cas de l'assurance-vie, plus compliquÃ©, restera un peu Ã  part.

"Dans certains cas trÃ¨s limitÃ©s, pour les gens qui ne payent pas ou peu d'impÃ´ts, la flat tax ne sera pas intÃ©ressante", explique l'Ã©conomiste Philippe Crevel, directeur du Cercle des Ã©pargnants. Mais attention, il ne sera pas possible de choisir la flat tax et les prÃ©lÃ¨vements traditionnels Ã  la carte, en fonction du type d'Ã©pargne, ce sera tout ou rien.

Livret A, assurance-vie, dividendes... L'Ã©conomiste Philippe Crevel, directeur du Cercle des Ã©pargnants, a donnÃ© aux HuffPost les clÃ©s pour faire le bon choix.

Livret A, LDDS, Livret jeune, Livret populaire

Aucun changement, ces livrets restent exonÃ©rÃ©s d'impÃ´t sur le revenu et de prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux. La flat tax ne s'y appliquera pas.

Livrets bancaires et produits de taux sur un compte titre

Ce sont les livrets B, ces livrets qui servent quand le livret A est plein. Ils fonctionnent de la mÃªme maniÃ¨re, mais sont fiscalisÃ©s. Les fonds composÃ©s d'obligations logÃ©s dans des comptes titres concernent surtout les professionnels qui y font fructifier leur trÃ©sorerie Ã  court terme, rarement les particuliers.

Philippe Crevel: "La Flat Tax s'appliquera Ã  compter du 1er janvier 2018. Actuellement, les Ã©pargnants avaient le choix entre le barÃ¨me de l'impÃ´t sur le revenu ou, sous certaines conditions, Ã  un prÃ©lÃ¨vement libÃ©ratoire de 24 %.

Dans les deux cas, s'ajoutaient les prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux Ã  hauteur de 15,5 % (17,2 % Ã  compter du 1er janvier 2018).

Ã€ l'exception des personnes non assujetties Ã  l'impÃ´t sur le revenu la Flat Tax sera toujours plus intÃ©ressante."

Le Plan d'Ã‰pargne Logement

La Flat Tax s'appliquera pour les plans ouverts Ã  compter du 1er janvier 2018. Ceux qui veulent y Ã©chapper ont donc jusqu'au 31 dÃ©cembre pour ouvrir un compte.

Elle concernera Ã©galement les plans de plus de 12 ans. Les anciens plans resteront soumis aux prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux (15,5% jusqu'au 31 dÃ©cembre 2017 puis 17,2%). Pour les plans ouverts depuis le 1er aoÃ»t 2016, le taux de rendement est de 1 %.

De ce fait, aprÃ¨s Flat Tax, le rendement net sera de 0,7 % contre 0,83 % pour les plans qui seront souscrits avant le 1er janvier 2018 (avec un taux de prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux Ã  17,2 %).

L'Assurance-vie

Le rÃ©gime fiscal de l'assurance-vie est le plus complexe. Le systÃ¨me actuel et le nouveau continueront de coexister aprÃ¨s le 1er janvier 2018, et quelle que soit l'option retenue, il varie en fonction de la durÃ©e de dÃ©tention du contrat.

Ainsi, les versements effectuÃ©s avant le 31 dÃ©cembre resteront soumis au rÃ©gime actuel (prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux +prÃ©lÃ¨vement libÃ©ratoire 35%, 15% ou 7,5 % selon l'anciennetÃ© du contrat).

Les versements intervenant aprÃ¨s le 1er janvier 2018 et dÃ©passant 150.000 euros pour un cÃ©libataire ou 300.000 euros pour un couple seront soumis Ã  la Flat Tax, libre Ã  l'assurÃ© d'opter pour le barÃ¨me de l'impÃ´t sur le revenu malgrÃ© tout.

Les versements infÃ©rieurs Ã  ces seuils resteront soumis au rÃ©gime actuel, sachant que les prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux passeront Ã  17,2% au 1er janvier 2018, avec la hausse de la CSG de 1,7% voulue par Macron.

Voici les deux tableaux qui rÃ©sument la fiscalitÃ© appliquÃ©e quand on retire tout ou partie des fonds de son contrat. Le premier montre la fiscalitÃ© de rÃ©gime dit libÃ©ratoire additionnÃ©e aux prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux. Le deuxiÃ¨me montre la fiscalitÃ© lorsque l'on opte pour le barÃ¨me de l'impÃ´t sur le revenu.

Le Plan d'Ã‰pargne en Actions

Son rÃ©gime ne sera pas modifiÃ©, la fiscalitÃ© est allÃ©gÃ©e pour l'investissement dans des actions franÃ§aises ou europÃ©ennes. Mais, il sera concurrencÃ© par les comptes titres qui seront Ã  la Flat Tax.

Les dividendes

La Flat Tax s'applique aux dividendes des actions. Le contribuable pourra opter entre le barÃ¨me Ã  l'impÃ´t sur le revenu et la fameuse taxe forfaitaire unique.

Dans le premier cas, il doit acquitter les prÃ©lÃ¨vements sociaux mais il bÃ©nÃ©ficie d'un abattement de 40%. Dans le second cas, le montant des dividendes sera amputÃ© de 30 %.

Ã€ partir d'un taux d'imposition de 30%, la Flat Tax est plus intÃ©ressante.

Ã€ voir Ã©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Ce que la flat tax va changer pour votre Livret A, LDD, PEL, Assurance-vie...

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTCHENNAI -- Apologizing for supporting demonetisation, actor Kamal Hassan said he will again salute Prime Minister Narendra Modi if he also accepts that the note ban was a mistake.
Hassan said Modi should not be stubborn in arguing that the rabbit he had caught has three legs.
On his initial support for the demonetisation of 1,000 and 500 rupee notes, Hassan said he had welcomed the move and tweeted that it should be supported regardless of party affiliation.
The actor said his friends and those who know economics had called him and criticised his support for demonetisation.
Hassan said he later thought that demonetisation was good but the manner in which it was implemented was wrong.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

CHENNAI -- Apologizing for supporting demonetisation, actor Kamal Hassan said he will again salute Prime Minister Narendra Modi if he also accepts that the note ban was a mistake.

In an article in the Tamil magazine Anandavikatan, the actor said accepting and correcting mistakes is a marker for great leaders which Mahatma Gandhi was able to do.

Hassan said Modi should not be stubborn in arguing that the rabbit he had caught has three legs.

On his initial support for the demonetisation of 1,000 and 500 rupee notes, Hassan said he had welcomed the move and tweeted that it should be supported regardless of party affiliation.

"I thought people should bear with minor irritants in the goal to eradicate black money," he wrote.

The actor said his friends and those who know economics had called him and criticised his support for demonetisation.

Hassan said he later thought that demonetisation was good but the manner in which it was implemented was wrong.

He said now there were voices saying demonetisation was a deception and the weak response from the government raises serious doubts about the scheme.
TITLE: Kamal Hassan Retracts Support For Demonetisation, Calls It A Mistake
