SUMMARY:
It was Tenbrink who allegedly jumped out of a silver Jeep after an argument with protesters and produced a handgun.
â€œIâ€™m going to fucking kill you,â€ Tenbrink reportedly yelled at the protesters, while the Fears brothers encouraged him to shoot.
Tyler TenbrinkTenbrink, the man who fired the gun, is a white supremacist from Richmond, Texas.
In June, Tenbrink participated in a white supremacist rally at the Texas State Capitol building in Austin, according to the ADL.
After the Charlottesville rally, Fears posted a 13-minute-long statement on YouTube.
TEXT:
GAINESVILLE, Fla. â€• About five hours before his companion allegedly fired a bullet toward several protesters, and a day before police charged him with attempted homicide, Colton Fears, in an interview with HuffPost, laid out the grievances that had brought him to town. â€œBasically, Iâ€™m just fed up with the fact that Iâ€™m cis-gendered, Iâ€™m a white male, and I lean right, towards the Republican side,â€ said Fears, 28, wearing a pin of the 3rd SS Panzer Division Totenkopf of the Waffen-SS. â€œAnd I get demonized if I donâ€™t accept certain things.â€

According to the Anti-Defamation League, Colton Fears is the â€œleast activeâ€ of the three Texas men charged in Thursdayâ€™s shooting, which happened after Richard Spencerâ€™s speech at the University of Florida. Fearsâ€™ brother, William, 30, and Tyler Tenbrink, 28, were also charged. It was Tenbrink who allegedly jumped out of a silver Jeep after an argument with protesters and produced a handgun. â€œIâ€™m going to fucking kill you,â€ Tenbrink reportedly yelled at the protesters, while the Fears brothers encouraged him to shoot.

Tenbrink popped off a single round that missed his targets and hit a building behind them, then got back in the Jeep and fled. One of the victims reported the Jeepâ€™s vehicle tag number to police. Officers from three different law enforcement units caught up with the trio later that evening on Interstate 75 and took them into custody.

Even before their arrest, the trio were known quantities â€• Tenbrink and William Fears in particular. They are fairly representative specimens of the sort of flotsam that drifts through the the so-called â€œalt-rightâ€ and, increasingly, trails in the wake of any white nationalist chieftain, even one as snooty as Spencer. They are, in short, surly groupies for whiteness. Hereâ€™s what we know about them.

Tyler Tenbrink

Tenbrink, the man who fired the gun, is a white supremacist from Richmond, Texas. He told the Washington Post that he came to Spencerâ€™s Gainesville speech because he received threats from the â€œradical leftâ€ after he was spotted at the Unite The Right rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. But Tenbrink had been active in the white nationalist scene long before the August gathering.

Chris McGonigal/HuffPost Tyler Tenbrink is photographed during protests.

In June, Tenbrink participated in a white supremacist rally at the Texas State Capitol building in Austin, according to the ADL. The ADL also identified Tenbrink at another Richard Spencer speech at Texas A&M University last December, a white supremacist protest in front of the Houston ADL offices last October, a private event organized by the neo-Nazi Aryan Renaissance Society last September, and a white supremacist protest in front of the Houston NAACP office last August.

Tenbrink told the Post that all he cares about are the â€œ14 words,â€ a reference to the popular white supremacist slogan: â€œWe must secure the existence of our people and a future for white children.â€

Tenbrink pled guilty to a felony assault charge in Texas in 2014. That means he now faces additional charges of possession of a firearm by a convicted felon, the Gainesville Police Department wrote in a statement.

William Fears

William Fears, from Pasadena, Texas, claims he didnâ€™t even know about the alt-right until Hillary Clinton condemned the movement in a campaign speech last August, at which point his radicalization journey began. By December, he was turning up at Spencerâ€™s speaking events, including one at Texas A&M where Fears described himself as â€mainly an Internet troll.â€

But Fears was more than a troll. In 2009, he pleaded guilty to aggravated kidnapping after he abducted an 18-year-old female University of Texas at Tyler student at knifepoint and â€œwounded her several times.â€ He has also been convicted of criminal trespassing and possession of a controlled substance. It was while he was incarcerated, he told the Post, that he had become racially aware.

â€œI donâ€™t think any race experiences racism in the modern world the way that white people do in a jail,â€ he said. â€œIn jail, whites come last.â€

In May, Fears, who now works in construction, crashed a May Day rally with other neo-Nazis and reportedly assaulted a man. In June, he antagonized members of the Oath Keepers, a far-right militia movement, at a rally in Houston until one of them put him in a chokehold. In August, he showed up in Charlottesville to brawl in a helmet, gas mask and goggles, waving a white nationalist flag and shouting, â€œShoot! Fire the first shot of the race war!â€ In September, he and other neo-Nazis tried to provoke anarchists at a Houston book fair to violence.

â€œNazi is like the N-word for white people,â€ says Fears. â€œAnd I just embrace it.â€

Colton Fears

Before coming to Spencerâ€™s Gainesville speech, Colton Fears participated in the Charlottesville rally and an April counter-protest of a Houston Socialist Movement event as part of a group of white supremacists, which included neo-Nazis and members of the alt-right, the ADL said.

After the Charlottesville rally, Fears posted a 13-minute-long statement on YouTube. He congratulated himself for attending the event, lamented the mainstream mediaâ€™s attack on Southern heritage, and complained bitterly about being doxxed. He made no mention of Heather Heyer, the 32-year-old protester who was killed at the rally.

Chris McGonigal/HuffPost Colton Fears was interviewed by HuffPost before the protests started.

In his interview with HuffPost, Fears tried to distance himself a little from the scene around him. He said of Richard Spencer, â€œI agree with like 75 percent of his â€• heâ€™s not â€• heâ€™s kind of a scam artist, in my opinion.â€ Asked if he identified as alt-right, he said: â€œI try and deny identity politics. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m not wearing a white polo and all that stuff.â€ But he also served up a word salad of white grievance: â€œLike, OK, for one thing, say, you know, gay marriage, thatâ€™s cool, whatever, you know, except â€” thatâ€™s fine, Iâ€™m cool with it â€” well, then, whatâ€™s after that? The next step? This whole transgender movement, right? Well, if you donâ€™t accept that, youâ€™re a bigot, this and that. Well, that all goes hand in hand with being a white person.â€
TITLE: These Are The Three Richard Spencer Fans Arrested For Attempted Homicide In Gainesville

TEXT:
"Wir gegen den Rest der Welt": Wie mein schwerbehinderter Sohn und ich das Pflegesystem revolutionieren wollen UnhÃ¶flichkeit, VerstÃ¤ndnislosigkeit, fehlendes MitgefÃ¼hl, und keinerlei Kommunikation auf AugenhÃ¶he: So wÃ¼rde ich die Zusammenarbeit mit den Beamten der deutschen SozialÃ¤mter beschreiben. U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders attends a news conference at the U.S. Capitol on Oct. 4, 2017 in Washington, D.C.Bernie Sanders is coming to Canada.
The U.S. senator, who unveiled his "Medicare For All" bill last month, will speak about health care at a University of Toronto event on Oct. 29.
The doctor rose to Internet fame in 2014 after a clip of her response at a U.S. Senate subcommittee looking at health care systems around the world went viral.

Dr. Danielle Martin (left) watches as Sen. Bernie Sanders speaks during his event to introduce the Medicare for All Act of 2017 on Sept. 13, 2017.
TEXT:
U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders attends a news conference at the U.S. Capitol on Oct. 4, 2017 in Washington, D.C.

Bernie Sanders is coming to Canada.

The U.S. senator, who unveiled his "Medicare For All" bill last month, will speak about health care at a University of Toronto event on Oct. 29.

He'll be joined by Canadian physician Danielle Martin. The doctor rose to Internet fame in 2014 after a clip of her response at a U.S. Senate subcommittee looking at health care systems around the world went viral. She stood behind Sanders when he introduced his health care act in September.

Dr. Danielle Martin (left) watches as Sen. Bernie Sanders speaks during his event to introduce the Medicare for All Act of 2017 on Sept. 13, 2017.

Sanders, who ran against Hillary Clinton last year for the Democratic presidential nomination, will speak about his bill and touch on what the U.S. can learn from Canada on health care.

The Broadbent Institute, one of the organizers of the event, will be livestreaming the talk, for people who want to feel the bern in the comfort of their own home.

With a file from Zi-Ann Lum

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Bernie Sanders' Toronto Event To Focus On Health Care

Oserons-nous un jour, dans une mÃªme approche, envisager le politique et la poÃ©sie, l'organisation sociale et l'onirisme, la crÃ©ation, l'humour, la passion et le dÃ©sir? Est-elle envisageable cette vocation anarchiste et quelle mÃ©thode emprunter? Il n'y en a peut-Ãªtre pas; pas de recette, pas de programme, pas de marche Ã  suivre. Il y a l'expÃ©rience, les actes, les Ã©changes et une maniÃ¨re d'Ãªtre au monde, sensible et humaniste. Il faudrait faire un pas de cÃ´tÃ© et penser hors des structures politiques traditionnelles; c'est ce que m'a appris Patrick Schindler, membre de la FÃ©dÃ©ration Anarchiste, amoureux amusÃ© et passionnÃ©, militant depuis toujours. Nous nous sommes donnÃ©s rendez-vous par une aprÃ¨s-midi ensoleillÃ©e, sur une terrasse toute proche du bois de Vincennes.

"J'aime beaucoup cet endroit, le bois de Vincennes, c'est la derniÃ¨re trace de forÃªt primaire dans Paris et, depuis l'enfance, j'y ai un rapport affectif. Tu vas me prendre en photo et tu sais que j'en ai horreur, alors j'ai besoin de ce lien. Quand j'Ã©tais mÃ´me, c'Ã©tait mon terrain d'aventure et une maniÃ¨re de fuir la famille, aujourd'hui c'est le lieu pour me soigner de la ville. Je suis profondÃ©ment attachÃ© Ã  la nature. En septembre il y a eu une marÃ©e noire en GrÃ¨ce dont on a trÃ¨s peu entendu parler. J'y Ã©tais et je me souviens avoir vu la merde humaine dÃ©ferler, une masse d'ordures qui se dÃ©verse; tu as dÃ©jÃ  vu des oiseaux dans du mazout? Tout souffre et crÃ¨ve. Je ne fais pas de diffÃ©rence entre la dÃ©solation humaine et animale; on construit des murs autour des hommes et on torture et cache les animaux dans des barquettes et des usines Ã  viande, ou alors on les domestique, on les sacralise. Quand on discute de la consommation de viande, je prÃ©fÃ¨re parler de notre rapport au monde qui me semble malsain. Je crois au raisonnable, au local, il faut qu'on rÃ©apprenne Ã  consommer ce dont on a besoin. Que chacun se prenne en charge et pense Ã  son Ã©chelle, aussi minime soit-elle.

Quand on discute de la consommation de viande, je prÃ©fÃ¨re parler de notre rapport au monde qui me semble malsain. Je crois au raisonnable, au local.

Ce regard participe aux chemins qui mÃ¨nent vers l'anarchie, car il y en a de nombreux. Le mien a Ã©tÃ© principalement politique et intellectuel, avec la poÃ©sie pour boussole.

Je suis l'auteur d'une biographie sur Arthur Rimbaud et d'une autre sur Jean Genet, de Contingent rebelle, un bouquin sur l'Appel des Cent contre le service militaire dans les annÃ©es 70, et je prÃ©pare en ce moment une biographie d'Erika et Klaus, les enfants aÃ®nÃ©s de Thomas Mann, antifascistes convaincus de la premiÃ¨re heure qui s'exilÃ¨rent Ã  l'arrivÃ©e du pouvoir d'Hitler en 33. Je ne suis pas un intello mais je me suis faÃ§onnÃ© ma propre culture, au contact des autres et des bouquins. J'ai cessÃ© aujourd'hui toute activitÃ© salariÃ©e ce qui me laisse tout mon temps pour militer, rÃ©flÃ©chir, me promener et surtout rÃ©aliser enfin ma passion pour le thÃ©Ã¢tre, l'Ã©criture et la mÃ©moire. Ma vie a nÃ©anmoins Ã©tÃ© rythmÃ©e par des tas de mÃ©tiers, je connais le travail et les boulots de merde. J'ai Ã©tÃ© serveur, coursier, homme de mÃ©nage, infirmier psy, journaliste, steward, j'ai aussi fait de l'intÃ©rim.

Ma vie a Ã©tÃ© rythmÃ©e par des tas de mÃ©tiers, je connais les boulots de merde. J'ai Ã©tÃ© serveur, coursier, homme de mÃ©nage, infirmier psy, journaliste, steward, j'ai fait de l'intÃ©rim.

Politiquement, le communisme ne me correspondait pas car j'ai horreur de la rigueur autoritaire, par contre je me suis reconnu dans les auteurs anarchistes et le "ni dieu ni maÃ®tre" m'a fait l'effet d'une formule magique. Il y a aussi la cÃ©lÃ¨bre phrase de Proudhon "l'anarchie c'est l'ordre sans le pouvoir". J'ai commencÃ© le militantisme au FHAR (Front Homosexuel d'Action RÃ©volutionnaire) au dÃ©but des annÃ©es 70. Pendant mon service militaire, en 1974, j'Ã©tais l'un des signataires de l'Appel des Cent, un appel rÃ©solument antimilitariste. En 1995 j'ai dÃ©fendu les droits des sans-papiers avec Ras l'Front, nous Ã©tions trÃ¨s actifs et avancions ensemble pour une cause juste, je retrouvais l'essence du militantisme. Je suis sÃ©ropositif depuis 1991; quand Sarkozy est arrivÃ© au pouvoir, Ã§a a Ã©tÃ© un dÃ©clic, je pressentais un massacre pour la santÃ©. La gauche n'avait rien fait et Ã§a allait Ãªtre pire! Il y avait une urgence vitale, je voyais les copains mourir les uns aprÃ¨s les autres. Alors j'ai rejoins Act UP et y ai retrouvÃ© l'esprit soixante-huitard du FHAR, nous avions la solidaritÃ© et l'humour comme meilleure arme pour transcender la peur et avons obtenu de magnifiques victoires. La seule chose qui me gÃªnait, Ã  la rigueur, Ã©tait la prise de dÃ©cision Ã  la majoritÃ© qui n'est pas notre conception de la dÃ©mocratie Ã  la FÃ©dÃ©ration Anarchiste.

J'ai cessÃ© aujourd'hui toute activitÃ© salariÃ©e ce qui me laisse tout mon temps pour militer, rÃ©flÃ©chir, me promener et surtout rÃ©aliser enfin ma passion.

Chez nous, les dÃ©cisions sont prises Ã  l'unanimitÃ©, ce qui signifie que si une personne s'oppose, rien qu'une, on prend le temps de discuter, d'Ã©couter et de convaincre. Nous ne sommes pas pressÃ©s aprÃ¨s tout; d'oÃ¹ vient cette injonction Ã  la vitesse? On sait qu'on a raison, que c'est la meilleure maniÃ¨re de respecter un individu. Il faut accepter que notre fonctionnement est diffÃ©rent mais qu'il est capable de s'adapter, dans de petites cellules, dans les entreprises, et qu'il fonctionne. Chacun de nos groupe est autonome, notre radio -Radio Libertaireâ€“ aussi. Nous repensons les Ã©chelles afin de rendre de l'autonomie aux individus et aux structures. Quand tu as goÃ»tÃ© Ã  cette libertÃ©, constructive et sans chef, c'est bien simple, tu ne peux plus t'en passer.

Une dÃ©mocratie idÃ©ale ne devrait pas comporter de prÃ©sident mais des mandatÃ©s pour la santÃ©, pour la culture et pour l'Ã©ducation par exemple, avec des mandats impÃ©ratifs et rÃ©vocables d'un an. A la moindre dÃ©faillance, celle ou celui qui est en charge du mandat doit dÃ©gager, comprendre qu'il n'a plus rien Ã  foutre dans son rÃ´le. Ainsi il n'y aurait plus de privilÃ¨ges, plus d'enjeux financiers, plus question d'ego. Le mandatÃ© doit rendre compte de son mandat, point barre. Subitement, on verrait beaucoup moins de gens se battre pour la place, nous n'aurions que des personnes compÃ©tentes et responsables. Comment appliquer l'anarchie d'un point de vue politique? Il n'y a pas de rÃ©ponse, pas de solution toute faite. L'anarchie n'a pas de programme politique, mais des artistes, des auteurs, des penseurs, c'est une faÃ§on d'Ãªtre, c'est l'Ã©coute, la prise en compte des dÃ©sirs... AprÃ¨s, on se dÃ©merde, on est capable, j'y crois!

Chez nous, les dÃ©cisions sont prises Ã  l'unanimitÃ©, ce qui signifie que si une personne s'oppose, rien qu'une, on prend le temps de discuter, d'Ã©couter et de convaincre.

Nous avons cependant des principes de base: on est antireligieux et antidogmatiques, que les gens aient des croyances, on s'en fiche, on refuse juste de se faire emmerder par une Bible, par un Coran, ou par une Torah. On est antiracistes, anti-autoritaires, antisexistes. Tout ce qui est communautaire et nationaliste me fait chier. Les black blocs aussi me font chier; casser trois banques c'est pas casser le capitalisme. C'est contre-productif, c'est du spectacle complÃ¨tement intÃ©grÃ©. Rien de rÃ©volutionnaire. On connaÃ®t trÃ¨s bien l'aboutissement de la violence et moi je suis fonciÃ¨rement non violent et pacifiste. Je veux de la vie et du bonheur, rappelez-vous les paroles d'Emma Goldmann: "Si je ne peux pas danser, je ne veux pas prendre part Ã  votre rÃ©volution". Le militantisme c'est de la transmission de valeurs, du partage, et des actes au quotidien. Les expÃ©riences anarchistes, mÃªme si elles n'ont pas encore abouti, ont marquÃ© les esprits. Regarde la Commune de Paris et la guerre d'Espagne quand Barcelone, parmi d'autres, Ã©tait une ville anarchiste!

L'anarchie n'a pas de programme politique, mais des artistes, des auteurs, des penseurs, c'est une faÃ§on d'Ãªtre, c'est l'Ã©coute, la prise en compte des dÃ©sirs...

Nous ne devons pas regarder uniquement vers le passÃ©, notre tort est peut-Ãªtre d'avoir peur de ce qui nous Ã©chappe aujourd'hui, on n'arrive plus Ã  se comprendre avec les jeunes et on ne saisit pas la cÃ©sure qu'il y a entre nous. Pourtant nous aimerions nous adresser Ã  eux, notre message n'a rien perdu en vigueur et en ambition. Les jeunes, vous Ãªtes trop dispersÃ©s, lÃ¢chez vos smartphones pour regarder le rÃ©el, faites l'amour, la rÃ©volution en vraie! De notre cÃ´tÃ©, les anars, nous sommes en retard sur les nouvelles technologies, il faut nous bousculer, nous proposer des initiatives! Profitez en, on n'a certainement pas envie de mourir et on est d'accord pour se transformer. Tout est Ã  faire, tout est Ã  construire, on est lÃ  et on y croit toujours!"

SUMMARY:
Various packaged vegetable products have been recalled in Canada.
OTTAWA â€” The Canadian Food Inspection Agency says numerous packaged vegetable products have been recalled over concerns about listeria contamination.
The agency says 26 Mann's products, two Compliments products and six Western Family products are affected by the recall.
The items were sold in Ontario and Quebec, and the CFIA says they may have been distributed nationally as well.
Food contaminated with Listeria monocytogenes may not look or smell spoiled, but can still make you sick.
TEXT:
Various packaged vegetable products have been recalled in Canada.

OTTAWA â€” The Canadian Food Inspection Agency says numerous packaged vegetable products have been recalled over concerns about listeria contamination.

The agency says 26 Mann's products, two Compliments products and six Western Family products are affected by the recall.

The items were sold in Ontario and Quebec, and the CFIA says they may have been distributed nationally as well.

See the full recall at CFIA's website.

It says there have been no reported illnesses linked to the consumption of the vegetables.

Food contaminated with Listeria monocytogenes may not look or smell spoiled, but can still make you sick.

Symptoms can include vomiting, nausea, persistent fever, muscle aches, severe headache and neck stiffness.

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Mann's, Compliments, Western Family Packaged Vegetables Recalled In Canada Over Listeria Concern

La preocupaciÃ³n estarÃ­a centrada mÃ¡s en lo polÃ­tico que en los negocios, pues los grandes corporativos o las multinacionales que han trabajado en MÃ©xico por dÃ©cadas "no van a entrar en pÃ¡nico; harÃ¡n una evaluaciÃ³n realista", pero en el Congreso sÃ­ hay una imagen "medio fantasiosa de este paÃ­s", afirmÃ³.

Nadie sabe por quÃ© unos paÃ­ses son mÃ¡s exitosos que otros, pero algo que quisiÃ©ramos ver es que las cosas se asemejen a las historias de Ã©xito asiÃ¡ticas. Corea del Sur, por ejemplo, atravesÃ³ desde hambrunas hasta ser hoy un paÃ­s de primer mundo", explicÃ³.

Pero esto se debiÃ³ a que empezÃ³ a dar un nivel de educaciÃ³n mÃ¡s alto con relaciÃ³n al propio nivel de ingresos de las familias. "He visitado Corea del Sur y MÃ©xico, y lo que he visto es que allÃ¡ preparan a su gente para que estÃ© lista para un mundo global y en MÃ©xico no es asÃ­", subrayÃ³.

DestacÃ³ que ha sido un gran avance la aprobaciÃ³n de las reformas estructurales, pero "no ha sido suficiente".

Respecto a la corrupciÃ³n, dijo que Ã©sta ahoga a cualquier mediana empresa.

Die Situation in Katalonien spitzt sich weiter zu. Weil die Regionalregierung in Barcelona auf einer Abspaltung beharrt, will die Zentralregierung in Madrid nun Artikel 155 der Verfassung in Kraft setzen. Es wÃ¤re das erste Mal seit Inkrafttreten der Verfassung im Jahr 1978.

Artikel zur Einhaltung der spanischen Verfassung

Die mÃ¶glichen Schritte

â–º Einsatz des MilitÃ¤rs: Wie Peter A. Kraus von der UniversitÃ¤t Augsburg "Focus Online" sagte, kÃ¶nnte Madrid das MilitÃ¤r einsetzen, wie schon wÃ¤hrend des Referendums am 1. Oktober. SUMMARY:
June Oh Seo was at the centre of a 12-hour standoff with police.
The man at the centre of a 12-hour stand-off atop a Sydney high-rise unit after his girlfriend's body was found in a laneway below has been charged with murder.
Korean-born tradesman June Oh Seo, 37, was charged with murder in the Hornsby Local Court on Friday morning.
He was originally charged with one count of domestic violence-related assault occasioning actual bodily harm after his girlfriend's body was discovered.
Police carried out interviews with up to 90 people before charging Seo with murder as well.
TEXT:
June Oh Seo was at the centre of a 12-hour standoff with police.

The man at the centre of a 12-hour stand-off atop a Sydney high-rise unit after his girlfriend's body was found in a laneway below has been charged with murder.

The body of Hee Kyung Choi, 34, was found by a passer-by in a lane near the heart of the busy Chatswood shopping and business district on a Monday morning earlier this month.

Korean-born tradesman June Oh Seo, 37, was charged with murder in the Hornsby Local Court on Friday morning.

He was originally charged with one count of domestic violence-related assault occasioning actual bodily harm after his girlfriend's body was discovered. That charge still stands, the court heard on Friday.

Police carried out interviews with up to 90 people before charging Seo with murder as well.

The 37-year-old was scheduled to appear in Hornsby court on Friday morning via video link but is now set to appear in Sydney Central Court in December via video link.
TITLE: June Oh Seo Charged With Murder Of Girlfriend After Chatswood Rooftop Standoff

"Para mÃ­ fue brutal porque no solamente tenÃ­a cÃ¡ncer y me habÃ­a quedado sin mama, sino que ademÃ¡s habÃ­a perdido a mis bebÃ©s y eso me doliÃ³ muchÃ­simo".
"Los doctores estÃ¡n muy espantados con el cÃ¡ncer de mama y quieren meter al protocolo de quimios y radios a todo el mundo".
Aproximadamente 1 de cada 8 mujeres desarrollan cÃ¡ncer de mama y alrededor del 25% de ellas tienen hijos pequeÃ±os cuando sucede.
Con el cÃ¡ncer de mama no existe tal cosa como la prevenciÃ³n: la Ãºnica manera de combatirlo es la detecciÃ³n temprana.
Y para crear la cultura de la detecciÃ³n temprana, no hay mÃ¡s que hablar del tema para que ninguna mujer quede indiferente al mismo.
TEXT:
Un diagnÃ³stico de cÃ¡ncer de mama es avasallador para toda mujer en cualquier etapa de su vida. Sin embargo cuando esta mujer ademÃ¡s se quiere convertir en madre, ya estÃ¡ embarazada (el cÃ¡ncer de seno se diagnostica en aproximadamente 1 de cada 3 mil mujeres embarazadas) o bien tiene ya hijos pequeÃ±os, el reto se vuelve aÃºn mÃ¡s crudo.

Rebeca tenÃ­a 35 aÃ±os cuando se embarazÃ³ por primera vez y durante el primer trimestre de gestaciÃ³n le detectaron microcalcificaciones muy alineadas en una mama. Con el antecedente de que su madre habÃ­a muerto de cÃ¡ncer a los treinta aÃ±os (mismo que le detectaron tambiÃ©n durante un embarazo) los mÃ©dicos supieron que habÃ­a que actuar rÃ¡pido. Sin embargo, meterla a quirÃ³fano para hacer la biopsia implicaba un riesgo de perder el embarazo (gemelar), pero no hacer nada podÃ­a tener como consecuencia que Rebeca perdiera la vida, como pasÃ³ con su madre cuando finalizÃ³ el embarazo de su hermana.

Pocas semanas despuÃ©s detectaron que el embarazo no era viable por lo que tuvieron que practicarle un legrado, seguido por la biopsia que resultÃ³ en un diagnÃ³stico de cÃ¡ncer de mama. "Para mÃ­ fue brutal porque no solamente tenÃ­a cÃ¡ncer y me habÃ­a quedado sin mama, sino que ademÃ¡s habÃ­a perdido a mis bebÃ©s y eso me doliÃ³ muchÃ­simo". Rebeca se concentrÃ³ en resolver el tema del cÃ¡ncer, pues tras la mastectomÃ­a, habÃ­a que tomar decisiones importantes. "Los doctores estÃ¡n muy espantados con el cÃ¡ncer de mama y quieren meter al protocolo de quimios y radios a todo el mundo".

El cÃ¡ncer de mama es la primer causa de muerte entre las mujeres mexicanas.

via GIPHY

El problema con ese tipo de tratamientos es que se complementan con un medicamento llamado tamoxifen que baja drÃ¡sticamente los niveles hormonales volviendo imposible un embarazo durante un lapso de aproximadamente cinco aÃ±os. "Tuve la suerte de encontrarme con la doctora Gerson que, a diferencia de todos los mÃ©dicos hombres, entendiÃ³ que estaba joven, en el momento justo para tener hijos y que todo lo que me habÃ­an hecho habÃ­a sido bastante preventivo, entonces me sugiriÃ³ hacerme la mastectomÃ­a del otro lado, dejar pasar un tiempo y volverme a embarazar".

Como el embarazo no se dio fÃ¡cilmente, Rebeca y su pareja recurrieron a un tratamiento in vitro y asÃ­ se logrÃ³ un embarazo idÃ©ntico al que perdiÃ³ la primera vez: gemelar de dos niÃ±as. "Para mÃ­ era muy importante ser mamÃ¡ porque yo no tuve una". Las niÃ±as nacieron de manera prematura y no poderlas lactar fue un tema que afectÃ³ profundamente a Rebeca pues sabÃ­a que era algo que les hubiera ayudado mucho a sus hijas. Hoy ella y sus hijas gozan de excelente salud. "Me siento profundamente agradecida por poder seguir mi vida y estar cerca de mis hijas".

El cÃ¡ncer es un padecimiento relativamente comÃºn entre las mujeres en edad reproductiva. Aproximadamente 1 de cada 8 mujeres desarrollan cÃ¡ncer de mama y alrededor del 25% de ellas tienen hijos pequeÃ±os cuando sucede.

Existen factores que pueden predisponer mÃ¡s a unas mujeres que a otras como lo son la herencia genÃ©tica y diversos factores de estilo de vida. Sin embargo, ninguna mujer estÃ¡ exenta de padecerlo.

via GIPHY

En junio del 2013, cuando su hijo tenÃ­a 3 aÃ±os, Ana se detectÃ³ una bolita en el seno. "Desgraciadamente me tocÃ³ una oncÃ³loga del IMSS que fue muy negligente, opinÃ³ que era difÃ­cil que fuera cÃ¡ncer y dijo que no pasaba nada si dejaba esperaba unos meses para hacerme la biopsia". Fue hasta enero, cuando el tumor ya habÃ­a crecido, cuando le dijeron a Ana que no habÃ­a mÃ¡s que quitar el seno.

"Quise tener una segunda opiniÃ³n y me dijeron que me podÃ­an hacer la operaciÃ³n centinela (biopsia de ganglio linfÃ¡tico centinela). EncontrÃ© un gran oncÃ³logo que me apoyÃ³ mucho, por medio del Seguro Popular me dio acceso al Hospital Universitario de Monterrey y ahÃ­ recibÃ­ 16 quimioterapias y unas 28 o 30 radiaciones. Nunca me sentÃ­ mal con eso, si no fuera porque se me cayÃ³ el pelo, no tenÃ­a ni dolor. Me hicieron la cuadrantectomÃ­a y me conservaron el pecho".

El doctor la dejÃ³ en observaciÃ³n y le recetÃ³ tamoxifen. Poco mÃ¡s de un aÃ±o despuÃ©s, un dÃ­a a Ana se le terminÃ³ la medicina, se tardÃ³ en volver a comprarla y le vino la menstruaciÃ³n. AhÃ­ ella pensÃ³ que podÃ­a aprovechar ese momento para buscar un embarazo con su esposo y asÃ­ lo hicieron. LogrÃ³ un embarazo anembrionario que tuvo que abortar. "Acepto que fue mi error dejar el medicamento, pero yo querÃ­a volver a vivir la vida normalmente, formar una familia. Me sentÃ­a capaz de eso".

Hace cinco meses que Ana estÃ¡ incapacitada de nuevo. Ahora con metÃ¡stasis en sistema Ã³seo, costillas y pulmones. Su hijo estÃ¡ consciente de lo que esto implica pues desde los tres aÃ±os ha vivido de cerca el padecimiento de su madre. "Cuando mi hijo tenÃ­a cuatro aÃ±os conociÃ³ lo que era un piso de quimioterapia. Ã‰l viviÃ³ toda la enfermedad conmigo porque yo nunca lo quise dejar mientras me iba al tratamiento, era muy complicado dejarlo asÃ­ que preferÃ­a llevÃ¡rmelo. No he tenido que bombardearlo de informaciÃ³n ni maquillarle la realidad, Ã©l lo ha visto todo con sus propios ojos".

Y es que ademÃ¡s de luchar por la vida, cuando una madre joven padece cÃ¡ncer de mama, su mayor preocupaciÃ³n es encontrar tiempo y fuerzas para estar con sus hijos, ademÃ¡s de hacerles el proceso comprensible y llevadero. Para Ana la clave para sobrellevar la enfermedad es la actitud: no se trata de querer dar lÃ¡stima sino de seguir adelante y sacar fuerzas y tiempo de donde. Para ella se vale llorar, caerse, pero siempre levantarse. "El cÃ¡ncer hace que te cambie la manera de pensar. Dejas de darle importancia a cosas que no la tienen, empiezas realmente a vivir".

Con el cÃ¡ncer de mama no existe tal cosa como la prevenciÃ³n: la Ãºnica manera de combatirlo es la detecciÃ³n temprana. La autoexploraciÃ³n se recomienda cada mes desde los 20 aÃ±os y realizar mastografÃ­as de manera periÃ³dica a partir de los 40 aÃ±os es una manera de reducir el riesgo de mortandad. Los ultrasonidos son un complemento recomendable para detectar aquello que no se revela en la mastografÃ­a. Y para crear la cultura de la detecciÃ³n temprana, no hay mÃ¡s que hablar del tema para que ninguna mujer quede indiferente al mismo.

*Este contenido representa la opiniÃ³n del autor y no necesariamente la de HuffPost MÃ©xico.
TITLE: CÃ¡ncer de mama y maternidad: un reto extendido

TEXT:
If you're one of those people who go to several Halloween parties and by the night of Oct. 31 you're lazy AF, sweat not.

There are some legit, easy DIY costumes that you can create in just two simple steps. Whether you live (or die) for this haunted night, you can enjoy your time with the undead by opting for a supremely lazy costume.

1. Offred from "The Handmaid'sâ€‹ â€‹Tale"

A post shared by Jennifer Belsher (@love.heels.everything) on Oct 15, 2017 at 1:50pm PDT

Since this Hulu series has become the new show to binge-watch, how about going as Offred? All you need is a red robe and a white bonnet.

2. Arthur

A post shared by Lauren Riihimaki (@laurdiy) on Oct 2, 2016 at 5:30pm PDT

All you need is a yellow jumper, round glasses and a pair of cute ears to pull off the perfect Arthur.

3. "Atomic Blonde"

A post shared by Lady Ember Brennen Sparks (@ladyemberbsparks) on Aug 11, 2017 at 8:39am PDT

Easiest costume ever. Simply pull out your mini LBD, a pair of black thigh-high boots and your black fall coat. If you're blond, great. If not, get a wig and some shades to kick some ass.

4. Regina George from "Mean Girls"

A post shared by ğŸ’‹ Lauren ğŸ’‹ (@xxlaurenxx55) on Jul 19, 2014 at 4:47pm PDT

The classic Regina George. All you have to do is cut two holes in a tank top and wear it over a colourful bra or tank top. Just sport the menacing "Mean Girl" look and you're a plastic. Congratulations.

5. Shia LaBeouf

A post shared by ğŸ€ SHSL YOINK ğŸ (@dinosparkles) on Aug 7, 2016 at 5:41pm PDT

Remember the time Shia LaBeouf wore a paper bag over his head to a film premiere? Now that's an easy Halloween costume!

6. Snapchat filter

A post shared by Megan Sundquist (@misssunkist89) on Oct 29, 2016 at 5:15pm PDT

Most of us are familiar with Snapchat filters, especially the popular deer, butterfly, and flower filters. An easy one to pull off and soothe your lazy soul is the deer filter. Simply apply makeup on your face and nose, and maybe add a pair of antlers. Cute, eh? You could also try the butterfly filter by sporting a gold headband and some glitter over your forehead.

7. Georgie from "It"

A post shared by a n a l u c i a (@anallatas) on Oct 7, 2017 at 10:54am PDT

Remember Georgie from the horror movie "It"? All you have to do is wear a yellow raincoat and a red balloon and you're all set to be Pennywise's next victim.

8. Britney Spears

A post shared by Kianna PedersenğŸœğŸŒŒ (@beingkianna) on Oct 28, 2016 at 11:30pm PDT

Britney has given us life with her music videos, and her iconic outfits have given us a Halloween costume. You can easily recreate the "...Baby One More Time" outfit with a white shirt, black skirt and grey sweater.

9. Glam Skull

A post shared by Mayra Calleros (@lensmakememories) on Oct 16, 2017 at 6:59pm PDT

Glam skull makeup is easy to do and all you need is a black dress to complete the look. We're sure you already have all the tools you need to pull this one off.

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Easy DIY Halloween Costumes For The Supremely Lazy

Leipzig empfÃ¤ngt den VfB Stuttgart - fÃ¼r FuÃŸball-Fans auch im Live-Stream

Das Video oben zeigt, wie ihr die Bundesliga im Internet sehen kÃ¶nnt

Die Samstagsbegegnung beginnt um 15.30 Uhr

RB Leipzig - VfB Stuttgart im Live-Stream: Mit dem vierten Bundesligasieg in Serie wollen die Sachsen den Kontakt zum Spitzenduo Dortmund und MÃ¼nchen halten. Die Chancen dafÃ¼r sind da: Die Schwaben sind mit drei Siegen, einem Remis und vier Niederlagen Tabellenelfter - und haben auswÃ¤rts alle vier Spiele verloren.

Nun ist das erste Aufeinandertreffen beider Teams in der Bundesliga. Denn im Vorjahr stieg RB in die Bundesliga auf und Stuttgart in die 2. Liga ab.

Und ein weiteres Spiel am Samstag: Der Hamburger SV trifft am Samstag um 18.30 Uhr auf Bayern MÃ¼nchen. Der FC Bayern ist an TabellenfÃ¼hrer Dortmund unter Trainer Heynckes schon wieder bis auf zwei Punkte herangerÃ¼ckt.

Der HSV hingegen ist seit sechs Partien sieglos und muss bei einer weiteren Niederlage den Absturz auf die AbstiegsrÃ¤nge fÃ¼rchten. Und die Statistik macht da keinen Mut: Der HSV feierte seinen letzten Heimsieg gegen Bayern am 26. September 2009.

Wie ihr RB Leipzig - VfB Stuttgart im Live-Stream sehen kÃ¶nnt

Die Bundesliga-Spiele am Samstag kÃ¶nnen FuÃŸball-Fans mit Sky im Pay-TV und im Internet verfolgen. Sky Sport 4 berichtet ab 15.10 Uhr aus Leipzig. Sky Sport 1 bietet die Samstags-Konferenz der Duelle, die um 15.30 Uhr angepfiffen werden, und ab 17.30 Uhr das Spiel zwischen dem HSV und dem FCB.

Abonnenten und KÃ¤ufer eines Spieltag-Tickets von Sky kÃ¶nnen die Ãœbertragungen auch im Live-Stream sehen - und zwar auf dem Portal Sky Go.

â–º Bundesliga auf Sky Go im Internet sehen (Abo)

Angebot: DAZN bietet seinen Abonnenten die Highlights der 1. Bundesliga in der Zusammenfassung an. â¨ Hier kÃ¶nnt ihr euren Gratismonat starten Danach beginnt ein kostenpflichtiges Abonnement.

Das Bundesliga-Spiel auf Amazon live verfolgen

Wer sich das Bundesliga-Spiel am Samstag lieber anhÃ¶rt, der hat die Wahl: Zum einen Ã¼bertragen die Regionalsender der ARD die Samstagsspiele im Radio. Zwar nicht komplett, jedoch verpasst ihr in der Regel dort kein Highlight.

â–º Hier kÃ¶nnt ihr die Bundesliga-Ãœbertragungen der "Sportschau" im Radio anhÃ¶ren

Wer die ganze Begegnung im Audio-Live-Stream verfolgen mÃ¶chte, kann dies auf Amazon. Amazon Music Ã¼bertrÃ¤gt fÃ¼r Amazon-Prime-Abonnenten alle Bundesliga-Spiele einzeln und in der Konferenz.

â–º Bundesliga im Audiostream von Amazon hÃ¶ren - hier geht's lang (Abo)

Das kÃ¶nnte euch auch interessieren:

â¨ 2. Bundesliga im Live-Stream: Wie ihr die FuÃŸball-Spiele 2017/18 online sehen kÃ¶nnt

â¨ MÃ¶nchengladbach - Leverkusen im Live-Stream: Bundesliga-Derby online sehen, so geht's

â¨ Frankfurt - BVB Dortmund im Live-Stream: 1. Bundesliga online sehen, so geht's

SUMMARY:
Singer Justine Skye took a knee as she sang the national anthem before the Brooklyn Netsâ€™ home opener against the Orlando Magic on Friday night.
The 22-year-old Brooklyn native dropped to one knee towards the end of her performance at the Barclays Center.
â€œWe will not be silenced.â€ Skye captioned her post with the #blacklivesmatter hashtag, in an apparent show of solidarity with the movement.
Skyeâ€™s taking of the knee is a continuation of the ongoing protests inspired by the National Football League demonstrations against police brutality and racial injustice.
They began when former San Francisco 49er Colin Kaepernick started taking the knee during the anthem last year, and have been repeatedly criticized by President Donald Trump.
TEXT:
Singer Justine Skye took a knee as she sang the national anthem before the Brooklyn Netsâ€™ home opener against the Orlando Magic on Friday night.

The 22-year-old Brooklyn native dropped to one knee towards the end of her performance at the Barclays Center. She was greeted by a mixture of boos and cheers from the basketball fans, per CBS News.

Watch the video here:

A post shared by The Purple Unicorn (@justineskye) on Oct 20, 2017 at 5:08pm PDT

â€œGot a bit shaky at the endâ€¦ was pretty uneasy about singing the anthem and probably wonâ€™t ever be invited to sing it again,â€ Skye later posted on Instagram.

â€œBut I had to take a a knee for the opening game in my city and let my voice be heard,â€ she added. â€œWe will not be silenced.â€ Skye captioned her post with the #blacklivesmatter hashtag, in an apparent show of solidarity with the movement.

A Nets spokeswoman said the team recognized that Skye had â€œkneeled brieflyâ€ but had not been aware â€œthat she was going to do so,â€ reports ABC News.

Skyeâ€™s taking of the knee is a continuation of the ongoing protests inspired by the National Football League demonstrations against police brutality and racial injustice. They began when former San Francisco 49er Colin Kaepernick started taking the knee during the anthem last year, and have been repeatedly criticized by President Donald Trump.
TITLE: National Anthem Singer Takes A Knee Before Brooklyn Nets Home Opener

SUMMARY:
Vom "Marschall-Plan" fÃ¼r Afrika ist oft die Rede, wenn es darum geht, eine Antwort auf die Krisen des afrikanischen Kontinents zu finden.
Er habe gleich Bedenken gehabt, "dass das eine MilchmÃ¤dchenrechnung ist", sagte der Schriftsteller und Reporter Hans Christoph Buch im GesprÃ¤ch mit der deutschen Tageszeitung "Welt".
Denn um den Plan umzusetzen, mÃ¼ssten die Regierungen der Industriestaaten mit zweifelhaften Regierungen in Afrika zusammenarbeiten.
Die Regierungen wÃ¼rden kurzsichtig handeln und die humanitÃ¤ren Krisen vor ihren Toren verschÃ¤rfen.
Auf das Leiden und die NÃ¶te der Hilfesuchenden.
TEXT:
Ein Experte fÃ¤llt ein vernichtendes Urteil Ã¼ber den Afrika-Plan der Bundesregierung

Statt Fluchtursachen wirksam zu bekÃ¤mpfen, unterstÃ¼tze Berlin korrupte und autokratische Staaten

Das Fazit des Experten Ã¼ber den "Marshall-Plan" fÃ¼r Afrika seht ihr auch oben im Video

Die Bundesregierung hat die Herausforderung erkannt. Vom "Marschall-Plan" fÃ¼r Afrika ist oft die Rede, wenn es darum geht, eine Antwort auf die Krisen des afrikanischen Kontinents zu finden. Mit Investitionen sollen Fabriken gebaut und Jobs geschaffen werden.

Doch Experten halten die MaÃŸnahmen der deutschen und anderen europÃ¤ischen Regierungen fÃ¼r ungenÃ¼gend. Er habe gleich Bedenken gehabt, "dass das eine MilchmÃ¤dchenrechnung ist", sagte der Schriftsteller und Reporter Hans Christoph Buch im GesprÃ¤ch mit der deutschen Tageszeitung "Welt".

Denn um den Plan umzusetzen, mÃ¼ssten die Regierungen der Industriestaaten mit zweifelhaften Regierungen in Afrika zusammenarbeiten. "Und wenn man korrupten Regierungen Geld und Hilfe anbietet, werden die VerhÃ¤ltnisse nicht unbedingt besser", warnt Buch. "Vor allem die FlÃ¼chtlingsstrÃ¶me lassen dann nicht nach."

Niemand will wahrhaben, wie groÃŸ die afrikanische Krise ist

Afrika stecke in einer Krise, deren AusmaÃŸ niemand wahrhaben wolle, sagt der Autor des Buchs "Black Box Afrika". TatsÃ¤chlich zeigen allein schon ein paar wenige Zahlen, wie groÃŸ die Herausforderungen sind:

â–º Allein in Subsahara-Afrika werden bis 2050 800 Millionen junge MÃ¤nner und Frauen auf den Arbeitsmarkt drÃ¤ngen.

â–º Die BevÃ¶lkerungszahl wird sich auf dem Kontinent laut Prognosen bis 2050 von einer auf zwei Milliarden Menschen verdoppeln.

â–º Allein im Jahr 2015 mussten 2,4 Millionen Afrikaner vor Krieg und Gewalt flÃ¼chten.

Buch alarmiert vor allem, dass die meisten Regierungen in Afrika korrupt oder autokratisch seien. Der Kontinent versinke in einem "Sumpf der Korruption". Und die europÃ¤ischen Regierungen wÃ¼rden nun diese Regierungen mit Investitionen weiter fÃ¶rdern.

"Wir alimentieren Regimes, vor denen gerade die Leute weglaufen. Die fliehen, weil sie keine Chance haben in Staaten, die von einer Ethnie oder Partei zu einem Selbstbedienungsladen gemacht worden sind", sagt Buch.

"Merkel behandelt die Krise als Algebra-Problem"

Auch das renommierte US-Magazin "Foreign Policy" widmete sich kÃ¼rzlich in einer mehrteiligen Serie der europÃ¤ischen Afrika-Politik. Das Urteil der Autoren fiel vernichtend aus. Die Regierungen wÃ¼rden kurzsichtig handeln und die humanitÃ¤ren Krisen vor ihren Toren verschÃ¤rfen.

"EuropÃ¤ische Staats- und Regierungschefs, inklusive Merkel, behandeln die Krise primÃ¤r als Problem politischer Algebra", kritisierten die "Forein Policy"-Autoren.

Ein anonymer Mitarbeiter des Bundesentwicklungsministeriums gestand im GesprÃ¤ch mit dem Magazin Ã¼ber den "Marschall-Plan": "Wir haben genau diese Hilfe seit Dekaden geleistet. Jetzt packen wir ein neues Schild drauf, nennen es Marshall-Plan und tun so, als ob wir damit das Migrations-Problem lÃ¶sen. Es hat auch frÃ¼her nicht geklappt."

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Die Obergrenze fÃ¼r FlÃ¼chtlinge lÃ¶st keine Probleme â€“ weil Europa nicht auf die nÃ¤chste Krise vorbereitet ist

Das mÃ¼sste Europa tun

Dabei gebe es schon heute gute und sinnvolle Projekte, sagt Schriftsteller Buch gegenÃ¼ber der "Welt". Allerdings seien viele Projekte immer noch eher Symbolpolitik - und keine echte Hilfe fÃ¼r die Menschen vor Ort.

Er fordert, den Kampf gegen Fluchtursachen ernsthaft anzugehen. AuÃŸerdem rÃ¤t er den europÃ¤ischen Staaten:

â–º Menschen in Afrika sollten die Chance haben, schon in ihren LÃ¤ndern einen Visumsantrag zu stellen.

â–º Die EU und die UN mÃ¼ssten Lager fÃ¼r Asylsuchende einrichten, in denen die menschenwÃ¼rdige ZustÃ¤nde herrschen.

Was bleibt, ist die Hoffnung

Zumindest die AsylantrÃ¤ge will die EU zukÃ¼nftig auch schon in Afrika ausstellen lassen. Das sagte der franzÃ¶sische PrÃ¤sident Emmanuel Macron im August auf dem EU-Migrationsgipfel in Paris.

Bundeskanzlerin Merkel verfolgt zugleich weiter den Plan, die Mittelmeer-Route fÃ¼r illegale Asylsuchende zu schlieÃŸen - und akzeptiert damit auch LÃ¶sungen wie die Zusammenarbeit zwischen Italien und Libyen. Dabei berichten Menschenrechtsorganisationen immer wieder von den schrecklichen ZustÃ¤nden in den libyschen FlÃ¼chtlingslagern.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Was ich als Arzt in Libyen in einem Gefangenenlager fÃ¼r FlÃ¼chtlinge erlebt habe

Buch zeigt sich am Ende des GesprÃ¤chs mit der "Welt" ratlos. "Ich bin immer wieder in Afrika gewesen und denke stets aufs Neue darÃ¼ber nach: Was kann man machen, wie kann man Fehler der Vergangenheit vermeiden?" Ein Patentrezept gebe es jedenfalls nicht.

Seit die afrikanischen Staaten sich von den Fesseln des Kolonialismus befreit hÃ¤tten, sei die Lage nicht besser, sondern eher schlechter geworden. Was bleibe, sei die Hoffnung, dass sich die Situation doch noch wendet.

"Hoffnung gibt es immer. Vielleicht sieht es schon in ein paar Jahren besser aus, wer weiÃŸ das", lautet das Fazit des Experten.

FlÃ¼chtlingskrise: Helft den Helfern! Die FlÃ¼chtlingskrise bewegt die Deutschen wie kein anderes Thema. Viele blicken fassungslos auf das, was sich an Europas Grenzen abspielt. Auf das Leiden und die NÃ¶te der Hilfesuchenden. Dabei gibt es zahlreiche Menschen und Organisationen, die vor Ort helfen, die Probleme zu lÃ¶sen. Wie ihr selbst aktiv werden kÃ¶nnt, erfahrt ihr bei unserem Kooperationspartner Betterplace..

(sk)
TITLE: "Das ist eine MilchmÃ¤dchen-Rechnung": Experte nimmt Merkels Afrika-Plan auseinander

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTTransportation minister Nitin Gadkari made an announcement recently that India will switch completely to electric vehicles by 2030.
The brave initiative to switch completely to electric vehicles will obviously face many social and political challenges.
All climate actions that require disruptive socio-technical transitions will face hurdles, some expected and some unexpected.
Cab services like Ola have also announced their plans to switch to electric vehicles.
The switch to electric vehicles can thus be a golden opportunity.
TEXT:
A range of newly-launched Tata Motors Ltd. hybrid and electric buses stand on display at the company's commercial vehicle manufacturing unit in Pune, India, on Wednesday, Jan. 25, 2017. Image used for representational purposes only.

ADVERTISEMENT

Transportation minister Nitin Gadkari made an announcement recently that India will switch completely to electric vehicles by 2030. Bold indeed! The earlier initiative from 2015 called Faster Adoption and Manufacture of (Hybrid and) Electric vehicles (FLAME) seems to have failed to take off. But Mr. Gadkari said this time he will just bulldoze his way through. Considering that India imports over 80% of its crude oil at a cost of over $80 billion, and air pollution is now blamed for over 1 million premature deaths per year, this transformation would be a giant step towards energy security and air quality improvements of unprecedented levels.

While the United States saw an increase in the sale of bigger vehicles due to the drop in crude oil prices over the last few years, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government chose to keep petrol and diesel prices the same or even slightly higher during these cheap crude oil years. The additional revenues have largely gone to reducing the fuel-subsidies and to deal with the slowdown in economic growth. The brave initiative to switch completely to electric vehicles will obviously face many social and political challenges. All climate actions that require disruptive socio-technical transitions will face hurdles, some expected and some unexpected. The expected resistance will come from established industries and institutions that stand to lose, and the entrenched behavioral patterns of citizens whose pocketbooks or ways of life get hit by these transitions.

'Creative destruction' to destabilise the old structures is as critical as the innovation, and adoption of the new.

The good news for India's transition to all-electric-vehicles is that charging stations have already popped up in states such as Karnataka and Maharashtra due to their early adoption of electric vehicles for government fleets. Cab services like Ola have also announced their plans to switch to electric vehicles. Some auto-manufacturers have also taken steps towards increasing the production of electric cars and two-wheelers. The cost of batteries and battery charges have seen a significant global reduction while charging speeds as well battery quality have gone up. Companies like Tesla are already salivating at the idea of capturing the Indian electric car market share.

Several policies and incentives have been put forth for facilitating the transition such as the subsidies for hybrid and electric bikes and cars by the National Electric Mobility Mission Plan. While most of the sociotechnical transition plans focus on policies and incentives to drive adoption and innovation towards the new technologies, much less attention is paid towards strategies to dismantle the old technologies. The so-called 'creative destruction' to destabilise the old structures is as critical as the innovation and adoption of the new.

For example, manufacturing and marketing, the workforce, education/training and R&D that support petrol and diesel vehicles cannot simply be wished away by 2030. Planned phasing out of this massive infrastructure is as critical if nst more so, as simultaneously driving the innovation for manufacturing, training a new workforce or retraining much of the existing workforce, mental models to drive large-scale adoption of electric vehicles as well as the infrastructure for electricity production, charging stations, smarter grids, and better and cheaper batteries as well as their recycling.

Unplanned transitions can create long-lasting trauma, the worst case being the mine closures in the UK which have left persistent social problems due to a failure to retrain the mine workers

Unplanned transitions can create long-lasting trauma, the worst case being the mine closures in the UK which have left persistent social problems due to a failure to retrain the mine workers. Some of the current global backlash against immigration, and the swing to the Right in election outcomes are blamed on socio-technical transitions that have not included appropriate policy mixes for creative destruction of the old while transitioning to the new. The framework provided for deep decarbonisation also apply to the many socio-technical transitions India must undergo to live up to its commitments to the Paris Agreement.

The planned transition to electric vehicles may offer a golden opportunity to focus on combining the positive incentives to drive consumers, corporations, local and state governments towards them, with policies and subsidies to transition out of using petrol and diesel vehicles. Removing the subsidies that already exist for petrol/diesel vehicles is obviously the first task. But unintended consequences must be kept in mind. For example: diesel vehicles are now the main mode of transporting food and grains which means the transition to electric vehicles must ensure that food prices are not affected adversely, especially for the poor.

Large-scale social acceptance will require business support as well as efforts to raise awareness of co-benefits such as cleaner air, water and food.

The challenge of the cost, quality, comfort, and maintenance of electric vehicles can hardly be underestimated. As of now, fewer than 25,000 electric vehicles are sold annually but the drop in price expected in the coming years will bump up demand. Past transitions have relied on different but interdependent innovations. Renewable energy advances and its large-scale adoption can combine with novel battery technologies, smart grids, increased electric vehicle demand with supportive policies and subsidies, as well new business models may work as a game-changer for the transition to electric vehicles.

But the government needs to proactively facilitate the synergy of innovations and policies needed for making electric vehicles an attractive alternative, while also driving the creative destruction of the petrol/diesel vehicles as a way of life. Large-scale social acceptance will require business support as well as efforts to raise awareness of co-benefits such as cleaner air, water and food. And a broader discourse on the positive outcomes of a low-carbon economy in terms of global competitiveness and quality of life in addition to standards of living.

Climate policies can benefit from technological innovations which offer solutions and accelerate the green spiral.

Externalities such as unforeseen increases in oil prices or a bottom-up demand on improving air quality may well become important players in this sociotechnical transition. Climate policies can benefit from technological innovations which offer solutions and accelerate the green spiral which can lead to positive feedback of green industries coming together to expand the low-carbon coalition. Such bottom-up coalitions of businesses and societies can make climate action resilient to political setbacks: the continued climate actions by some states in the US under the Trump-administration being a prime example.

India thus need not rely simply on bans and regulations to enforce the transition to electric vehicles, or any of the other transitions necessary to keep abreast of its INDC targets. It can adopt a strategic mix of policies, incentives, regulations and subsidies to drive a smooth and equitable transition. Investments in science and technology education will also need to drive innovations and entrepreneurship to support such transitions, as well train a globally-aware workforce. This workforce will continue to exploit the green markets as well as it has cashed in on IT and other outsourcing. The switch to electric vehicles can thus be a golden opportunity.

The opinions expressed in this post are the personal views of the author. They do not necessarily reflect the views of HuffPost India. Any omissions or errors are the author's and HuffPost India does not assume any liability or responsibility for them.
TITLE: Indiaâ€™s Switch To Electric Vehicles Can Be A Global Role Model For Climate Actions

SUMMARY:
"Although further work is required to confirm our results, our findings suggest that exposure to hair dyes may contribute to breast cancer risk."
Mokbel also added that the link between frequent hair dye use and breast cancer is just a correlation.
"The positive association between the use of hair dyes and breast cancer risk does not represent evidence of a cause-effect relationship," he wrote on Facebook.
"We also found that use of chemical relaxers or straighteners was associated with a 74 per cent increased risk among Caucasians, with some differences in breast cancer risk observed by estrogen receptor status."
Another study published earlier this year also found that hair dyes increased the risk of breast cancer, noting that researchers observed a 23 per cent increase in the risk among women who dyed their hair.
TEXT:
Ladies, it might be time to start letting your hair grow in.

According to a new study by London surgeon Kefah Mokbel, women who frequently dye their hair increase their risk of developing breast cancer by about 14 per cent, reports The Independent.

In fact, Mokbel says that women should dye their hair no more than two to five times a year, which could be an issue for women who prefer to cover up greys, or those who are used to dyeing their hair regularly, which can be as much as every three weeks.

And that's not the only change Mokbel suggests we make. According to him, we should be using more natural products on our hair including henna, beetroot or rose hip.

"What I find concerning is the fact that the industry recommends women should dye their hair every four to six weeks," Mokbel said.

"Although further work is required to confirm our results, our findings suggest that exposure to hair dyes may contribute to breast cancer risk."

We should be using more natural products on our hair including henna, beetroot or rose hip.

Mokbel also added that the link between frequent hair dye use and breast cancer is just a correlation. "The positive association between the use of hair dyes and breast cancer risk does not represent evidence of a cause-effect relationship," he wrote on Facebook.

He also took to Twitter to further explain his findings, noting that women over 40 should undergo regular breast cancer screenings and that hair dyes that contain natural ingredients are safe.

It would be preferable to choose hair dyes that contain the minimum concentration of aromatic amines suchas PPD (less than 2%) â€” Kefah mokbel (@breastguide) October 14, 2017

This research confirms a previous 2017 study published in the journal Carcinogenesis, which found a link between hair dye and relaxers and breast cancer.

According to researchers at Rutgers University in New Jersey, carcinogens in the hair products may be contributing to the increased risk.

"We found that use of dark shade hair dyes was associated with a 51 per cent increase overall risk in developing breast cancer among African American women, and a 72 per cent increased risk of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer among African Americans," researchers told the Women's Circle Health Study. "We also found that use of chemical relaxers or straighteners was associated with a 74 per cent increased risk among Caucasians, with some differences in breast cancer risk observed by estrogen receptor status."

Another study published earlier this year also found that hair dyes increased the risk of breast cancer, noting that researchers observed a 23 per cent increase in the risk among women who dyed their hair.

However, according to the National Cancer Institute, while some studies have shown a link between hair dye usage and increased risk of some cancers, other studies have not shown these links.

"Studies of breast and bladder cancer have also produced conflicting results," they note. "Relatively few studies have been published about the association of hair dye use with the risk of other cancers. Based on its review of the evidence, the IARC (International Agency for Research on Cancer) Working Group concluded that personal use of hair dyes is 'not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans.'"

While some studies have shown a link between hair dye usage and increased risk of some cancers, other studies have not shown these links.

Because there's still no strong link found between personal hair dye use and increased cancer risk, the American Cancer Society notes that more studies need to be conducted and that there is no specific medical advice for people who dye their hair other than to stick to a healthy diet, be physically active, quit smoking, and get routine exams.

They also note that some people might want to avoid hair dye if they cause allergic reactions and that some doctors recommend women avoid getting their hair dyed when they're pregnant.

If you are concerned about the safety of hair dye, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration recommends reading the package instructions carefully, testing for allergic reactions before you use it on your hair, wearing gloves when using the product, not leaving the dye on your head longer than the recommended time, and rinsing your hair thoroughly with water after you're done.

TITLE: Women Who Frequently Dye Their Hair Have An Increased Risk Of Getting Breast Cancer

SUMMARY:
Image caption Steve Hewlett 1958-2017Full text of the lecture as delivered at the Royal Television Society on 28 September 2017:I am honoured to be asked to deliver this, the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture.
Thank you to the RTS, the Media Society and to Rachel for inviting me to deliver it.
It's great to have Steve's boys - Freddie, Billy, Bertie - here, his sister Sue and other members of the family too.
Steve's death was news - national news - which, had he been here to see it and to see you all gathered here for the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture - would have produced one of those characteristically laconic Hewlett chuckles.
It was news, of course, because millions had grown used to turning up the car radio or stopping the ironing or waiting before turning on the kettle to make sure they not miss the latest weekly instalment of the Hewlett cancer chronicle - in which a middle aged man described the pain in his oesophagus; the splitting of his nails or chapping of his feet; the search for the drug or the treatment that might buy him some relief and some more time before the end which he sensed and we sensed was coming all too fast.
TEXT:
Image caption Steve Hewlett 1958-2017

Full text of the lecture as delivered at the Royal Television Society on 28 September 2017:

I am honoured to be asked to deliver this, the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture.

Thank you to the RTS, the Media Society and to Rachel for inviting me to deliver it. It's great to have Steve's boys - Freddie, Billy, Bertie - here, his sister Sue and other members of the family too.

Steve's death was news - national news - which, had he been here to see it and to see you all gathered here for the first annual Steve Hewlett memorial lecture - would have produced one of those characteristically laconic Hewlett chuckles.

It was news, of course, because millions had grown used to turning up the car radio or stopping the ironing or waiting before turning on the kettle to make sure they not miss the latest weekly instalment of the Hewlett cancer chronicle - in which a middle aged man described the pain in his oesophagus; the splitting of his nails or chapping of his feet; the search for the drug or the treatment that might buy him some relief and some more time before the end which he sensed and we sensed was coming all too fast.

TEXT:
Communities across the UK are battening down the hatches with sandbags and barricades in preparation for the arrival of Storm Brian.

Treacherous conditions are forecast to set in overnight, with winds of up to 70mph battering coastal areas and driving high tidal waves over sea walls.

The storm, caused by a â€œweather bombâ€ of low pressure in the Atlantic Ocean, has already struck the western coast of Ireland with heavy rain, the Press Association reported.

Meanwhile, hazardous conditions are due to hit western parts of the UK at 4am on Saturday, as families begin their half-term holidays.

The storm comes just days after the remnants of Hurricane Ophelia thrashed the British Isles, killing three people in Ireland and leaving thousands without power.

PA Wire/PA Images Storm Brian is expected to bring lashing rains and 70mph winds this weekend

The Met Office said the southern and western coast of England will remain under a yellow weather warning for wind until midnight on Saturday, when the worst of the inclement weather will have lost potency and moved into the far north-easterly reaches of Scotland.

Met Office meteorologist Craig Snell said people should beware of venturing outdoors onto coastal walkways.

He said: â€œIf you donâ€™t need to be at the coast the best advice will be not to be there.

â€œWe are concerned that there could be some flooding at the immediate coast but even without flooding there will be some very high waves.

â€œThe best bet will be to stay safe and stay away.â€

Good evening,Rob here with tonight's summary.A blustery 48hrs ahead. Here are some #windy stats for your Friday eve https://t.co/KDZlRGU8oN pic.twitter.com/G1rrTW9KGC â€” Met Office (@metoffice) October 20, 2017

Pictures of Environment Agency staff placing steel flood barriers at Fowey in Cornwall emerged on Friday, as south-western towns braced themselves to become some of the worst affected areas of the British Isles.

National flood duty manager for the Environment Agency Ben Lukey warned members of the public against posing for photos during the hazardous conditions.

He said: â€œEnvironment Agency teams are on the ground, checking defences and taking precautionary action to close tidal gates and put up temporary barriers.

â€œWeâ€™re working with the Met Office and local authorities and are ready to respond as necessary.

Defences going up fast in Fowey as #StormBrian ğŸŒŠğŸ’¨approaches pic.twitter.com/3zHmR59Rji â€” lucie fisher (@fisher_lucie) October 20, 2017

â€œWe urge people to stay safe along the coast and warn against putting yourself in unnecessary danger by taking â€˜storm selfiesâ€™ or driving through flood water - just 30cm is enough to move your car.â€

Vehicle recovery and insurance firm The AA also reminded drivers to take extra care while surface spray, reduced visibility and potential flooding remained high risks.

Network Rail said it was gathering extra personnel ahead of the weekend in anticipation of potential disruptions, and reminded passengers to check travel updates before setting out on their journeys.

A spokesman for Network Rail said: â€œWe are keeping a close eye on Storm Brian and are doing everything we can to prepare for severe weather.

â€œWe are deploying additional teams across the railway network to remove debris quickly and safely if we need to, and to keep passengers moving.â€
TITLE: Storm Brian Sees Brits Batten Down The Hatches As They Prepare For Atlantic Ocean 'Weather Bomb'

TEXT:
Alexâ€™s fridge is emblazoned with the words â€œf*ck you cancerâ€. The sign is a daily reminder of how far she and her friend Jo have come in the past two years.

Itâ€™s not common for women under the age of 40 to be diagnosed with breast cancer, but the friends, in their thirties, both realised they had the disease within 14 months of each other.

Surprisingly though, their story is not one of tragedy, but one of hope.

Alex and Jo supported each other through the highs and lows of diagnosis and treatment, and now, they want to show other women thereâ€™s life after cancer.

HuffPost UK Jo (left) and Alex (right)

London-based Jo was diagnosed with breast cancer in September 2015 at 37 years old, after feeling pain in her breast that she initially dismissed as a symptom of PMT.

Shortly after her diagnosis she met Alex, an American also based in the capital. They were introduced at a tennis club and immediately hit it off, with a shared love of hitting the dance floor after practice.

Jo joked that nights out with Alex, getting â€œutterly drunkâ€ with their tennis team, helped her to maintain a sense of normality throughout treatment.

But just over a year later, their blossoming friendship was dealt another blow when Alex felt a lump in her breast and was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 31. Jo was one of the first people she told.

â€œI knew if anyone was going to understand what I felt like, it would be Jo,â€ she told HuffPost UK.

HuffPost UK Alex's fridge.

Having only recently ended treatment herself, hearing about Alexâ€™s diagnosis was difficult for Jo.

â€œItâ€™s actually quite awful to hear that someone else has got it,â€ she said.

â€œWhen youâ€™ve got it yourself, youâ€™re constantly fighting, youâ€™re having the appointments, the meetings with doctors, and you donâ€™t really have time to step back and think about the emotional side of things.

â€œBut when itâ€™s someone close to you, you actually then realise how absolutely terrifying it is. I was devastated. I think itâ€™s worse to look at someone going through it.â€

With Alexâ€™s family spread across America, Jo became an invaluable lifeline for her. She became the person Alex went to for fun and distraction, but also the person she lent on during her darkest moments.

â€œIt was so helpful to have somebody who knew what to go through and how it would feel, and to know that no matter how bad my day was, I could always call,â€ Alex said.

Jo Jo in hospital during treatment.

Despite the parallels in their diagnosis, the treatment the two friends received was quite different.

Jo had a mastectomy and implant reconstruction, without chemotherapy, and is currently taking daily tamoxifen tablets and receiving a monthly zoladex implant injection.

Meanwhile Alex had a lumpectomy followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy, which she finished in May of this year. Like Jo, she is also still taking daily tamoxifen tablets and receiving a monthly injection.

Because of the different nature of their treatments, Alex and Jo experienced different side effects, with Alex losing her hair.

â€œHair is so easily your identity as a woman,â€ Alex said.

â€œI loved my hair. It was very long and hair makes you feel sexy. As soon as you lose it you have a really hard time... I still donâ€™t feel like I look sexy. But you do get used to it.â€

Jo added that not losing her hair has also caused problems, as cancer treatment is so often associated with hair loss.

â€œWeirdly enough, people seem to think Iâ€™m either lying about my cancer because Iâ€™ve still got my hair, or people ask me why Iâ€™ve still got hair if Iâ€™ve had cancer - which is a really weird thing to ask somebody,â€ she said.

Alex Alex and Jo.

Both Alex and Jo were keen to share their stories to prove breast cancer isnâ€™t just an â€œold lady diseaseâ€.

Almost half (48%) of breast cancer cases in the UK each year are diagnosed in people over the age of 65, and as women in their thirties, Alex and Jo struggled to find support they could relate to.

â€œWhen you go online and look for help, all the pamphlets that you find have got old ladies on them, it makes you feel like youâ€™ve got an old lady disease,â€ Jo explained.

â€œI had a mastectomy with an implant reconstruction, which is something that a lot of young women struggle with because most of the information covering mastectomies uses older womenâ€™s experiences.

â€œI want to show other young people that you can still look normal after a mastectomy - Iâ€™m quite proud of my Barbie boob!â€

Thankfully, the pair were able to access the information and support they needed thanks to Breast Cancer Haven, a charity that supports women through cancer treatment.

Staff at the Haven offer practical advice on things like managing money and employment, healthy eating and combating stress through treatment.

Women can also join exercise classes or therapy groups specifically tailored to breast cancer patients.

But ultimately, itâ€™s their strong friendship that has helped Alex and Jo navigate diagnosis, treatment and aftercare, together.

â€œItâ€™s been amazing,â€ Alex told Jo. â€œI donâ€™t know what I would have done without you.â€

For more information about Breast Cancer Haven, visit the website here.

Breast Cancer Signs And Treatment
TITLE: Two Friends Took On Breast Cancer Together After Being Diagnosed 14 Months Apart

SUMMARY:
As part of our 2017 Canadian University Rankings, we asked over 40,000 students to rate their schools across 40-plus categories.
One of these categories measured how likely students were to recommend their school to friends or family, similar to a classic metric used by marketers to gauge how strongly a company's customers would advocate for them.
Out of 72 Canadian universities, the average rating was a respectable 7.7 out of 10.
If you're curious which school we recommend for your unique personality type, take our signature school matching quiz (it's free).
Overall, the university's career services centre is rated #6 among universities in Canada, adding yet another point of value to students.
TEXT:
As part of our 2017 Canadian University Rankings, we asked over 40,000 students to rate their schools across 40-plus categories. One of these categories measured how likely students were to recommend their school to friends or family, similar to a classic metric used by marketers to gauge how strongly a company's customers would advocate for them. We are the first to measure this for schools across Canada.

Out of 72 Canadian universities, the average rating was a respectable 7.7 out of 10. However, only 19 schools received a rating greater than 8, and the lowest-performing school scored 5.6 (we won't name names). What we will do, however, is highlight the four schools with the highest ratings.

If you're curious which school we recommend for your unique personality type, take our signature school matching quiz (it's free).

The students have spoken. Bishop's is officially Canada's most-recommended university â€” by a landslide. But we're not surprised. Bishop's ranks extremely well across many of our university rankings categories. In fact, they rank top 10 in a total of 30 categories, including Best Overall Value (#1), Happiest Students (#2) and Most Approachable Professors (#5).

Bishop's focuses on undergraduate education and provides students opportunities beyond just the lecture hall. These include co-op placements, internships and access to a top-rated study-abroad program. Bishop's even developed an academic credit course for students participating in serious levels of competitions, like Model UN, as well as a special projects fund to support endeavours like a history student conducting archaeology work in Europe or a political science student doing a study tour of the European Union.

"The average first year class size is [36], smaller than many upper year classes at larger schools," a former Bishop's Gaiter explained in one of Bishop's student reviews. "Purple pride is evident in many aspects of the alumni," says another student â€” an empowering fact when combined with the school's unofficial motto: Bleed Purple.

A football game between Sherbrooke and Laval University in Quebec City.

2. UniversitÃ© de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke & Longueuil, Que. (8.7/10)

UniversitÃ© de Sherbrooke is a French-language university, and perhaps isn't as widely known as it should be. But the QuÃ©becois are well aware of the massive school, which is home to 40,000 students and over 3,000 staff across its three major campuses.

USherbrooke also performed incredibly well in our university rankings, placing in the top 10 across 19 categories. Their specialty is career-focused education, and they rank competitively among Canada's universities for Best for Getting a Job (#3), and first in Canada in the Best for Employer Recruiting and Best Co-op Program categories (yes, it beating the University of Waterloo).

Established in 1954, USherbrooke was the first university in Canada to implement a co-operative education program, and today they continue to place over 4,000 students in career-relevant, paid industry roles annually. "The co-op programs are very well made and I have never heard of a student who did not find an internship," notes a student in their review of the school.

Founded in 1911 with just 197 students, Mount Royal University is considered to be one of the world's 40 Changemaker Campuses for its commitment to campus-wide excellence in social innovation. Mount Royal U is specifically known and renowned for its unique research centres, dedicated to issues like non-profit studies, children's well-being and scholarship. The school has eight strong sports teams (go Cougars!), and is considered by students to have one of the best recreation and sports facilities in Canada.

Students here also enjoy learning in small classes (average class size is 29) in Mount Royal's most famous programs: business, communications, nursing and public relations. International study is also a popular choice, with students regularly travelling around the world to experience and learn in different environments. Overall, the university's career services centre is rated #6 among universities in Canada, adding yet another point of value to students. As one student describes it, the university has "lots of alumni involvement and career help opportunities," which are a "huge help in any area needed."

Another one of Canada's oldest universities cracks this list at #4, having been founded in 1853. Among other things, StFX's student residences have been highly ranked in our survey; perhaps because visiting this Atlantic Coast campus makes you feel like you're visiting an Ivy League school. The school's alumni network is also considered to be the best in Canada, with alumni located in 140 countries, yet again helping students to develop their career networks.

Follow HuffPost Canada Blogs on Facebook

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Students Are Most Likely To Recommend These Canadian Universities
